The mixing interaction energy can be written as<center><math> U\mathrm{_{mix}=N_{AB}U_{AB}+N_{AA}U_{AA}+N_{BB}U_{BB}},</math></center> where the <math>N_{ij}</math> count the number of boundaries of the different types within the system. In the ''mean field approximation'' , we can evaluate them by neglecting local variations in density:<center><math>\begin{matrix} N_{AB} & = & N_{A}z\frac{N_{B}}{N_{A}+N_{B}}=z\left(N_{A}+N_{B}\right)\phi\left(1-\phi\right),
N_{BB} & = & \frac{z}{2}\left(N_{A}+N_{B}\right)\left(1-\phi\right)^{2},
N_{AA} & = & \frac{z}{2}\left(N_{A}+N_{B}\right)\phi^{2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The interaction energy per-particle due to mixing is then<center><math> u_{\mathrm{mix}}=\frac{U_{\mathrm{mix}}}{N_{A}+N_{B}}=z\phi\left(1-\phi\right)U_{AB}+\frac{z}{2}\left(1-\phi\right)^{2}U_{BB}+\frac{z}{2}\phi^{2}U_{AA},</math></center> and we will subtract from it the enthalpy of the "pure" system, where the components are unmixed:<center><math> \frac{U_{0}}{N_{A}+N_{B}}=\left(1-\phi\right)\frac{z}{2}U_{BB}+\phi\frac{z}{2}U_{AA}.</math></center> The difference between these two quantities it the change in enthalpy per unit cell due to mixing:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \Delta u_{\mathrm{mix}} & = & \frac{U_{\mathrm{mix}}-U_{0}}{N_{A}+N_{B}}=\overset{{\scriptstyle \equiv k_{B}T\chi}}{\overbrace{z\left(U_{AB}-\frac{1}{2}U_{AA}-\frac{1}{2}U_{BB}\right)}}\phi\left(1-\phi\right)=k_{B}T\chi\phi\left(1-\phi\right),\end{matrix}</math></center> <center><math> \chi=\frac{1}{k_{B}T}\left[U_{AB}-\frac{U_{AA}-U_{BB}}{2}\right]z.</math></center>
The sign of the ''Flory parameter'' <math>\chi</math> determines whether the minimum of the energy will be at the center or edges of the parabola in <math>\phi</math>.<center><math>\begin{matrix} \Delta f_{\mathrm{mix}} & = & \frac{\Delta F_{\mathrm{mix}}}{N_{A}+N_{b}}=\Delta u_{\mathrm{mix}}-T\sigma_{\mathrm{mix}},\end{matrix}</math></center> <center><math> \Delta f_{\mathrm{mix}}=k_{B}T\chi\phi\left(1-\phi\right)+k_{B}T\phi\ln\phi+k_{B}T\left(1-\phi\right)\ln\left(1-\phi\right).</math></center> This is the MFT approximation for the free energy of mixing. {{Sidenote|If the two components have different volumes, then<center><math>\begin{matrix} \phi_{A} & = & \frac{v_{A}N_{A}}{v_{A}N_{A}+v_{B}N_{B}},\\
\phi_{B} & = & 1-\phi_{A}.\end{matrix}</math></center> Otherwise, the treatment is very similar (see homework).}}
====The Flory-Huggins model for polymer solutions==== This is based on work mostly done by Huggins around 1942. The basic idea is to consider a lattice like the one shown in (11), with chains (inhabiting <math>N=5</math> blocks in the example) in a solvent (which can also be a set of chains, but in the example the number of blocks per solvent unit is <math>S=1</math>). The enthalpy of mixing <math>U_{\mathrm{mix}}</math> is approximately independent of the change from the molecule-solvent system to this polymer-solvent system, at least within the MFT approximation. We can therefore set <math>\phi=\frac{N_{P}}{N_{P}+N_{S}}</math> (<math>N_{P}</math> is the number of monomers and <math>N_{S}</math> the number of solvent units; <math>\frac{N_{p}}{N}</math> is the number of chains) and use the previous expressions for <math>\Delta u_{\mathrm{mix}}</math> and <math>\chi</math>. The fact we have chains rather than individual monomers is of crucial importance when we calculate the entropy, though: chains have more constraints and therefore a lower entropy than isolated monomers. We will make an approximation (correct to first order in <math>N</math> for <math>N\gg1</math>) based on the assumption that the chains are solid objects and can only be transformed, rather than also rotated and conformed around their center of mass. {{Sidenote|This is treated in detail in the books by Flory and by Doi & Edwards.}} This gives, making the Stirling approximation as before,<center><math>\begin{array}{lcl} S_{\mathrm{mix}} & \simeq & k_{B}\frac{\left(N_{P}+N_{S}\right)!}{N_{S}!\left(\frac{N_{P}}{N}\right)!},\\
-\frac{\sigma_{\mathrm{mix}}}{k_{B}} & \simeq & \frac{\phi}{N}\ln\phi+\left(1-\phi\right)\ln\left(1-\phi\right)+\alpha\phi,\\
\alpha & = & \frac{1}{N}\ln\left(\frac{N_{S}+N_{P}}{N}\right)-\ln\left(N_{S}+N_{P}\right)+1-\frac{1}{N}.\end{array}</math></center> If we neglect the term linear in <math>\phi</math>, which we will later show is of no importance, these two expressions lead to the Flory-Huggins free energy of mixing:<center><math> f\left(\phi,T\right)=\frac{\Delta f_{\mathrm{mix}}}{k_{B}T}=\chi\phi\left(1-\phi\right)+\frac{\phi}{N}\ln\phi+\left(1-\phi\right)\ln\left(1-\phi\right).</math></center> Compared to our previous expression, we see that the only difference is in the division of the second term by <math>N</math>. {{Sidenote|This formula is for <math>S=1</math>, but it is easy to show (homework) that for a ''blend'' of two polymers with <math>N_{1}</math> and <math>N_{2}</math>, we will still have <math>\phi=\phi_{A}=1-\phi_{B}</math> and <math> \begin{array}{lcl} \scriptstyle f\left(\phi,T\right)&\scriptstyle = \scriptstyle &\frac{\Delta f_{\mathrm{mix}}}{k_{B}T}\\ &\scriptstyle =&\scriptstyle \chi\phi\left(1-\phi\right)\\ &&\scriptstyle+\frac{\phi}{N_{1}}\ln\phi+\frac{\left(1-\phi\right)}{N_{2}}\ln\left(1-\phi\right).\end{array}</math> Similarly, if the molecular volumes are different we can define <math>\scriptstyle \phi_{A}=\frac{N_{A}V_{A}}{N_{A}V_{A}+N_{B}V_{B}}</math> and <math>\scriptstyle \phi_{B}=\frac{N_{B}V_{B}}{N_{A}V_{A}+N_{B}V_{B}}</math>, then continue to use the same expression.}}
====Polymer/solvent phase transfers====
A system composed of a polymer immersed in a solvent can be in a uniform phase (corresponding to a good solvent) or separated into two distinct phases (a bad solvent). Qualitatively, this depends on <math>\chi</math>: the entropic contribution to the free energy from <math>\sigma_{\mathrm{mix}}</math> will always prefer mixing, but the preference of <math>\Delta u_{\mathrm{mix}}</math> depends on the the sign of <math>\chi</math>. Phase transfers can only possibly exist if <math>\chi>0</math>, because otherwise the total change in energy due to mixing is always negative. When discussing Helmholtz free energy, <math>\phi</math> is the degree of freedom - however, in the physical case of interest it constant and we must perform a Legendre transformation, or in other words introduce a Lagrange multiplier to impose the constraint that <math>\phi=\Phi</math>. We therefore define<center><math> g=f-\mu\phi,</math></center> and after <math>g</math> is minimized <math>\mu</math> will be determined so as to maintain our constraint (it turns out that <math>\mu</math> is the difference between the chemical potentials of the polymer and solvent). When <math>g</math> has multiple minima (<math>\frac{dg}{d\phi}=\frac{df}{d\phi}-\mu=0</math> for more than one <math>\phi</math>), a phase transfer can exist.
If <math>g</math> has only one minimum at <math>\phi</math>, then we must have <math>f^{\prime}\left(\phi\right)=\mu</math>. If <math>g</math> has two minima, a first order phase transfer will exist when the free energy <math>g</math> at these two minima is the same. This amount to a ''common tangent construction'' condition for <math>f</math> (see 12):<center><math> \begin{cases} f\left(\phi_{1}\right)-\mu\phi_{1}=f\left(\phi_{2}\right)-\mu\phi_{2},\\
f^{\prime}\left(\phi_{1}\right)=f^{\prime}\left(\phi_{2}\right)=\mu.\end{cases}</math></center> This requires <math>f\left(\phi_{1}\right)-f\left(\phi_{2}\right)=\mu\left(\phi_{1}-\phi_{2}\right)</math>. The two formulations (in terms of <math>g</math> and <math>f</math>) are of course identical. The common tangent actually describes the free energy <math>f</math> of a mixed phase system (having a volume <math>v_{1}</math> at concentration <math>\phi_{1}</math> and a volume <math>v_{2}</math> at concentration <math>\phi_{2}</math>, such that <math>\Phi=\frac{v_{1}\phi_{1}}{v_{1}\phi_{1}+v_{2}\phi_{2}}</math>). When <math>\phi_{1}<\phi<\phi_{2}</math> this line is always lower than the concave profile of the uniform system with concentration <math>\phi</math>, and therefore the mixed-phase system must be the stable state.
Note that any additional term to <math>f</math> which is linear in <math>\phi</math> will only produce a shift in <math>\mu</math>, and not qualitatively change the phase diagram. This is because <center><math>\begin{array}{lcl} f & \rightarrow & f+\alpha\phi\\
& \Downarrow\\
g & \rightarrow & \left(f+\alpha\phi\right)-\mu\phi=f-\left(\mu-\alpha\right)\phi.\end{array}</math></center>
Returning to the Flory-Huggins mixing energy, for <math>\chi>0</math> we can see that <math>f</math> has two minima and the system can therefore be in two phases. For <math>\chi<0</math> only one minimum exist, and therefore only one phase. Generalizing beyond the Flory-Huggins model, at any temperature <math>T</math> there exists some <math>\chi\left(T\right)</math>, and often a dependence <math>\chi\left(T\right)=A-\frac{B}{T}</math> works well experimentally (we have found a dependence <math>\sim\frac{1}{T}</math> assuming that the interactions are independent of temperature). For every <math>T</math> or <math>\chi</math>, we can find <math>\phi_{1}</math> and <math>\phi_{2}</math> from the procedure above where two phases exist. This produces a phase diagram similar to (13), where the <math>\phi\left(T\right)</math> curve is known as the ''binodal'' or ''demixing curve'' . The phase diagram (13) includes a few more details: one is the critical point <math>\left(T_{c},\phi_{c}\right)</math> or <math>\left(\chi_{c},\phi_{c}\right)</math>, beyond which two solution can no longer exist. Another is the ''spinodal curve'', existing within the demixing curve at <math>f^{\prime\prime}=0</math>, marks the point of transition between metastability and instability (within the spinodal curve, phase spearation occurs spontaneously, while between the spinodal and binodal curves it requires some initial nucleation). The spinodal curve is usually quite close to the binodal curve, and since it can be found analytically provides a useful estimate:<center><math>\begin{array}{lcl} f\left(\phi\right) & = & \chi\phi\left(1-\phi\right)+\frac{\phi}{N}\ln\phi+\left(1-\phi\right)\ln\left(1-\phi\right),\\
& \Downarrow\\
f^{\prime\prime}\left(\phi\right) & = & -2\chi+\frac{1}{N}\frac{1}{\phi}+\frac{1}{1-\phi},\\
& \Downarrow & {\scriptstyle f^{\prime\prime}\left(\phi\right)=0}\\
2\chi_{s} & = & \frac{1}{1-\phi}+\frac{1}{N}\frac{1}{\phi}.\end{array}</math></center> The endpoint of the spinodal curve is also the endpoint of the binodal curve; also, this endpoint is the same for the <math>\chi\left(\phi\right)</math> and <math>T\left(\phi\right)</math> curves. We can find it from<center><math>\begin{array}{lcl} 0 & = & \left.\frac{\partial\chi_{s}}{\partial\phi}\right|_{c}=\frac{1}{2}\left[-\frac{1}{N}\frac{1}{\phi_{c}^{2}}+\frac{1}{\left(1-\phi_{c}\right)^{2}}\right],\\
& \Downarrow\\
\phi_{c} & = & \frac{1}{1+\sqrt{N}}.\end{array}</math></center> Inserting this into the equation for <math>\chi_{s}</math> gives<center><math> \chi_{c}=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)^{2}.</math></center>
There is a great deal to expand on here. Chapter 4 in Rubinstein is a good place to start.
==Surfaces, Interfaces and Membranes==
===Introduction and Motivation=== We will differentiate between several types of surfaces:
*An outer ''surface'' (or boundary) between a liquid phase and a solid boundary or surface. This surface needs not be in thermal equilibrium and exists under external constraints. *An ''interface'' between two phases in equilibrium with each other, like the A/B liquid mixture that was studied earlier. *''Membranes'' have a molecular thickness and are in equilibrium with surrounding water. We will talk now separately about flat interfaces first, and then extend the discussion to curved and fluctuating interfaces.
===Flat Surfaces=== ====Ginzburg-Landau formalism==== The simplest kind of non-homogeneous system one can imagine may be described by the variation in some order parameter or concentration as a function of a single spatial direction, <math>\phi\left(z\right)</math>. For instance, if we have a gas at <math>z\rightarrow+\infty</math> and a liquid at <math>z\rightarrow-\infty</math>, there will be some crossover regime between them. This kind of physics can be treated with a Ginzburg-Landau formalism, which can be derived from the continuum limit of a lattice gas/Ising model.
If every cell <math>i</math> (with size <math>\ell</math>) is parametrized by a discrete spin variable $S_{i}$ such that<center><math>\begin{array}{lcl} S_{i}=1 & \Leftrightarrow & \mbox{cell }i\mbox{ contains molecule }A, \\
S_{i}=0 & \Leftrightarrow & \mbox{cell }i\mbox{ contains molecule }B,\end{array}</math></center> we may write the Hamiltonian as<center><math> \mathcal{H}=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{ij}J_{ij}S_{i}\left(1-S_{j}\right).</math></center> The <math>\left\{ J_{ij}\right\} </math> are the interaction constants between cells. Note that<center><math> J_{ij}S_{i}\left(1-S_{j}\right)+J_{ji}S_{j}\left(1-S_{i}\right)=\begin{cases} 0 & S_{i}=S_{j},
J_{ij} & \left({\scriptstyle S_{i}=1}\wedge{\scriptstyle S_{j}=0}\right)\vee\left({\scriptstyle S_{i}=0}\wedge{\scriptstyle S_{j}=1}\right).\end{cases}</math></center> The partition function is<center><math> Z=\mbox{Tr}_{\left\{ S_{i}\right\} }e^{-\beta\mathcal{H}},</math></center> with <math>F=-k_{B}T\ln Z</math>. We can formulate now a mean-field theory (by neglecting correlations such as: <math>\left\langle S_{i}S_{j}\right\rangle \approx\left\langle S_{i}\right\rangle \left\langle S_{j}\right\rangle </math>) for this model in cases of spatial inhomogeneities (presence of walls and interfaces). The full development is left as an exercise: the result assumes a local thermal equilibrium <math>\phi_{i}=\left\langle S_{i}\right\rangle </math> and gives<center><math>\begin{matrix} F_{0} & = & \left\langle F_{0}\right\rangle
& = & \frac{1}{2}\sum_{ij}J_{ij}\left\langle S_{i}\right\rangle \left(1-\left\langle S_{j}\right\rangle \right)+k_{B}T\sum_{i}\left[\phi_{i}\ln\phi_{i}+\left(1-\phi_{i}\right)\ln\left(1-\phi_{i}\right)\right].\end{matrix}</math></center> Separating this $F_{0}$ into internal energy and entropy,<center><math> U=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{ij}J_{ij}\phi_{i}\left(1-\phi_{j}\right),</math></center> <center><math> -TS=k_{B}T\sum_{i}\left[\phi_{i}\ln\phi_{i}+\left(1-\phi_{i}\right)\ln\left(1-\phi_{i}\right)\right].</math></center> In the continuum limit <math>\phi_{i}\rightarrow\phi\left(z\right)</math> and <math>\sum_{i}\rightarrow\int\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\ell^{3}}</math> and neglecting long-term interactions, we can perform a Taylor expansion:<center><math> \phi_{i}-\phi_{j}=\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{i}\right)-\phi\left(\mathbf{r}_{i}+\boldsymbol{\ell}\right)\simeq-\boldsymbol{\ell}\cdot\left.\triangledown\phi\right|_{\mathbf{r}_{i}},</math></center> <center><math>\begin{matrix} J_{ij}\phi_{i}\left(1-\phi_{j}\right) & = & \frac{1}{2}J_{ij}\left[\left(\phi_{i}-\phi_{j}\right)^{2}-\phi_{i}^{2}-\phi_{j}^{2}+2\phi_{i}\right]
\sum_{i\neq j}J_{ij}\phi_{i}\left(1-\phi_{j}\right) & \rightarrow & \frac{1}{4}\int\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\ell^{3}}zJ\left(-\phi^{2}-\phi^{2}+2\phi\right)+\frac{1}{4}\int\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\ell^{3}}\sum_{ij}J_{ij}\left(\boldsymbol{\ell}_{j}\cdot\triangledown\phi\right)^{2}\end{matrix}</math></center> $z$ is the coordination number.<center><math> U=\frac{1}{2}\int\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\ell^{3}}\left[zJ\phi\left(1-\phi\right)\right]+\frac{1}{4}\int\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\ell^{3}}J\ell^{2}\left(\triangledown\phi\right)^{2}.</math></center> Adding the continuum limit entropy,<center><math>\begin{matrix} F & = & \int\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\left[f_{0}\left(\phi\right)+\frac{1}{2}B\left(\triangledown\phi\right)^{2}\right],
f_{0} & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{\ell^{3}}\left[\chi\phi\left(1-\phi\right)+\phi\ln\phi+\left(1-\phi\right)\ln\left(1-\phi\right)\right],
B & \equiv & \frac{J}{2\ell},
\frac{1}{2}zJ & \equiv & k_{B}T\chi.\end{matrix}</math></center> We can find the profile <math>\phi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)</math> at equilibrium by minimizing the free energy functional <math>F\left[\phi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right]</math> with respect to <math>\phi(\mathbf{r})</math> and taking external constraints into account. Normally, <math>B>0</math> and the minimum of <math>F</math> is homogeneous other than surfaces and interfaces. If <math>\phi\left(-\infty\right)=\phi\left(+\infty\right)=\phi_{A}</math>, the minimal solution <math>\phi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)</math> is a constant and we will have a single homogeneous phase. On the other hand, if<center><math> \begin{cases} \phi\left(-\infty\right)=\phi_{A},
\phi\left(+\infty\right)=\phi_{B},\end{cases}</math></center> and we are in the two-phase region in (<math>\chi,</math><math>\phi)</math> then a 1D profile must exist that solves the Euler-Lagrange equation, and becomes approximately homogeneous far from the center of the interface.
====1D profile at an interface====
Quite independently of the previous treatment and the microscopic model, the free energy can be written as a functional of an order parameter and its gradients:<center><math> F=\int\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\left\{ f_{0}\left(\phi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right)+\frac{B}{2}\left[\triangledown\phi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right]^{2}\right\} .</math></center> Since <math>\left(\triangledown\phi\right)^{2}>0</math>, for <math>B>0</math> the system avoids strong local fluctuations and smooth states have smaller energies. A uniform state is therefore preferred, and if the system is not allowed to become fully uniform then regions of different phases form in equilibrium with each other. This is shown in (16), and can also be described by a tangent construction of the type illustrated in (12). In the two phase example above, due to the symmetry of <math>f</math> in <math>\phi</math> <math>(\phi\longleftrightarrow1-\phi)</math>, the critical point is clearly at <math>\phi_{c}=\frac{1}{2}</math>. We will make a Taylor expansion of <math>\phi</math> around $\phi_{c}$:<center><math> \phi=\phi_{c}+\psi=\frac{1}{2}+\psi.</math></center> Due to the same symmetry in <math>\phi</math>, an expansion of <math>f</math> in <math>\psi</math> should contain only even powers. Performing this expansion gives the result<center><math>\begin{matrix} f_{0} & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{\ell^{3}}\left[2\psi^{2}+\frac{4\psi^{4}}{3}-\ln2+\chi\left(\frac{1}{4}-\psi^{2}\right)\right]+B\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}
& = & \frac{k_{B}T}{\ell^{3}}\left[\left(2-\chi\right)\psi^{2}+\frac{4}{3}\psi^{4}\right]+\mbox{const.}\end{matrix}</math></center> In general the <math>\frac{4}{3}</math> will be replaced by some positive numerical factor <math>\frac{\gamma}{4}</math>. To obtain the correct critical behavior (note that <math>\chi_{c}=\chi\left(T_{c}\right)=2</math>) we assume a linear dependence of the form <math>-\frac{\alpha}{2}\left(T_{c}-T\right)=2-\chi</math>, and minimize<center><math>\begin{matrix} F & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{\ell^{3}}\int\left[-\frac{\alpha}{2}\left(T-T_{c}\right)\psi^{2}+\frac{\gamma}{4}\psi^{4}\right]\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}+\frac{B}{2}\int\left(\triangledown\psi\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The above expansion of the inhomogeneous free energy is called the Ginzburg-Landau (GL) model or expansion. By applying a variational principle on this free energy, we obtain the Euler-Lagrange (EL) equations:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \frac{\delta F}{\delta\psi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)} & = & 0,
& \Downarrow
\frac{\partial F}{\partial\psi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)}-\triangledown\cdot\frac{\partial F}{\partial\left(\triangledown\psi\right)} & = & 0.\end{matrix}</math></center> 06/09/2009 Here <center><math>\begin{matrix} \triangledown\cdot\frac{\partial F}{\partial\left(\triangledown\psi\right)} & = & \sum_{i}\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}\frac{\partial f}{\partial\triangledown_{i}\psi},
\triangledown_{i}\psi & = & \frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}\psi.\end{matrix}</math></center> In particular, <math>\frac{B}{2}\triangledown\cdot\frac{\partial}{\partial\left(\triangledown\psi\right)}\left(\triangledown\psi\right)^{2}=B\triangledown\cdot\triangledown\psi=B\triangledown^{2}\psi</math> and <math>\frac{\delta f_{0}}{\delta\psi}=-\alpha\left(T_{c}-T\right)\psi+\gamma\psi^{3}</math>. The EL equation is therefore<center><math> -\alpha\left(T_{c}-T\right)\psi+\gamma\psi^{3}-B\triangledown^{2}\psi=0.</math></center> This is the well-known Ginzburg-Landau (GL) equation. For <math>T>T_{c}</math> the only homogeneous (bulk) solution (arrived at by neglecting the Laplacian term) is<center><math> -\alpha\left(T_{c}-T\right)\psi+\gamma\psi^{3}=0\Rightarrow\psi=0.</math></center> In the other case when <math>T<T_{c}</math>, the system has two homogeneous solutions<center><math> \psi=\pm\sqrt{\frac{\alpha\left(T_{c}-T\right)}{\gamma}}\equiv\pm\psi_{b}.</math></center> If we do not neglect the derivative but assume a 1D profile with <math>\psi\left(\pm\infty\right)=\pm\psi_{b}</math> and $\psi^{\prime}\left(\pm\infty\right)=0$, we must solve the equation<center><math> B\psi^{\prime\prime}\left(z\right)+\alpha\left(T_{c}-T\right)\psi\left(z\right)-\gamma\psi^{3}\left(z\right)=0.</math></center> The exact solution of the GL model is <center><math> \psi\left(z\right)=\psi_{b}\tanh\left(\frac{z}{\xi}\right),</math></center> <center><math> \xi^{-2}=\frac{\alpha\left(T_{c}-T\right)}{\gamma}.</math></center> We have introduced the correlation length <math>\xi</math>, which is typical of the width of the meniscus (the layer in which the phases are mixed). As a matter of fact, <math>\xi</math> is also the correlation length by the definition <math>\left\langle \psi\left(a\right)\psi\left(r+a\right)\right\rangle \sim\exp(-r/\xi)</math>. The dependence <math>\xi\sim\left(T_{c}-T\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}</math> is the mean field result with an exponent <math>\nu=\frac{1}{2}</math>. In general, <math>\xi\sim\left(T_{c}-T\right)^{-\nu}</math>. We also have for the order parameter dependence <math>\psi\sim\left(T_{c}-T\right)^{\beta}</math> where we have obtained in MFT <math>\beta=\frac{1}{2}</math>.
====Surface energy and surface tension====
''Surface energy'' is the excess of energy in the system with respect to the bulk. ''Surface tension'' <math>\sigma</math> is defined as the surface energy per unit area. Therefore, in our case of two phases separated by a meniscus, $\sigma$ can be calculated using<center><math> \sigma\cdot\mbox{Area}=\Delta F=F\left[\psi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right]-\left[\frac{1}{2}Vf_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)+\frac{1}{2}Vf_{0}\left(-\psi_{b}\right)\right].</math></center> Here, we have subtracted the bulk energy of the separate surfaces from the energy of the full system including the interface. Note that in equilibrium, by definition <math>f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)=f_{0}\left(-\psi_{b}\right)</math>. With the 1D dependence we are treating, then, <math>\psi\left(\mathbf{r}\right)=\psi\left(z\right)</math> and<center><math>\begin{matrix} \sigma & = & \overset{{\scriptstyle =1}}{\overbrace{\frac{1}{\mbox{Area}}\int\mathrm{d}x\int\mathrm{d}y}}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\mathrm{d}z\left[\frac{B}{2}[\psi^{\prime}\left(z\right)]^{2}+f_{0}\left(\psi\left(z\right)\right)-f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)\right]
& = & \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\mathrm{d}z\left[\frac{B}{2}[\psi'\left(z\right)]^{2}+f_{0}\left(\psi\right)-f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)\right].\end{matrix}</math></center> This is not an extensive quantity like <math>F\left[\psi\right]</math>, a single number in the size of the system: it is rather a geometry independent parameter with units of energy per unit area.
The first term above is reminiscent of kinetic energy and the second of potential energy. An analogy to the classical mechanics of a point particle exists, as detailed in the following table. \begin{table}[H] \centering{}\begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline <math>z</math> & <math>t</math> (time)\tabularnewline \hline \hline <math>\psi\left(t\right)</math> & <math>x\left(t\right)</math> (distance)\tabularnewline \hline <math>\frac{B}{2}\left(\psi^{\prime}\left(z\right)\right)^{2}</math> & <math>\frac{1}{m}\dot{x}^{2}</math> (kinetic energy)\tabularnewline \hline <math>f_{0}\left(\psi\right)</math> & <math>-V\left(x\right)</math> (potential energy)\tabularnewline \hline <math>f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)</math> & <math>-E</math> (total energy)\tabularnewline \hline \end{tabular} \end{table} With this analogy in mind, we can derive an expression similar to energy conservation in mechanics. From applying the variational principle to $f_{0}$ we obtain<center><math> \frac{\partial f_{0}}{\partial\psi}=\frac{\partial}{\partial z}\frac{\partial}{\partial\psi^{\prime}}\left[\frac{B}{2}\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right]=B\psi^{\prime\prime}.</math></center> Multiplying this by $\psi^{\prime}$ gives<center><math> \psi^{\prime}\frac{\partial f_{0}}{\partial\psi}=B\psi^{\prime}\psi^{\prime\prime}=\frac{B}{2}\frac{d}{dz}\left[\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right].</math></center> Integrating over $z$ from $-\infty$ to $+\infty$,<center><math>\begin{matrix} \overset{{\scriptstyle =\int_{-\infty}^{z}\frac{df_{0}}{dz}\mathrm{d}z}}{\overbrace{\int_{-\infty}^{z}\frac{df_{0}}{d\psi}\frac{d\psi}{dz}\mathrm{d}z}} & = & \frac{B}{2}\int_{-\infty}^{z}\frac{d}{dz}\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}z=\left.\frac{B}{2}\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right|_{-\infty}^{z}
& \Downarrow
f_{0}\left(\psi\right)-f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right) & = & \frac{B}{2}\left\{ \left[\psi^{\prime}\left(z\right)\right]^{2}-\overset{=0}{\overbrace{\left(\psi^{\prime}\left(-\infty\right)\right)^{2}}}\right\}
& \Downarrow\end{matrix}</math></center> <center><math> f_{0}\left(\psi\right)-f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)=\frac{1}{2}B\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}.</math></center> The last term disappears due to to the boundary condition at <math>z\rightarrow-\infty</math>, where <math>\psi\rightarrow\psi_{b}=\mathrm{const.}</math> and therefore <math>\psi^{\prime}=0</math>. The analogy between this equation and the law of conservation of mechanical energy can be stressed by writing it as<center><math> \overset{{\scriptstyle kin.\, En.}}{\overbrace{\frac{1}{2}B\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}}}\overset{{\scriptstyle Pot.\, En.}}{\overbrace{-f_{0}\left(\psi\right)}}=\overset{{\scriptstyle Tot.\, En.}}{\overbrace{-f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)}}.</math></center> Returning to the surface tension, we can use this conservation law to rewrite it in the simpler form <center><math>\begin{matrix} \sigma & = & \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left[\frac{B}{2}\left(\psi^{\prime}\left(z\right)\right)^{2}+\overset{{\scriptstyle =\frac{B}{2}\left(\psi^{\prime}\right)^{2}}}{\overbrace{f_{0}\left(\psi\right)-f_{0}\left(\psi_{b}\right)}}\right]\mathrm{d}z=B\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\psi^{\prime}\left(z\right)\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}z.\end{matrix}</math></center> An estimate may be obtained from<center><math> \sigma\simeq B\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\psi^{\prime}\left(z\right)\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}z\simeq B\left(\frac{\psi_{b}}{\xi}\right)^{2}\xi,</math></center> or<center><math> \sigma\simeq B\psi_{b}^{2}\xi^{-1}.</math></center> The exact expression for <math>\sigma</math> may be obtained from the exact GL form that we have derived for <math>\psi</math>. In any case, the temperature dependence of $\sigma$ is of the form <center><math> \sigma\approx B\overset{{\scriptstyle \xi^{-1}}}{\overbrace{\sqrt{\frac{T_{c}-T}{2B}}}}\overset{{\scriptstyle \psi_{b}^{2}}}{\overbrace{\frac{\alpha\left(T_{c}-T\right)}{\gamma}}}\sim\left(T_{c}-T\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}.</math></center> If we insert the general exponential dependencies of <math>\xi</math> and <math>\psi_{b}</math> into the equation, we will see that the exponent for surface energy as function of <math>(T_{c}-T)</math> is <math>2\beta+\nu</math>. This discussion can be extended to systems which do not have symmetry between <math>\phi</math> and <math>1-\phi</math>, such as a liquid/gas system with two densities <math>n_{\ell}</math> and <math>n_{g}</math>. Without proof, we will state that within the GL formalism it can be shown that<center><math> f_{0}\left(n\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left[f_{0}\left(n_{g}\right)+f_{0}\left(n_{\ell}\right)\right]=c\left(n-n_{g}\right)^{2}\left(n-n_{\ell}\right)^{2}.</math></center> The surface energy will be<center><math> \Delta F=\int\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\left[\frac{1}{2}B\left(\triangledown n\right)^{2}+f_{0}\left(n\right)-\frac{1}{2}f_{0}\left(n_{g}\right)-\frac{1}{2}f_{0}\left(n_{\ell}\right)\right].</math></center> For a profile in the $z$ direction,<center><math> \sigma=\frac{\Delta F}{\mbox{Area}}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\mathrm{d}z\left[\frac{B}{2}\left(n^{\prime}\right)^{2}+c[n\left(z\right)-n_{g}]^{2}[n\left(z\right)-n_{\ell}]^{2}\right].</math></center> After variation, one obtains for the two coexisting phases with $n_{\ell}>n>n_{g}$<center><math>\begin{matrix} \ln\frac{n_{\ell}-n}{n-n_{g}} & = & -\frac{z}{\xi},
\xi & = & \left(n_{\ell}-n_{g}\right)\sqrt{\frac{2c}{B}},\end{matrix}</math></center> with <math>n_{\ell}-n_{g}\sim\left(T_{c}-T\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}</math> and <math>\xi\sim\left(T_{c}-T\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}</math>. The density profile interpolates smoothly between the two phases:<center><math> n\left(z\right)=\frac{n_{\ell}}{1+e^{-\frac{z}{\xi}}}+\frac{n_{g}}{1+e^{+\frac{z}{\xi}}}.</math></center>
A few generalizations:
*Surfactants or surface active materials: this includes soap, detergent, biological membranes composed of biological amphiphiles called phospholipids and more. What they have in common is that they are formed of molecules with charged or polarized {}"heads" connected to long hydrocarbon {}"tails". These molecules are called ''amphiphyllic'' , since the tails are ''hydrophobic'' and the heads ''hydrophillic'' . This causes them to accumulate on interfaces between water and air, and reduce surface tension (by a factor $\sim2-3$):<center><math> \sigma\left(\mbox{with soap}\right)=\sigma_{\mathrm{air/water}}-\Delta\sigma(\phi_{s}),</math></center> where <math>\phi_{s}</math>is the surface concentration of the soap molecules. *Emulsions: drops of oil in water (or water in oil), stabilized by some sort of emulsifier (which is also a surfactant). Some common examples are milk and mayonnaise. {{Sidenote|There is a French biochemist by the name of Herve This who specializes in molecular gastronomy, who has some very interesting popular lectures which are worth looking up. He authored several books (one is called "molecular gastronomy"), and appeared on several TV shows. In his presentations he explains how food preparations depends crucially on physical chemical processes on the molecular level. This includes preparation of mousse, whipped cream, sauces, thickeners and emulsifiers.}} *Detergency of soap: while soap reduces surface tension between oil and water, it does not create a phase where oil and water are mixed on a molecular level. Rather, micrometric oil droplets are formed in the aqueous solution. The process of cleaning is the process where oily dirt is solubilized in the aqueous solution and is washed away from the object we clean. 06/11/2009
===Curved Surfaces=== ====Review of differential geometry==== \begin{description}
[{Books:}] The book by Safran has a short introduction which will be followed here. The one by Visconti is more thorough and oriented towards other physics problems such as relativity . There also exists a multi-authored book on the subject edited by David Nelson, and a mathematical book on the theory of manifolds by Spivak. \end{description} In order to discuss surfaces and curves which exhibit local curvature, we will need to introduce a few mathematical concepts. A brief introduction follows. \paragraph{Curves} A ''parametric curve'' <math>\mathbf{R}\left(u\right)</math> is a set of vectors along some contour in space, expressed as a function of the parameter <math>u</math>, which may vary, for example, from <math>0</math> to the length <math>L</math> of the curve. The differential length element <math>\mathrm{d}s</math> along the curve can be expressed by<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathrm{d}s & = & \left|\mathbf{R}\left(u+\mathrm{d}u\right)-\mathbf{R}\left(u\right)\right|\simeq\left|\frac{\partial\mathbf{R}}{\partial u}\right|\mathrm{d}u,
& \Downarrow
\mathrm{d}s & = & \left|\frac{\partial\mathbf{R}}{\partial u}\right|\mathrm{d}u,
\frac{\mathrm{d}s}{\mathrm{d}u} & = & \left|\frac{\partial\mathbf{R}}{\partial u}\right|.\end{matrix}</math></center> A tangent vector $\hat{\mathbf{t}}$ can be found from<center><math> \hat{\mathbf{t}}=\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{R}}{\mathrm{d}s}=\frac{\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{R}}{\mathrm{d}u}}{\frac{\mathrm{d}s}{\mathrm{d}u}}.</math></center> Note that from the magnitude of this expression, <math>\hat{\mathbf{t}}</math> is always a unit vector. It is tangent to the curve because it is proportional to <math>\Delta\mathbf{s}=\mathbf{R}\left(u+\mathrm{d}u\right)-\mathbf{R}\left(u\right)</math>.
With these definitions, we can define ''curvature'' as one extra derivative:<center><math> \frac{\mathrm{d}\hat{\mathbf{t}}}{\mathrm{d}s}=\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathbf{R}}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}}\equiv\kappa\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{c}.</math></center> The unit vector <math>\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{c}</math> is a unique vector perpendicular to <math>\hat{\mathbf{t}}</math> (this is easy to show by taking <math>\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}s}\hat{\mathbf{t}}^{2}=2\hat{\mathbf{t}}\cdot\frac{\mathrm{d}\hat{\mathbf{t}}}{\mathrm{d}s}=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{ds}}\left(1\right)=0</math>), and we can also write<center><math> \mathcal{\kappa}=\left|\frac{\mathrm{d}\hat{\mathbf{t}}}{\mathrm{d}s}\right|.</math></center> It is also useful to define the local ''radius of curvature'' <math>R=\kappa^{-1}</math>. Some intuition can be gained from an analogy with the kinetics of point particles moving without a friction on a curve in space, if <math>u</math> is replaced by the time <math>t</math>. The tangent and curvature vectors can then be related to the velocity and acceleration, respectively.
\paragraph{Surfaces}
Similarly to curves, ''a parametric surface <math>\mathbf{r'' =\mathbf{R}\left(u,v\right)</math>} in space can be defined as a function of two parameters. There are three scalar functions contained in this explicit definition:<center><math> \begin{cases} x=f\left(u,v\right),
y=g\left(u,v\right),
z=h\left(u,v\right).\end{cases}</math></center> Note that it is also possible to represent surfaces implicitly as<center><math> F\left(x,y,z\right)=0,</math></center> where other than its zeros <math>F</math> is arbitrary.
Any explicit definition requires some particular choice of <math>u</math> and $v$. For instance, one choice (called the Monge representation) is<center><math> \begin{cases} x=f\left(u,v\right)=u,
y=g\left(u,v\right)=v,
z=h\left(u,v\right)=h\left(x,y\right).\end{cases}</math></center> In vector notation,<center><math> \mathbf{r}=\left(x,y,h\left(x,y\right)\right).</math></center> This works only if there is a single <math>z</math> value for each choice of <math>x</math> and <math>y</math>, and is very convenient for surfaces which are almost flat. Another common choice useful for nearly spherical surfaces is the spherical representation, where <math>u=\vartheta</math> and <math>v=\varphi</math>. In spherical coordinates, this is<center><math> \mathbf{r}=\left(r,\vartheta,\varphi\right)=\left(R\left(\vartheta,\varphi\right),\vartheta,\varphi\right).</math></center>
We can define two tangent vectors <math>\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{u}</math> and <math>\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{v}</math> at every point on the surface, such that <math>\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{u}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{v}=0</math>. The unit vector normal to the surface is <math>\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\frac{\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{u}\times\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{v}}{\left|\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{u}\times\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{v}\right|}</math>. It is easy to find the unit vector from the implicit representation, and one can usually find an implicit representation: for instance, starting from Monge <math>F=z-h\left(x,y\right)=0</math>. On the surface, <math>F=0</math> implies<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathrm{d}F & = & F\left(\mathbf{r}\right)+F\left(\mathbf{r}+\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\right)
& = & -\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\triangledown F=0\end{matrix}</math></center> The vector <math>\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}</math> can be any vector tangent to the surface, and therefore <math>\triangledown F</math> must be proportional to the normal vector:<center><math> \hat{\mathbf{n}}=\frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}.</math></center>
\paragraph{Metric of a curved surface}
A surface has been defined as an ensemble of points <math>\left\{ \mathbf{r}\left(u,v\right)\right\} </math> embedded in 3-dimensional space. In order to measure length along such a surface, we must integrate along a differential length element within it:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathrm{d}\mathbf{r} & = & \frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial u}\mathrm{d}u+\frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial v}\mathrm{d}v\equiv\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v,
\mathrm{d}s & = & \left|\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\right|,
\mathrm{d}s^{2} & = & \mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}=\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v\right)\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v\right)
& = & \overset{E}{\overbrace{\mathbf{r}_{u}^{2}}}\left(\mathrm{d}u\right)^{2}+2\overset{F}{\overbrace{\mathbf{r}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}}}\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v+\overset{G}{\overbrace{\mathbf{r}_{v}^{2}}}\left(\mathrm{d}v\right)^{2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The metric is defined as <center><math> g\equiv EG-F^{2}.</math></center> It is positive definite since<center><math> g=EG-F^{2}=\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}\right)\left(\mathbf{r}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)-\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)^{2}=\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)^{2}>0.</math></center> The surface element can be expressed in terms of the metric:<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\left|\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}_{v}\right|=\left|\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathbf{r}_{v}\right|\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v=\sqrt{g}\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v.</math></center> We illustrate this in the Monge representation as an example. Here,<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathbf{r}_{u} & = & \mathbf{r}_{x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\left(x,y,h\left(x,y\right)\right)
& = & \left(1,0,h_{x}\right),
\mathbf{r}_{v} & = & \mathbf{r}_{y}=\left(0,1,h_{y}\right).\end{matrix}</math></center> The surface element is<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\sqrt{g}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y,</math></center> with the metric<center><math>\begin{matrix} g & = & \left(\mathbf{r}_{u}\times\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)^{2}=\left|\begin{matrix}{ccc} \mathbf{\hat{x}} & \mathbf{\hat{y}} & \mathbf{\hat{z}}
1 & 0 & h_{x}
0 & 1 & h_{y}\end{matrix}\right|,\\ \sqrt{g} & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The length element is<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathrm{d}s^{2} & = & r_{x}^{2}\mathrm{d}x^{2}+2\mathbf{r}_{x}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{y}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y+r_{y}^{2}\mathrm{d}y^{2},
\mathrm{d}s & = & \sqrt{\left(1+h_{x}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x^{2}+\left(1+h_{y}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}y^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> and therefore we have in the Monge representation<center><math> \mathrm{d}s=\sqrt{\left(1+h_{x}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x^{2}+\left(1+h_{y}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}y^{2}},</math></center> <center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y.</math></center> In the implicit representation, one can begin the same process by writing the surface element in terms of the volume element:<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\delta^{\left(3\right)}\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_{s}\left(x,y,z\right)\right)\mathrm{d}^{3}r,</math></center> using the 3D Dirac delta function <math>\delta^{\left(3\right)}\left(\mathbf{r}\right)</math>. A general property of the Dirac delta is that <center><math> \delta\left(f\left(x\right)-a\right)=\frac{\delta\left(x-f^{-1}\left(a\right)\right)}{\left.\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\right|_{x=f^{-1}\left(a\right)}},</math></center> where <math>f^{-1}</math> is the inverse function such that <math>f\left(x\right)=a\Rightarrow f^{-1}\left(a\right)=x</math>. In terms of the function <math>F</math> such that the surface is defined by $F=0$, we can use this property to write<center><math> \delta^{\left(3\right)}\left(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}_{s}\left(F\right)\right)=\delta\left(F\right)\left|\triangledown F\right|,</math></center> or<center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\delta\left(F\right)\left|\triangledown F\right|\mathrm{d}^{3}r.</math></center> Returning to the implicit version of the Monge representation,<center><math>\begin{matrix} \triangledown F & = & \left(-h_{x},-h_{y},1\right),
\left|\triangledown F\right| & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}},\end{matrix}</math></center> <center><math> \mathrm{d}A=\delta\left(z-h\left(x,y\right)\right)\mathrm{d}z\sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y.</math></center>
\paragraph{Curvature of surfaces}
So far we have discussed first order differential expressions and the area element. This has to do with properties like surface energy <math>\mathrm{d}f=\sigma\mathrm{d}A</math>. Curvature is a second order property, useful in discussing deformations and fluctuations. Consider a curve <math>\mathbf{r}\left(s\right)</math> with <math>0<s<L</math> on a surface parametrized by <math>u</math> and <math>v</math>. On the curve, <math>u=u\left(s\right)</math> and <math>v=v\left(s\right)</math>. If <math>\hat{\mathbf{n}}</math> is a vector normal to the surface, the local curvature (of the curve) is<center><math> \kappa=\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathbf{r}\left(s\right)}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}}\cdot\hat{n}=\mathbf{r}^{\prime\prime}\left(s\right)\cdot\hat{\mathbf{n}}.</math></center> The first derivative is<center><math> \frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s}=\frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial u}\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{d}s}+\frac{\partial\mathbf{r}}{\partial v}\frac{\mathrm{d}v}{\mathrm{d}s}=\mathbf{r}_{u}u^{\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{v}v^{\prime},</math></center> and the second derivative<center><math>\begin{matrix} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}} & = & \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}s}\left(\mathbf{r}_{u}u^{\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{v}v^{\prime}\right)
& = & \mathbf{r}_{uu}\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\mathbf{r}_{vv}\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{2}+2\mathbf{r}_{uv}u^{\prime}v^{\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{u}u^{\prime\prime}+\mathbf{r}_{v}v^{\prime\prime}.\end{matrix}</math></center> Since <math>\hat{\mathbf{n}}</math> is perpendicular to <math>\mathbf{r}_{u}</math> and $\mathbf{r}_{v}$, we are left with<center><math> \kappa=L\left(u^{\prime}\right)^{2}+N\left(v^{\prime}\right)^{2}+2Mu^{\prime}v^{\prime},</math></center> <center><math>\begin{matrix} L & = & \hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uu},
N & = & \hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{vv},
M & = & \hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uv}.\end{matrix}</math></center>
\begin{minipage}[t]{1\columnwidth} \begin{shaded} (some missing formulas...)\end{shaded} \end{minipage}<center><math>\begin{matrix} L & = & -\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u},
N & = & -\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v},
M & = & -\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}=-\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}.\end{matrix}</math></center> We finally obtain<center><math> \kappa=\frac{\left(\mathbf{\hat{n}}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}\right)\mathrm{d}u^{2}+\left(\mathbf{\hat{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{u}+\mathbf{\hat{n}}_{u}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v+\left(\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{v}\right)\mathrm{d}v^{2}}{\left(\mathrm{d}s\right)^{2}},</math></center> and with <math>\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{r}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\mathbf{r}_{v}\mathrm{d}v</math> and $\mathrm{d}\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{u}\mathrm{d}u+\hat{\mathbf{n}}_{v}\mathrm{d}v$,<center><math> \kappa=-\frac{\mathrm{d\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}=-\frac{\mathrm{d\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}}.</math></center> (missing diagram...)
\paragraph{Curvature tensor}
Since $\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathbf{\hat{n}}=0$,<center><math> \hat{\mathbf{n}}+\mathrm{d}\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\left(\mathbf{r}+\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\right)=\mathbf{\hat{n}\left(\mathbf{r}\right)}+\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\triangledown\mathbf{\hat{n}},</math></center> or <center><math> \mathrm{d}\mathbf{\hat{n}}=\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\triangledown\hat{\mathbf{n}}\equiv\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}.</math></center> The quantity <center><math>\begin{matrix} \overleftrightarrow{Q} & = & \triangledown\hat{\mathbf{n}},
Q_{ij} & = & \left(\triangledown\hat{\mathbf{n}}\right)_{ij}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}\left(\mathbf{\hat{n}}\right)_{j},\end{matrix}</math></center> is a second rank tensor or dyadic.
Now, we can write <math>\kappa</math> with \begin{minipage}[t]{1\columnwidth} \begin{shaded} (some missing formulas...)\end{shaded} \end{minipage}<center><math> \kappa=-\frac{\mathrm{d\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}=-\frac{\mathrm{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}=-\frac{\mathrm{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}\cdot}\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s^{2}},</math></center> or<center><math> \kappa=\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\left(s\right)\cdot\overleftrightarrow{Q}\cdot\mathbf{r}^{\prime}\left(s\right)=\sum_{ij}r_{i}^{\prime}Q_{ij}r_{j}^{\prime}</math></center> where <math>\mathbf{r}'(s)={\normalcolor \frac{\mathrm{d}\mathbf{r}}{\mathrm{d}s}}</math>.
This can be used for the case of an implicitly defined surface where $\hat{\mathbf{n}}=\frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}$:<center><math>\begin{matrix} Q_{ij} & = & \left[\triangledown\left(\frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}\right)\right]_{ij}
& = & \partial_{i}\left(\frac{\partial_{j}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}\right)=\frac{\partial_{i}\partial_{j}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}-\left(\partial_{j}F\right)\cdot\frac{\partial_{i}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}.\end{matrix}</math></center> Using $\partial_{i}\left|\triangledown F\right|=\partial_{i}\sqrt{\left(\partial_{x}F\right)^{2}+\left(\partial_{y}F\right)^{2}+\left(\partial_{z}F\right)^{2}}$,<center><math> Q_{ij}=-\frac{1}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}\left[\frac{\partial_{i}\left|\triangledown F\right|\partial_{j}F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|}-\partial_{i}\partial_{j}F\right].</math></center>

\paragraph{The curvature tensor and its invariants}
The dyadic matrix <math>Q=\overleftrightarrow{Q}</math> has eigenvalues <math>\lambda_{i}</math>, a trace <math>\mathrm{Tr}Q=\sum_{i}\lambda_{i}</math> and a determinant <math>\mathrm{Det}Q=\left|Q\right|=\prod_{i}\lambda_{i}</math> which are invariant under similarity transformations <math>\tilde{Q}=UQU^{-1}</math>. The sum of the principal minors <math>\sum_{i}M_{ii}</math> is also invariant: to see this, consider the characteristic polynomial<center><math>\begin{matrix} P\left(\lambda\right) & = & \mathrm{Det}\left(Q-\lambda I\right)
& = & \mathrm{Det}\left(U^{-1}U\right)\mathrm{Det}\left(Q-\lambda I\right)
& & \mathrm{Det}\left(U^{-1}\right)\mathrm{Det}\left(Q-\lambda I\right)\mathrm{Det}\left(U\right)
& = & \mathrm{Det}\left(U^{-1}QU-\lambda U^{-1}IU\right)
& = & \mathrm{Det}\left(\tilde{Q}-\lambda I\right).\end{matrix}</math></center> Here <math>I</math> is the unit matrix. Expanding <math>P\left(\lambda\right)</math> in powers of $\lambda$,<center><math> P\left(\lambda\right)=\left|Q\right|-\lambda\sum_{i}M_{ii}+\lambda^{2}\sum_{i}Q_{ii}-\lambda^{3}.</math></center> We can identify clearly the coefficients of the polynomial <math>P(\lambda)</math>as the 3 invariants. One eigenvalue is always equal to zero (as an exercise do it in the implicit representation). If we choose <math>\lambda_{3}=0</math>, we are reduced to two nontrivial invariants: <math>\mathrm{Tr}Q=\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}</math> and <math>\sum_{i}M_{ii}=\lambda_{1}\lambda_{2}</math>(as <math>{\normalcolor \mathrm{Det}}(Q)=0)</math>. These invariants are called the ''mean curvature'' <math>H</math> and the ''Gaussian curvature'' $K$:<center><math> H\equiv\frac{1}{2}\left(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}\right),</math></center> <center><math> K\equiv\lambda_{1}\lambda_{2}.</math></center>
For example, in the implicit representation we can write<center><math>\begin{matrix} \mathbf{\hat{n}} & = & \frac{\triangledown F}{\left|\triangledown F\right|},
N & \equiv & \left|\triangledown F\right|,
\mathrm{Tr}Q & = & -\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\left[\frac{N_{i}F_{i}}{N}-F_{ii}\right],\end{matrix}</math></center> where <center><math> \begin{cases} N_{i}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}N,
F_{ij}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{i}}\frac{\partial}{\partial r_{j}}F.\end{cases}</math></center> Note that since, for instance, <center><math> N_{i}=\partial_{i}\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}+F_{z}^{2}}=\frac{\partial_{i}\left(F_{j}F_{j}\right)}{2\sqrt{F_{x}^{2}+F_{y}^{2}+F_{z}^{2}}}=\frac{1}{N}F_{j}F_{ij},</math></center> with a few more steps we can show (another exercise) that<center><math> H=-\frac{1}{2N^{3}}\left[2F_{x}F_{y}F_{xy}-F_{xx}\left(F_{y}^{2}+F_{z}^{2}\right)+\mathrm{2\, cyclic\, permuations}\right],</math></center> <center><math> K=-\frac{1}{2N^{3}}\left[F_{xx}F_{yy}F_{z}^{2}-F_{xy}^{2}F_{z}^{2}+2F_{xz}F_{x}\left(F_{y}F_{yz}-F_{z}F_{yy}\right)+\mathrm{2\, cyclic\, permuations}\right],</math></center>
where by cyclic permutations we mean permuting the axes: <math>x\rightarrow y\rightarrow z\rightarrow x</math>. In the case of the Monge representation where <math>F=z-h\left(x,y\right)</math>, <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> have a simpler form: <center><math>\begin{matrix} N & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}},
h_{i} & = & \partial_{i}h,
F_{x} & = & -h_{x},
F_{y} & = & -h_{y},
F_{z} & = & 1.\end{matrix}</math></center> One can then show that<center><math> H=\frac{1}{2\left(\sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\right)^{3}}\left[\left(1+h_{y}^{2}\right)h_{xx}+\left(1+h_{x}^{2}\right)h_{yy}-2h_{x}h_{y}h_{z}\right],</math></center> <center><math> K=\frac{h_{xx}h_{yy}-h_{xy}^{2}}{\left(1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}\right)^{2}}.</math></center> ====Small disturbances of planar surfaces==== To treat nearly flat surfaces, one can use the Monge representation to expand a Taylor series around a completely flat surface in derivatives of $h\left(x,y\right)$:<center><math>\begin{matrix} N & = & \sqrt{1+h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}}\simeq1+\frac{1}{2}\left(h_{x}^{2}+h_{y}^{2}\right),\end{matrix}</math></center> or equivalently<center><math> N=\left|\triangledown F\right|\simeq1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\triangledown_{||}h\right)^{2}.</math></center> From similar arguments, one can show that<center><math>\begin{matrix} H & \simeq & \frac{1}{2}\left(h_{xx}+h_{yy}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\triangledown_{\parallel}^{2}h,
K & \simeq & h_{xx}h_{yy}-\left(h_{xy}\right)^{2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> In the general parametric representation,<center><math> \kappa=\frac{L\left(du\right)^{2}+2Mdudv+N\left(dv\right)^{2}}{E\left(du\right)^{2}+2Fdudv+G\left(dv\right)^{2}}</math></center> with <math>L=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uu}</math><math>M=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{uv}</math>and <math>N=\hat{\mathbf{n}}\cdot\mathbf{r}_{vv}</math>. Picking a unit vector <math>\hat{\mathbf{a}}=l\mathbf{r}_{u}+m\mathbf{r}_{v}</math> in the plane, the curvature in the direction of <math>\hat{\mathbf{a}}</math> is given by<center><math> \kappa=Ll^{2}+2Mlm+Nm^{2}.</math></center> The parameters $l$ and $m$ must obey<center><math> a=\hat{|\mathbf{a}}|=1\Rightarrow\hat{\mathbf{a}}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{a}}=El^{2}+2Fml+Gm^{2}=1.</math></center> In investigating <math>\kappa\left(l,m\right)</math> as a function of the direction of <math>\hat{\mathbf{a}}</math>, we can find its extrema with the constraint $a=1$ by adding a Lagrange multiplier:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \tilde{\kappa} & = & \kappa\left(l,m\right)-\lambda(El_{2}+2Flm+Nm^{2}),
& \Downarrow
\frac{\partial\tilde{\kappa}}{\partial l}=\frac{\partial\tilde{\kappa}}{\partial m} & = & 0.\end{matrix}</math></center> The solution takes the form of a quadratic equation<center><math> \kappa^{2}\left(EG-F^{2}\right)-\kappa\left(EN+GL-2FM\right)+\left(LN-M^{2}\right)=0,</math></center> which has 2 roots: <math>\kappa_{a}</math> and <math>\kappa_{b}.</math> This extremum finding process defines the ''principal directions'' , which (we will state without proof) are always perpendicular to each other. The two invariants are then<center><math>\begin{matrix} H & = & \frac{1}{2}\left(\kappa_{a}+\kappa_{b}\right)=-\frac{EN+GL-2FM}{2\left(EG-F^{2}\right)},
K & = & \kappa_{a}\kappa_{b}=\frac{LN-M^{2}}{EG-F^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center>
Consider a few cases in terms of the radii of curvature <math>r_{a}=\frac{1}{\kappa_{a}}</math> and <math>r_{b}=\frac{1}{\kappa_{b}}</math>:
#If at some point both radii are positive, then <math>\kappa_{a}</math>, <math>\kappa_{b}</math>, <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> are all positive. The surface is convex around the point, as in (17a). #If both are negative, then <math>H<0</math> and <math>K>0</math>. The surface is concave around the point, as in (17b). #If the two have opposing signs, <math>K</math> is negative and one is at a saddle point of the surface, as in (17c). #The special surface having <math>H=(\kappa_{a}+\kappa_{b})/2=0</math> at ''any'' point is called a ''minimal surface'' (or ''Schwartz surface,'' after the 19th century mathematician who studied them in detail). These surfaces have a saddle at every point, as one curvature is always positive and the second negative: <math>\kappa_{a}=-\kappa_{b}</math>. Hence, their Gaussian curvature is always negative: <math>K<0.</math> We will use the principal directions to describe a local paraboloid expansion of a nearly flat surface. In general,<center><math> z=z_{0}+\frac{1}{2}L\left(u-u_{0}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}N\left(v-v_{0}\right)^{2}.</math></center> In the Monge representation,<center><math> z=z_{0}+\frac{1}{2}\kappa_{a}\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\kappa_{b}\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}.</math></center> ====Free energy of soft surfaces==== \begin{description}
[{Book:}] Landau & Lifshitz' book on ''Elasticity '' has a chapter on elasticity of hard (solid) shells. There is also a book by Boal on ''elasticity and mechanics of fluid membranes'' . Safran's book shows how the parameters we describe can be derived from a microscopic model where the lipid (surfactant) molecules are modeled as beads connected with various springs. \end{description} Consider a liquid surface or fluid membrane: as such a surface curves, its free energy varies. Phenomenologically,<center><math> \Delta F=\sigma\int\mathrm{d}A+2k\int\left(H-C_{0}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}A+\bar{k}\int K\mathrm{d}A.</math></center> All the integrals are taken over the surface. The fact that the above expression models a fluid membrane is related to the fact that we do not account for any lateral shear forces. Molecules composing the fluid membrane are free to flow inside the membrane but they resist elastic deformations such as bending. The first term describes the contribution of surface tension, which is proportional to the total surface area. The geometric values <math>H</math> and <math>K</math> are the mean and Gaussian curvatures we have already encountered. The coefficients <math>k</math> and <math>\bar{k}</math> (with units of energy) depend, like <math>\sigma</math>, on the material properties in question. The spontaneous curvature <math>C_{0}</math> is also a material property: it defines a certain preferred angle (perhaps due to the shape of surfactant molecules), and its sign depends on the preferred direction of curvature. See (18) for an illustration. Unless there is an active process that causes an asymmetry in the lipid composition of the two leaflets, the bilayer will have the same lipid composition on the inside and outside, and therefore has in total <math>C_{0}=0</math>. Usually for fluid membranes, <math>k</math> and <math>\bar{k}</math> range from <math>\sim1k_{B}T</math> to <math>\sim40k_{B}T</math>.
One example is a sphere of radius $R$, where:<center><math>\begin{matrix} H & = & \frac{1}{2}\left(R_{1}^{-1}+R_{2}^{-1}\right)=R^{-1},
K & = & R^{-2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> This gives<center><math>\begin{matrix} \left.\Delta F\right|_{\mathrm{sphere}} & = & \sigma\int\mathrm{d}A+2k\int\left(H-C_{0}\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}A+\bar{k}\int K\mathrm{d}A
& = & 4\pi R^{2}\sigma+2k\left(\frac{1}{R}-C_{0}\right)^{2}\cdot4\pi R^{2}+4\pi\bar{k}
& = & 4\pi R^{2}\sigma+8\pi k\left(1-C_{0}R\right)^{2}+4\pi\bar{k}.\end{matrix}</math></center> The interesting fact that the surface integral over the Gaussian curvature <math>K</math> gives a constant value of <math>4\pi</math> - independent on the radius <math>R</math> of the sphere - has a deep meaning. It is related to the famous Gauss-Bonnet theorem which will be stated here without further details: according to this theorem, the integral over the Gaussian curvature is a topological invariant of the surface whose value is equal to <math>4\pi\left(1-g\right)</math>, where <math>g</math> is the ''genus'' of the surface. A sphere or any closed object with no {}"holes" has <math>g=0</math> and an integrated Gaussian curvature of <math>4\pi</math>, while a torus (or {}"donut") with one hole has <math>g=1</math> and hence a zero integrated Gaussian curvature. {{Sidenote|More information about the Gauss-Bonnet theorem may be found in books on differential geometry}}
A second example is an infinite cylinder with radius <math>R</math>. Here, <math>\kappa_{a}=\frac{1}{R}</math> and $\kappa_{b}=0$. The free energy per unit length is<center><math>\begin{matrix} \frac{\Delta F}{L} & = & 2\pi R\sigma+2k\left(\frac{1}{2R}-C_{0}\right)\cdot2\pi R+\bar{k}\overset{{\scriptstyle =0}}{\overbrace{\int\frac{1}{R}\cdot0\cdot\mathrm{d}A}}
& = & 2\pi R\sigma+\frac{4\pi k}{R}\left(\frac{1}{2}-C_{0}R\right)^{2}.\end{matrix}</math></center> An even simpler example is the infinite plane, where <math>\kappa_{a}=\kappa_{b}=0\Rightarrow K=H=0</math>. This yields<center><math> \frac{\Delta F}{\mathrm{Area}}=\sigma+2kC_{0}^{2}.</math></center>

====Thermal fluctuations of a plane==== \begin{description}
[{Book:}] Safran's book. \end{description} To second order in derivatives of <math>h</math> in the Monge representation for $\bar{k}=0$,<center><math> \Delta F=\frac{\sigma}{2}\int\left(\triangledown h\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y+\frac{2k}{4}\left(\triangledown^{2}h\right)^{2}\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y.</math></center> The minimum of energy is obtained for a flat surface. Going to a Fourier transformed form, we have<center><math>\begin{matrix} h_{\mathbf{q}} & = & \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\right)^{2}\int\mathrm{d}^{2}r\, h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)e^{-i\mathbf{q}\cdot\mathbf{r}},
h\left(\mathbf{r}\right) & = & \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\right)^{2}\int\mathrm{d}^{2}q\, h_{\mathbf{q}}e^{i\mathbf{q}\cdot\mathbf{r}},
\left(\triangledown^{2}h\right)^{2} & \rightarrow & q^{4}h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}},
\left(\triangledown h\right)^{2} & \rightarrow & q^{2}h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> This gives for the free energy in terms of the normal surface modes $\left\{ h_{q}\right\} $:<center><math> \Delta F=\frac{\sigma}{2}\int\left(q_{x}^{2}+q_{y}^{2}\right)h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\mathrm{d}^{2}q+\frac{k}{2}\int\left(q_{x}^{2}+q_{y}^{2}\right)^{2}h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\mathrm{d}^{2}q.</math></center> With <math>h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)</math> real, we know that <math>h_{\mathbf{q}}=h_{-\mathbf{q}}^{*}</math>, or <math>h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}=\left|h_{\mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}</math>. From the classical equipartition theorem we can estimate the equilibrium energy for the average of this quantity:<center><math>\begin{matrix} \frac{k_{B}T}{2} & = & \frac{1}{2}\sigma q^{2}\left\langle h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\right\rangle +\frac{1}{2}kq^{4}\left\langle h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{-\mathbf{q}}\right\rangle
& \Downarrow
\left\langle \left|h_{\mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}\right\rangle & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{\sigma q^{2}+kq^{4}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> It is now useful to define the new length scale <math>\xi\equiv\sqrt{\frac{k}{\sigma}}</math>, and examine the limits of <math>k\xi\gg1</math> and <math>k\xi\ll1</math>. In the <math>k\xi\ll1</math> limit, one obtains a surface dominated by surface tension. Consider the real space thermal correlation function<center><math>\begin{matrix} \left\langle h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)h\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right\rangle & = & \frac{1}{\left(2\pi\right)^{2}}\int\int e^{-i\mathbf{q}\cdot\mathbf{r}}e^{-i\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\cdot\mathbf{r}}\overset{{\scriptstyle =2\pi\delta\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}}{\overbrace{\left\langle h_{\mathbf{q}}h_{\mathbf{q^{\prime}}}\right\rangle }}\mathrm{d}^{2}q\mathrm{d}^{2}q^{\prime}
& = & \frac{1}{2\pi}\int\mathrm{d}^{2}q\,\frac{k_{B}T}{\sigma q^{2}}.\end{matrix}</math></center> Since this integral diverges at both large and small <math>q</math>, to obtain a physically meaningful result we must introduce cutoffs to the range of <math>\mathit{q}</math>: <math>q_{\mathrm{min}}=\frac{2\pi}{L}</math> where <math>L</math> is the linear dimension of the system, and <math>q_{\mathrm{max}}=\frac{2\pi}{a}</math> where <math>a\sim3\AA</math> is the typical molecular size. This gives an example of a famous result from the 1930's, known as Landau-Peierls instability for 2-dimensional systems and the lack of an ordered phase at $T>0$:<center><math> \left\langle h^{2}\left(\mathbf{r}\right)\right\rangle =\frac{k_{B}T}{2\pi\sigma}\ln\frac{L}{a}.</math></center> Since the logarithmic divergence is very weak, it turns out that the thermal fluctuations are two or three Angstroms in size for a water surface of macroscopic (a few millimeters or centimeters) dimension. These thermal fluctuations are not easy to measure because the signal should come only from the water molecules at the water surface. In the 1980s they were measured for the first time for water surfaces at room temperature using a powerful synchrotron X-ray source. The technique employs scattering at very low angles (called grazing incidence) from the water surface and obtains the intensity of the scattered X-ray as function of <math>q.</math> This quantity is proportional to <math>\langle|h_{q}|^{2}\rangle</math>. In the opposite limit where <math>k\xi\gg1</math>, the membrane is dominated by its elastic energy, and $\sigma\ll kq^{2}$ can be neglected: <center><math> \left\langle \left|h_{\mathbf{q}}\right|^{2}\right\rangle =\frac{k_{B}T}{\sigma q^{2}+kq^{4}}\simeq\frac{k_{B}T}{kq^{4}}\sim q^{-4}.</math></center> The divergence at small <math>q</math> is much larger here than in the first case, and<center><math>\begin{matrix} \left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{2\pi k}\int_{q_{\mathrm{min}}}^{q_{\mathrm{max}}}\frac{1}{q^{3}}\mathrm{d}q
& = & \frac{k_{B}T}{4\pi k}\left[-\overset{\approx0}{\overbrace{\left(\frac{1}{q_{\mathrm{max}}}\right)^{2}}}+\left(\frac{1}{q_{\mathrm{min}}}\right)^{2}\right],\end{matrix}</math></center> and <center><math>\begin{matrix} \left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle & = & \frac{k_{B}T}{2\left(2\pi\right)^{2}}\frac{L^{2}}{k}
& \Downarrow
\sqrt{\left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle } & \sim & L.\end{matrix}</math></center> In such membranes, which are dominated by elasticity, the fluctuations increase linearly with membrane size. For a membrane around <math>1\mathrm{cm}</math> in length, a typical amplitude is in the <math>\mu\mathrm{m}</math> range. Another interesting observation is that <math>\left\langle h^{2}\right\rangle \sim T/k</math>. For small <math>k</math> (flexible membranes), as well as for higher temperatures, the fluctuations become larger. This is valid as long as the condition of the elastic-dominated case, <math>\sigma\ll kq^{2}</math>, remains satisfied. Also, recall that the source of the large membrane fluctuations comes from the small <math>q</math> or large wavelengths, and not from small wiggles associated with the motion of individual molecules. ====Rayleigh instability==== Due to surface tension, a cylinder of liquid created in air (or surrounded by another immiscible liquid) is unstable and will break into spherical droplets. Let's consider the following model: a cylinder of length <math>L</math> and smaller radius <math>R_{0}\ll L</math>, which contains inside it an ''incompressible'' liquid with a total volume of <math>V=\pi LR_{0}^{2}</math>. For simplicity, we will consider perturbations which preserve the body-of-revolution symmetry around the main axis and the cylinder length <math>L</math>, such that only the local radius <math>\rho\left(z\right)</math> along the cylinder's axis may vary. Expanding <math>\rho</math> in normal modes then gives<center><math> \rho\left(z\right)=R+\sum_{q\neq0}\rho_{q}e^{iqz}.</math></center> The mode amplitudes are <math>\rho_{q}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L}}\int\rho\left(z\right)e^{-iqz}\mathrm{d}z</math>. Note that <center><math> \left\langle \rho\left(z\right)\right\rangle =\frac{1}{L}\int_{0}^{L}\rho\left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z=R,</math></center> with <math>R</math> depending on <math>R_{0}</math>. This dependence can be found from the constant volume constraint<center><math>\begin{array}{lcl} V & = & \pi R_{0}^{2}L=\int_{0}^{L}\pi\rho^{2}\left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z \\
& = & \pi R^{2}L+\frac{\pi}{L}\sum_{q}\sum_{q^{\prime}}\overset{{\scriptstyle =L\delta_{qq^{\prime}}}}{\overbrace{\left(\int e^{i(q+q^{\prime})z}\mathrm{d}z\right)}}\rho_{q}\rho_{-q} \\
& \Downarrow & \\
R^{2}L & = & R_{0}^{2}L-\sum_{q\ne0}\rho_{q}\rho_{-q}.\end{array}</math></center> This is exact, but for small perturbations we can expand the root and obtain<center><math> R\simeq R_{0}\left(1-\frac{1}{2L}\sum_{q\ne0}\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}\right).</math></center> The surface energy of the distorted cylinder will be<center><math> F_{s}=\sigma\cdot\mathrm{Area}=\sigma\cdot\int_{0}^{L}2\pi\rho\left(z\right)\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial z}\right)^{2}}\mathrm{d}z.</math></center> (We have used expression for the surface area of a body-of-revolution with axial symmetry). Expanding all quantities up to second order in <math>\rho_{q}</math> gives<center><math> \begin{array}{lcl} F_{s} & \simeq & \overset{{\scriptstyle =0}}{\overbrace{2\pi\sigma\int_{0}^{L}\left(\rho\left(z\right)-R\right)\mathrm{d}z}}+2\pi\sigma\int_{0}^{L}\mathrm{d}zR\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial r}\right)^{2}\right) \\ & = & 2\pi\sigma L\left(R_{0}-\frac{R_{0}}{2L}\sum_{q}\frac{\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{R_{0}^{2}}\right)+\frac{\pi\sigma R_{0}}{L}\int_{0}^{L}\sum_{q}\sum_{q^{\prime}}\left(-q\cdot q^{\prime}\right)e^{i\left(q+q^{\prime}\right)z}\mathrm{d}z \\
& = & 2\pi\sigma LR_{0}-2\pi\sigma R_{0}\sum_{q}\frac{\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{2R_{0}^{2}}+2\pi\sigma R_{0}\sum_{q}\frac{q^{2}\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{2R_{0}^{2}}. \end{array}</math></center> Finally,<center><math> \Delta F=F_{s}-F_{s}^{0}=2\pi\sigma R_{0}\sum_{q}\frac{\left|\rho_{q}\right|^{2}}{2R_{0}^{2}}\left(q^{2}R_{0}^{2}-1\right).</math></center> The conclusion is that modes having <math>q^{2}R_{0}^{2}\le1</math> will reduce the original cylinder free energy <math>F_{s}^{0}.</math> Hence, this is the onset of an instability called the Rayleigh instability of a liquid cylinder. A liquid cylinder will spontaneously start to develop undulations of wavelength <math>\lambda\sim q^{-1}\ge R_{0}</math>. These undulations will grow and eventually break up the cylinder into spherical droplets of size <math>R_{0}</math>. Note that if we go back to the planar surface by taking the limit <math>R_{0}\rightarrow\infty</math>, no such instability will occur since the planar geometry has the lowest surface area with respect to any other fluctuating surface.

===Polymer Dynamics=== \noindent \begin{center} {\huge Physical Models in Biological } \par\end{center}{\huge \par} \noindent \begin{center} {\huge Systems and Soft Matter}
