{\huge of Polymer Dynamics} \par\end{center}{\huge \par} ~ \noindent \begin{center} {\large Submitted by : Shlomi Reuveni} \par\end{center}{\large \par} ~ ~ ~ ~\newpage{} \tableofcontents{} \newpage{}
====What is this document all about? ==== This paper is submitted as a final project in the course {\small {}"Physical Models in Biological Systems and Soft Matter". }Writing this document I aimed at achieving two goals. The first was getting to know a little better a subject that I found interesting and was not covered during the course. As an interesting by product I have also profoundly improved my knowledge on diffusion, a subject I was already superficially acquainted with. The second goal was to provide an accessible exposition to the subject of polymer dynamics aimed mainly for advanced undergraduate students who are curious about the subject and would like an easy start. This is also the reason this document is titled: {}"A Guided Tour to the Essence of Polymer Dynamics" and for the fact it is written in the form of questions and answers.
The saying goes: {}"There are two ways by which one can really master a subject: research and teaching". I felt that the effort I have put into making this document readable for advanced undergraduate students taught me more than I would have learned by passive reading. I have tried hard to make this document as self contained and self explanatory as possible and therefore hope that it will be of some help to you the curious student. So, if you wonder {}"What do you mean by polymer dynamics?" and {}"How can this subject be of any interest to me?" please read on. \newpage{} \section{O.K, sum it up in a few lines so I can decide if I want to go on reading!} =====What's a polymer?===== A polymer is a large molecule (macro-molecule) composed of repeating structural units (monomers) typically connected by covalent chemical bonds. Due to the extraordinary range of properties accessible in polymeric materials, they have come to play an essential and ubiquitous role in everyday life - from plastics and elastomers on the one hand to natural biopolymers such as DNA and proteins that are essential for life on the other. \begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.5]{Single_Polymer_Chains_AFM} \par\end{centering} \caption{Appearance of real linear polymer chains as recorded using an atomic force microscope on surface under liquid medium. Chain contour length for this polymer is <math>\sim204nm</math>; thickness is <math>\sim0.4nm</math>. Taken from: Y. Roiter and S. Minko, AFM Single Molecule Experiments at the Solid-Liquid Interface: In Situ Conformation of Adsorbed Flexible Polyelectrolyte Chains, Journal of the American Chemical Society, vol. 127, iss. 45, pp. 15688-15689 (2005) }
\end{figure}
=====What's polymer dynamics?=====
As every other molecule a polymer is also affected by the thermal motion of surrounding molecules. It is this thermal agitation that causes a flexible polymer to move about in the solution while constantly changing its shape. This motion is referred to as polymer dynamics.
\begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.5]{Motion} \par\end{centering}
\caption{Photographs of DNA polymers in aqueous solution taken by fluorescence microscopy. There is a 1 second interval between successive frames. The motion is clearly visible. Taken from: Introduction to Polymer Physics, M. Doi Translated by H. See, Clarendon Press, 30 November 1995.}
\end{figure}
=====What can I find in the rest of this document?=====
If you ever wondered how can one understand the motion of a polymer and what are the physical properties emanating from the dynamics of these materials you should read on. We will start with the building blocks, the dynamics of a single particle in solution. We will then gradually build on, presenting two models for polymer dynamics. Experimental observations will also be discussed as we confront our models with reality.
\newpage{}
\section{I knew there must be some preliminaries, can you keep it short and to the point? }
\subsection{Why do you bore me with this? why can't I skip directly to section 4?}
If you are familiar with concepts such as Diffusion, Einstein relation and Brownian motion you would find this section easier to read. If you are also familiar with the mathematics behind these concepts, Smoluchowski and Langevin equations, you can skip directly to section 4. In order to understand polymer dynamics we have to start from something more basic. A polymer can be thought of as long chain of particles (the monomers), the particles are connected to one another and hence interact. It would be wise to first try and understand the dynamics of a single particle and only then take into account these interactions. The dynamics of a single particle lies in the heart of the section.
\subsection{Can't say I know much about any of the stuff you mentioned above but first thing is first, what is diffusion?}
Molecular diffusion, often called simply diffusion, is a net transport of molecules from a region of higher concentration to one of lower concentration by random molecular motion. The result of diffusion is a gradual mixing of material. In a phase with uniform temperature, absent external net forces acting on the particles, the diffusion process will eventually result in complete mixing or a state of equilibrium. Basically, it is the movement of molecules from an area of high concentration to a lower area. \begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.55]{Diffusion_(1)}
~
\includegraphics[scale=0.14]{cell_diffusion_ink_India} \par\end{centering}
\centering{}\caption{Top: Schematic representation of mixing of two substances by diffusion. Bottom: Ink diffusing in water.}
\end{figure}
=====How can we mathematically treat diffusion?=====
As mentioned above diffusion is basically the movement of molecules from an area of high concentration to an area of lower concentration. For simplicity we will consider one-dimensional diffusion. Let <math>c(x,t)</math> be the concentration at position <math>x</math> and time <math>t</math>. A Phenomenological description of diffusion is given by Fick's law: <center><math> j(x,t)=-D\frac{\partial c(x,t)}{\partial x}</math></center> In words: if the concentration is not uniform, there will be a flux of matter which is proportional to the gradient in concentration. The proportionality constant is called the diffusion constant and it is denoted by <math>D</math> its units are <math>\frac{length^{2}}{time}</math>. The minus sign is there to take care of the fact that the flow is from the higher concentration region to the lower concentration region. ====Where is this flux coming from? ==== Its microscopic origin is the random thermal motion of the particles. The average velocity of each particle is zero, and there is an equal probability for each particle to have a velocity directioned right or left. However, if the concentration is not uniform the number of particles which happen to flow from the higher concentration region to the lower concentration region is higher than the number of particles flowing in the other direction simply because there are more particles there. \begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.5]{\string"23-07-2009 22-19-57\string".eps} \par\end{centering} \centering{}\caption{Microscopic explanation for Fick's law. Suppose that the particle concentration <math>c(x)</math> is not uniform. If the particles move randomly as shown by the arrows, there is a net flux of particles flowing from the higher concentration region to the lower concentration region. Here the diffusion constant of the particle, which determines the average length of the arrows, is assumed to be constant. }
\end{figure}
======How do we go on?======
We now write an equation for the conservation of matter, the change in the number of particles located at the interval <math>[x,x+\triangle x]</math> from time <math>t</math> to time <math>t+\triangle t</math> is given by the number of particles coming/going from the left minus the number of particles coming/going from the right: {\tiny <center><math> N(t+\triangle t)-N(t)\simeq\left[c(x+\frac{\triangle x}{2},t+\triangle t)-c(x+\frac{\triangle x}{2},t)\right]\triangle x\simeq\left[j(x,t+\frac{\triangle t}{2})-j(x+\triangle x,t+\frac{\triangle t}{2})\right]\triangle t</math></center> }or: <center><math> \frac{\left[c(x+\frac{\triangle x}{2},t+\triangle t)-c(x+\frac{\triangle x}{2},t)\right]}{\triangle t}=\frac{\left[j(x,t+\frac{\triangle t}{2})-j(x+\triangle x,t+\frac{\triangle t}{2})\right]}{\triangle x}</math></center> taking the limits <math>\triangle t,\triangle x\longrightarrow0</math> and assuming continuity and differentiability of the concentration and the flux we obtain: <center><math> \frac{\partial c(x,t)}{\partial t}=-\frac{\partial j(x,t)}{\partial x}</math></center> Substituting the expression for the flux gives the well known diffusion equation:<center><math> \frac{\partial c(x,t)}{\partial t}=D\frac{\partial^{2}c(x,t)}{\partial x^{2}}</math></center> \subsubsection{What happens if the particles are under the influence of some kind of a potential <math>U(x)</math>?}
If this happens Fick's law must be modified since the potential <math>U(x)</math> exerts a force: <center><math> F=-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}</math></center> on the particle and gives an non zero average velocity <math>v</math>. If the force is weak there is a linear relation between force and velocity given by: <center><math> v=\frac{F}{\zeta}=-\frac{1}{\zeta}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}</math></center> the constant <math>\zeta</math> is called the friction constant and its inverse <math>1/\zeta</math> is called the mobility.
\subsubsection{How come the velocity doesn't grow indefinitely? there is a constant force!}
Correct, but it is not the only force acting on the particle. There are also friction and random forces exerted by other particles and hence like a feather falling under its own weight the particle reaches a finite average velocity.
======O.K, and what do we do now?======
We will obtain the Smoluchowski equation that takes the potential into account, but first we will obtain an important relation between the diffusion constant the temperature and the friction constant. The average velocity of the particle gives an additional flux <math>cv</math> so that the total flux is: <center><math> j(x,t)=-D\frac{\partial c(x,t)}{\partial x}-\frac{c}{\zeta}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}</math></center> An important relation is obtained from this equation. As you may recall from statistical mechanics, in equilibrium the concentration is given by the Boltzmann distribution:<center><math> c_{eq}(x,t)\propto exp(-U(x)/k_{B}T)</math></center> for which the flux must vanish and hence:<center><math> -D\frac{\partial c_{eq}(x,t)}{\partial x}-\frac{c_{eq}}{\zeta}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}=0</math></center> Substituting for $c_{eq}(x,t)$ we get:<center><math> \frac{Dc_{eq}}{k_{B}T}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}-\frac{c_{eq}}{\zeta}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}=c_{eq}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}\left[\frac{D}{k_{B}T}-\frac{1}{\zeta}\right]=0</math></center> Since this is true for every $x$ it follows that: <center><math> D=\frac{k_{B}T}{\zeta}</math></center> this relation is called the Einstein relation. The Einstein relation states that the diffusion constant which characterizes the thermal motion is related to the friction constant which specifies the response to external force. The Einstein relation is a special case of a general theorem called the fluctuation dissipation theorem, which states the spontaneous thermal fluctuations are related to the characteristics of the system response to an external field. ====And the Smoluchowski equation is obtained by plugging in the {===="new" flux into the continuity equation right?} Exactly right! using the Einstein relation we rewrite the flux as: <center><math> j(x,t)=-\frac{1}{\zeta}\left[k_{B}T\frac{\partial c(x,t)}{\partial x}+c\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}\right]</math></center> Substituting this into the continuity equation we get the Smoluchowski equation:<center><math> \frac{\partial c(x,t)}{\partial t}=-\frac{\partial j(x,t)}{\partial x}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\frac{1}{\zeta}\left[k_{B}T\frac{\partial c(x,t)}{\partial x}+c\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}\right]</math></center> which serves as a phenomenological description of diffusion under the influence of an external potential. Although we have derived the above equation for the concentration <math>c(x,t)</math> the same equation will also hold for the probability distribution function <math>\Psi(x,t)</math> that a particular particle is found at position <math>x</math> at time <math>t</math>. This is true since the distinction between <math>c(x,t)</math> and <math>\Psi(x,t)</math> is, for non-interacting particles, only the fact that <math>\Psi(x,t)</math> is normalized. The evolution equation for the probability <math>\Psi(x,t)</math> is hence written as: <center><math> \frac{\partial\Psi(x,t)}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}\frac{1}{\zeta}\left[k_{B}T\frac{\partial\Psi(x,t)}{\partial x}+\Psi(x,t)\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}\right]</math></center> which will also be termed the Smoluchowski equation.
===What's Brownian motion?=== Brownian motion (named after the Scottish botanist Robert Brown) is the seemingly random movement of particles suspended in a fluid (i.e. a liquid or gas) or the mathematical model used to describe such random movements. Brownian motion is traditionally regarded as discovered by the botanist Robert Brown in 1827. It is believed that Brown was studying pollen particles floating in water under the microscope. He then observed small particles within the vacuoles of the pollen grains executing a jittery motion. By repeating the experiment with particles of dust, he was able to rule out that the motion was due to pollen particles being 'alive', although the origin of the motion was yet to be explained. \begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.5]{PerrinPlot2} \par\end{centering} \caption{Three tracings of the motion of colloidal particles of radius 0.53\textmu{}m, as seen under the microscope, are displayed. Successive positions every 30 seconds are joined by straight line segments (the mesh size is 3.2\textmu{}m).Reproduced from the book of Jean Baptiste Perrin, Les Atomes,Perrin, 1914, p. 115.} \end{figure} =====And the mathematical treatment?===== \subsubsection{Before we start I have to say that it seems awfully similar to diffusion, what's new?} You are right! these are opposite sides of the same coin. However, the approach we take here is microscopic rather than macroscopic. Instead of starting from a macroscopic quantity, the concentration, we will start from the equation of motion for a single particle in solution, Newton's second law: <center><math> m\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}=-\zeta\frac{dx}{dt}-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}+g'(t)</math></center> Here the first term on the right hand side is the friction force which is assumed to take a standard form of being opposite in direction and proportional to the velocity. The second term is the force exerted as a consequence of the external potential and the third term is a random force that represents the sum of the forces due to collisions with surrounding particles. Let us now rewrite this equation in the form: <center><math> \frac{m}{\zeta}\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}+\frac{dx}{dt}=-\frac{1}{\zeta}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}+\frac{g'(t)}{\zeta}\equiv-\frac{1}{\zeta}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}+g(t)</math></center> where we have defined <math>g(t)\equiv\frac{g'(t)}{\zeta}</math>. Our next step is an approximation, treating very small and light weight particles we will drop the inertial term <math>\frac{m}{\zeta}\frac{d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}</math> assuming it is negligible and obtain: <center><math> \frac{dx}{dt}=-\frac{1}{\zeta}\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}+g(t)</math></center> we will refer to this equation as the Langevin equation. This equation describes the motion of a single Brownian particle, solving it one can (in principle) obtain a trajectory of such a particle. ======I don't understand why you throw away the inertial term, please explain!====== This can be further explained by the following example. Consider a particle immersed in some solvent moving under the influence of a constant external force <math>F=-\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}</math>. Let us denote the velocity: <center><math> v=\frac{dx}{dt'}</math></center> the equation of motion for $v$ is given by:<center><math> \frac{m}{\zeta}\frac{dv}{dt'}+v=\frac{F}{\zeta}+g(t')</math></center> For simplicity let us factor out the random force by taking an ensemble average (to avoid the subtleties of taking the time average) of both sides of the equation and obtaining an equation for the average velocity:<center><math> \frac{d<v>}{dt'}+\frac{\zeta}{m}<v>=\frac{F}{m}</math></center> Multiplying both sides by <math>e^{\frac{t'\zeta}{m}}</math> and integrating from zero to $t$ we are able to solve for $<v>$: <center><math> <v>=e^{\frac{-t\zeta}{m}}\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{F}{m}e^{\frac{t'\zeta}{m}}dt'=\frac{F}{\zeta}\left[1-e^{\frac{-t\zeta}{m}}\right]</math></center> Where we have assumed that the particle was at rest at time zero. We see that the velocity approaches an asymptotic value of <math>\frac{F}{\zeta}</math> exponentially fast and that the characteristic relaxation time is <math>\tau=\frac{m}{\zeta}</math>. Dropping the inertial term in the first place we would have simply gotten: <center><math> <v>=\frac{F}{\zeta}</math></center> i.e an immediate response to the force. It is now clear that if the relaxation time <math>\tau=\frac{m}{\zeta}</math> is small, dropping the inertial term is a good approximation! In the case of small particles (atoms,molecules,colloidal particles, etc...) immersed in a liquid, the relaxation time <math>\tau</math> is indeed very small supporting the validity of our approximation. \subsubsection{If these are opposite sides of the same coin how does the Langevin equation relate to the Smoluchowski equation?} As mentioned earlier, since we don't know the exact time dependence of <math>g(t)</math> we will treat it as a random force. The freedom in choosing the distribution of <math>g(t)</math> is very large, here however we will limit ourselves to a model which will be equivalent to the Smoluchowski equation. \subsubsection{The Langevin equation gives us trajectories, the Smoluchowski equation gives us a probability distribution for the position, how can they be equivalent?} Excellent question! Examining many trajectories one can generate the probability distribution for the position. For example starting the particles from a given origin and following its trajectory up to some time <math>t</math> one can record the position <math>x(t).</math> Repeating the processes many many times will yield many many different <math>x(t).</math> Creating a histogram one can generate an empirical probability distribution for the position at time <math>t</math>. One can show () that if the probability distribution of <math>g(t)</math> is assumed to be Gaussian and is characterized by: <center><math> \begin{cases} <g(t)>=0
<g(t)g(t')>=\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}\delta(t-t')\end{cases}</math></center> then the distribution of <math>x(t)</math> determined by the Langevin equation satisfies the Smoluchowski equation. In other words, if <math>g(t)</math> is a Gaussian random variable with zero mean and variance <math>\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}</math> and if <math>g(t)</math> and <math>g(t')</math> are independent for <math>t\neq t'</math> then the above statement holds. \subsubsection{I still don't understand, can you demonstrate on a simple special case?} Yes! Consider the Brownian motion of a free particle (no external potential) for which the Langevin equation reads:<center><math> \frac{dx}{dt}=g(t)</math></center> If the particle is at <math>x_{0}</math> at time <math>t=0</math>, its position at time $t$ is given by:<center><math> x(t)=x_{0}+\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}g(t')dt'</math></center> From the above we deduce that <math>x(t)-x_{0}</math> is a linear combination independent Gaussian random variables. We now recall that the sum independent Gaussian random variables is a Gaussian random variable itself and hence the probability distribution of <math>x(t)</math> may be written as: <center><math> \Psi(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi B}}exp\left[-\frac{\left(x-A\right)^{2}}{2B}\right]</math></center> where: <center><math> \begin{cases} A=<x(t)>
B=<(x(t)-A)^{2}>\end{cases}</math></center> The mean is calculated from: <center><math> A=<x(t)>=x_{0}+\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}<g(t')>dt'=x_{0}+\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}0\cdot dt'=x_{0}</math></center> For the variance we have: <center><math> B=<\left(\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}g(t')dt'\right)\left(\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}g(t")dt"\right)>=\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}<g(t')g(t")>dt'dt"</math></center> hence: <center><math> B=\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}\delta(t-t')dt'dt"=\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}t=2Dt</math></center> and thus:<center><math> \Psi(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4\pi Dt}}exp\left[-\frac{\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}}{4Dt}\right]</math></center> which is exactly (check by direct differentiation) the solution for the Smoluchowski equation: <center><math> \frac{\partial\Psi(x,t)}{\partial t}=D\frac{\partial^{2}\Psi(x,t)}{\partial x^{2}}</math></center> In other words, both equations result in the same probability distribution for <math>x(t)</math>. An important conclusion is that the mean square displacement of a Brownian particle from the origin is given by <math>2Dt</math> and is hence linear in time.
=====O.K, I think we covered everything! anything else?=====
We are almost done but in order to complete our analysis we need to analyze one more problem, the Brownian motion of a harmonic oscillator.
\subsubsection{Why do we have to do this? how come we always have to talk about the harmonic oscillator?}
The harmonic oscillator is a simple system that serves as a prototype for problems we will solve later one. Treating it here will ease things for us later.
======I understand, please go on.======
Consider a Brownian particle moving under the following potential: <center><math> U(x)=\frac{1}{2}kx^{2}</math></center> The equation of motion for this particle is given by: <center><math> \frac{dx(t')}{dt'}=-\frac{k}{\zeta}x(t')+g(t')</math></center> In order to get a formal solution for <math>x(t)</math> we multiply both sides by $e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}$and do some algebra:<center><math> \frac{dx(t')}{dt'}e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}+\frac{k}{\zeta}x(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}=\frac{d}{dt'}\left[x(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}\right]=g(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}</math></center> We now integrate from $-\infty$ to $t$ and get: <center><math> \left[x(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}\right]_{t'=-\infty}^{t'=t}=\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}g(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}dt'</math></center> Assuming the following boundary condition: <center><math> x(t'=-\infty)\cdot e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}\cdot\infty}=0</math></center> We conclude that:<center><math> x(t)=\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}g(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(t'-t\right)}dt'</math></center> It is also possible to solve under the initial condition <math>x(t=0)=x_{0}</math>, in that case:<center><math> \left[x(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}\right]_{t'=0}^{t'=t}=\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}g(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t'}dt'</math></center> and we have <center><math> x(t)=x_{0}e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}t}+\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}g(t')e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(t'-t\right)}dt'</math></center>
\subsubsection{O.K, but <math>g(t)</math> is a random variable and hence <math>x(t)</math> is also one that doesn't tell me much... Can we calculate some moments? Start with the case of the particle that has been with us since <math>t=-\infty</math>.}
First we note that for the mean position we have: <center><math> A(t)=<x(t)>=\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}<g(t')>e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(t'-t\right)}dt'=0</math></center> and the mean position is hence zero. We now aim at finding an expression for the mean square displacement from the origin <math><(x(t)-x(0))^{2}></math>, the variance of <math>x(t)</math> will be calculated as a by product. We start with the time correlation function of $x(t)$:<center><math> <x(t)x(0)>=\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}dt_{1}\overset{0}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}dt_{2}e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(t_{1}+t_{2}-t\right)}<g(t_{1})g(t_{2})></math></center> Recalling that: <center><math> <g(t)g(t')>=2D\delta(t-t')=\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}\delta(t-t')</math></center> we get:<center><math> <x(t)x(0)>=\overset{0}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}dt_{1}e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(2t_{1}-t\right)}\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}=\left[e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(2t_{1}-t\right)}\frac{k_{B}T}{k}\right]_{t_{1}=-\infty}^{t_{1}=0}=\frac{k_{B}T}{k}e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}t}</math></center> Here we assumed that <math>t>0</math> and used the fact that <math><g(t_{1}>0)g(t_{2})>\equiv0</math> since $t_{2}<0$. Similarly if $t<0$ we get:<center><math> <x(t)x(0)>=\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}dt_{1}e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(2t_{1}-t\right)}\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}=\left[e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(2t_{1}-t\right)}\frac{k_{B}T}{k}\right]_{t_{1}=-\infty}^{t_{1}=t}=\frac{k_{B}T}{k}e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}t}</math></center> We may hence conclude that: <center><math> <x(t)x(0)>=\frac{k_{B}T}{k}e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}\left|t\right|}</math></center> Letting $t=0$ we get <center><math> <x(0)x(0)>=<x^{2}>=\frac{k_{B}T}{k}</math></center> which coincides with the known result obtained from statistical mechanics with the use of the Boltzmann distribution <math>\psi_{eq}\propto exp(-kx^{2}/2k_{B}T)</math>. We will now show that this is also the variance: <center><math> B=<(x(t)-A(t))^{2}>=<x(t)x(t)>=\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}<g(t')g(t")>e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(t'+t"-2t\right)}dt'dt"</math></center> and hence: <center><math> B=\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(2t'-2t\right)}dt'=\frac{k_{B}T}{k}</math></center> The mean square displacement <math><(x(t)-x(0))^{2}></math> can now be easily calculated:{\scriptsize <center><math> <(x(t)-x(0))^{2}>=<x(t)^{2}>+<x(0)^{2}>-2<x(t)x(0)>=2\left[<x(t)^{2}>-<x(t)x(0)>\right]</math></center> }and hence:<center><math> <(x(t)-x(0))^{2}>=\frac{2k_{B}T}{k}\left[1-e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}\left|t\right|}\right]</math></center> Here, unlike the case of free diffusion, for long times the mean square displacement is bounded by <math>\frac{2k_{B}T}{k}</math>. The bound is approached exponentially fast with a characteristic relaxation time <math>\tau=\frac{\zeta}{k}</math>. Considering the opposite limit <math>\left|t\right|\rightarrow0</math> (very short times) we have (to first order):<center><math> <(x(t)-x(0))^{2}>=\frac{2k_{B}T}{k}\left[1-1+\frac{k}{\zeta}\left|t\right|\right]=2D\left|t\right|</math></center> Indeed in this limit the particle has yet to {}"feel" the harmonic potential and we expect regular diffusion.
\subsubsection{I think that since <math>x(t)</math> is a linear sum of Gaussian random variables and hence Gaussian itself, we can also write an expression for the it probability distribution. Am I right?} Yes you are! We already found the mean and variance and hence the probability distribution for $x(t)$ is:<center><math> \Psi(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi B}}exp\left[-\frac{\left(x-A\right)^{2}}{2B}\right]=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{2\pi k_{B}T}{k}}}exp\left[-\frac{kx^{2}}{2k_{B}T}\right]</math></center> which is exactly the Boltzmann distribution. We could have guessed that this will be so since we have given the particle an infinite amount of time to equilibrate with the potential well. ====Let's proceed to the case of the particle that started at <math>x_{0====</math>! }
First we note that for the mean position we have: <center><math> A(t)=<x(t)>=x_{0}e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}t}+\overset{t}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}<g(t')>e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(t'-t\right)}dt'=x_{0}e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}t}</math></center> the mean position depends on time and exponentially decays towards zero. For the variance we have: <center><math> B=<(x(t)-A(t))^{2}>=\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}<g(t')g(t")>e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(t'+t"-2t\right)}dt'dt"</math></center> and hence: <center><math> B=\overset{t}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}e^{\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(2t'-2t\right)}dt'=\frac{k_{B}T}{k}\left[1-e^{-\frac{2k}{\zeta}t}\right]</math></center> Here again the variance exponentially decays towards the equilibrium variance. The probability distribution is Gaussian again and we have: {\footnotesize <center><math> \Psi(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi B}}exp\left[-\frac{\left(x-A\right)^{2}}{2B}\right]=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{2\pi k_{B}T}{k}\left[1-e^{-\frac{2k}{\zeta}t}\right]}}exp\left[-\frac{k(x-x_{0}e^{-\frac{k}{\zeta}t})^{2}}{2k_{B}T\left[1-e^{-\frac{2k}{\zeta}t}\right]}\right]</math></center> }which for short times <math>t\ll\tau=\frac{\zeta}{k}</math> is the same as free diffusion:<center><math> \Psi(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4\pi Dt}}exp\left[-\frac{(x-x_{0})^{2}}{4Dt}\right]</math></center> and for long times gives the Boltzmann distribution: <center><math> \Psi(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{2\pi k_{B}T}{k}}}exp\left[-\frac{kx^{2}}{2k_{B}T}\right]</math></center> \newpage{} ====The Bead-Spring (Rouse) Model for Polymer Dynamics==== =====Give me the simplest model for polymer dynamics!===== A polymer is a chain of monomers linked to one another by covalent bonds. It is natural to represent a polymer by a set of beads connected to one another by springs. The dynamics of the polymer is modeled by the Brownian motion of these beads. Such a model was first proposed by Rouse in the fifties of the the twentieth century and has been the basis of the dynamics of polymers in dilute solutions. \begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.5]{\string"26-07-2009 16-17-49\string".eps} \par\end{centering} \caption{A pictorial description of the Rouse model.} \end{figure} ======But now the the beads are connected! how do we take that into account?====== Let <math>\{\vec{R}_{1},..,\vec{R}_{N}\}</math> be the positions of the beads, if we assume the beads experience a drag force proportional to their velocity as they move through the solvent, then for each bead we can write the following Langevin equation:<center><math> \frac{d\vec{R}_{n}(t)}{dt}=-\frac{1}{\zeta_{n}}\frac{\partial U}{\partial\vec{R}_{n}}+\vec{g}_{n}(t)</math></center> Here <math>\zeta_{n}</math> is the friction coefficient of the <math>n-th</math> bead and from now on we will assume that the beads are all alike and hence <math>\zeta=\zeta_{n}</math> for every <math>n</math>. The random force <math>\vec{g}_{n}(t)</math> is Gaussian with the following characteristics: <center><math> \begin{cases} <g_{\alpha n}(t)>=0 & \forall n,\forall\alpha=x,y,z
<g_{\alpha n}(t)g_{\beta m}(t')>=\frac{2k_{B}T}{\zeta}\delta_{nm}\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta(t-t') & \forall n,m\,,\forall\alpha,\beta=x,y,z\end{cases}</math></center> i.e the random forces acting on different beads and/or in perpendicular directions and/or in different times are independent.
======And the potential <math>U</math>? Harmonic as always?====== Indeed, having harmonic springs connecting the beads, we will take it as:<center><math> U=\frac{k}{2}\overset{N}{\underset{n=2}{\sum}}\left(\vec{R}_{n}(t)-\vec{R}_{n-1}(t)\right)^{2}</math></center> In this model the Langevin equation becomes a linear equation for $\vec{R}_{n}(t)$, for the internal beads we have:<center><math> \begin{cases} \frac{d\vec{R}_{n}(t)}{dt}=\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(\vec{R}_{n+1}(t)+\vec{R}_{n-1}(t)-2\vec{R}_{n}(t)\right)+\vec{g}_{n}(t) & \,\,\, n=2,...,N-1\end{cases}</math></center> and for the beads at each end we have:<center><math> \begin{cases} \frac{d\vec{R}_{n}(t)}{dt}=\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(\vec{R}_{2}(t)-\vec{R}_{1}(t)\right)+\vec{g}_{1}(t) & \,\,\, n=1
\frac{d\vec{R}_{n}(t)}{dt}=\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(\vec{R}_{N-1}(t)-\vec{R}_{N}(t)\right)+\vec{g}_{N}(t) & \,\,\, n=N\end{cases}</math></center> In order to unify the treatment we define two additional hypothetical beads $\vec{R}_{0}$ and $\vec{R}_{N+1}$ as:<center><math> \begin{cases} \vec{R}_{0}\equiv\vec{R}_{1}
\vec{R}_{N+1}\equiv\vec{R}_{N}\end{cases}</math></center> under this definition the Langevin equation for beads <math>n=1,2,...,N</math> is given by: <center><math> \begin{cases} \frac{d\vec{R}_{n}(t)}{dt}=\frac{k}{\zeta}\left(\vec{R}_{n+1}(t)+\vec{R}_{n-1}(t)-2\vec{R}_{n}(t)\right)+\vec{g}_{n}(t) & \,\,\, n=1,...,N\end{cases}</math></center>
======How do we proceed?======
In order to proceed it is convenient to assume that the beads are continuously distributed along the polymer chain. We first recall that in the continuum limit: <center><math> \vec{R}_{n+1}(t)+\vec{R}_{n-1}(t)-2\vec{R}_{n}(t)\,\,\longrightarrow\,\,\frac{\partial^{2}\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n^{2}}</math></center> Letting <math>n</math> be a continuous variable, and writing <math>\vec{R}_{n}(t)</math> as $\vec{R}(n,t)$ the Langevin equation takes the form: <center><math> \frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial t}=\frac{k}{\zeta}\frac{\partial^{2}\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n^{2}}+\vec{g}(n,t)</math></center> The definitions we made regarding the additional hypothetical beads <math>\vec{R}_{0}</math> and <math>\vec{R}_{N+1}</math> now turn into the following boundary conditions:<center><math> \begin{cases} \frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n}|_{n=0}=0
\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n}|_{n=N}=0\end{cases}</math></center>
\subsubsection{I don't know how to solve this one, can we bring it to a form of something we have solved before? }
Yes we can, as a first step we define normal coordinates by the following transformation: <center><math> \begin{cases} \vec{X}_{p}(t)=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{R}(n,t)dn & \,\,\, p=0,1,2,...\end{cases}</math></center> whose inverse is given by:<center><math> \vec{R}(n,t)=\vec{X}_{0}(t)+2\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=1}{\sum}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math></center>
\subsubsection{Defining new coordinates (call them as you will) is one thing but the inverse must be defined such that it takes you back to the original coordinates! Is this truly the correct inverse? }
We verify this by direct substitution: <center><math> \vec{X}_{p}(t)=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\left[\vec{X}_{0}(t)+2\overset{\infty}{\underset{p'=1}{\sum}}cos\left(\frac{p'\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{X}_{p'}(t)\right]dn</math></center> The first term gives: <center><math> \vec{X}_{0}(t)\delta_{p,0}=\begin{cases} \frac{\vec{X}_{0}(t)}{p\pi}sin\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)|_{n=0}^{n=N}=0 & \,\,\, p=1,2,3,..
\vec{X}_{0}(t) & \,\,\, p=0\end{cases}</math></center> Using the trigonometric identity:<center><math> cos(A)cos(B)=\frac{1}{2}\left[cos(A-B)+cos(A+B)\right]</math></center> the second term is written as: <center><math> \begin{cases} \frac{1}{N}\overset{\infty}{\underset{p'=1}{\sum}}\vec{X}_{p'}(t)\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\left[cos\left(\frac{(p+p')\pi n}{N}\right)+cos\left(\frac{(p-p')\pi n}{N}\right)\right]dn & \,\,\, p=1,2,3,..
\overset{\infty}{\underset{p'=1}{\sum}}\frac{2\vec{X}_{p'}(t)}{p'\pi}sin\left(\frac{p'\pi n}{N}\right)|_{n=0}^{n=N}=0 & \,\,\, p=0\end{cases}</math></center> which gives: <center><math> \vec{X}_{p}(t)(1-\delta_{p,0})=\begin{cases} \overset{\infty}{\underset{p'=1}{\sum}}\vec{X}_{p'}(t)\delta_{p,p'}=\vec{X}_{p} & \,\,\, p=1,2,3,..
0 & \,\,\, p=0\end{cases}</math></center> We conclude that: <center><math> \vec{X}_{p}(t)=\vec{X}_{0}(t)\delta_{p,0}+\vec{X}_{p}(t)(1-\delta_{p,0})=\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math></center> which proves that the inverse transformation is defined correctly.
======How does this new set of coordinates help us? ======
We will now show that the equations of motion for the normal coordinates <math>\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math> are the equations of motion for an infinite set of uncoupled Brownian harmonic oscillators. Since we have already treated the problem of a Brownian harmonic oscillator, this will ease our lives considerably. We start by applying <math>\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)dn</math> to both side of the Langevin equation for $\vec{R}(n,t)$: {\footnotesize <center><math> \frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial t}dn=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{k}{\zeta}\frac{\partial^{2}\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n^{2}}dn+\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{g}(n,t)dn</math></center> }The left hand side term is identified as: <center><math> \frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial t}dn=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left[\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{R}(n,t)dn\right]=\frac{d\vec{X}_{p}(t)}{dt}</math></center> The first term on the right hand side gives: <center><math> \frac{cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)}{N}\frac{k}{\zeta}\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n}|_{n=0}^{n=N}+\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{p\pi}{N^{2}}sin\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{k}{\zeta}\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n}dn</math></center> by integration by parts. Invoking the boundary condition for <math>\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial n}</math> the first term drops, another round of integration by parts gives:<center><math> \frac{p\pi}{N^{2}}sin\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{k}{\zeta}\vec{R}(n,t)|_{n=0}^{n=N}-\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{\left(p\pi\right)^{2}}{N^{3}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{k}{\zeta}\vec{R}(n,t)dn</math></center> Here the sine kills the first term and the second term is identified as:<center><math> -\frac{p^{2}\pi^{2}k\vec{X}_{p}(t)}{N^{2}\zeta}=-\frac{k_{p}}{\zeta_{p}}\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math></center> where we have defined: <center><math> \begin{cases} k_{p}=\frac{2p^{2}\pi^{2}k}{N} & \,\,\, p=0,1,2,3...
\zeta_{0}=N\zeta & \,\,\, p=0
\zeta_{p}=2N\zeta & \,\,\, p=1,2,3...\end{cases}</math></center> We are left with the second term on the right hand side of the original equation which we deal with by defining the random forces:<center><math> \begin{cases} \vec{g}_{p}(t)=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{g}(n,t)dn & \,\,\, p=0,1,2,3...\end{cases}</math></center> Which are characterized by zero mean:<center><math> \begin{cases} <g_{\alpha p}(t)>=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)<g_{\alpha}(n,t)>dn=0 & \forall p\,,\forall\alpha=x,y,z\end{cases}</math></center> And by: <center><math> \begin{cases} <g_{\alpha p}(t)g_{\beta p'}(t')>=\frac{2k_{B}T\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta_{pp'}\delta(t-t')}{\zeta_{p}} & \forall p,p'\,,\forall\alpha,\beta=x,y,z\end{cases}</math></center> since: {\footnotesize <center><math> <g_{\alpha p}(t)g_{\beta p'}(t')>=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{p'\pi n'}{N}\right)<g_{\alpha}(n,t)g_{\beta}(n',t')>dndn'</math></center> }and use of the trigonometric identity: <center><math> cos(A)cos(B)=\frac{1}{2}\left[cos(A-B)+cos(A+B)\right]</math></center> gives: {\footnotesize <center><math> <g_{\alpha p}(t)g_{\beta p'}(t')>=\frac{k_{B}T\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta(t-t')}{\zeta N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\left[cos\left(\frac{(p+p')\pi n}{N}\right)+cos\left(\frac{(p-p')\pi n}{N}\right)\right]dn</math></center> }which yields the result after preforming the integration. This means that the random forces with different values of <math>p</math> and/or acting in perpendicular directions and/or acting in different times are independent. The equations of motion for the normal coordinates <math>\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math> are given by: <center><math> \frac{d\vec{X}_{p}(t)}{dt}=-\frac{k_{p}}{\zeta_{p}}\vec{X}_{p}(t)+\vec{g}_{p}(t)</math></center> and since the random forces are independent of each other, the motions of the <math>\vec{X}_{p}</math>'s are also independent of each other. These are the equations of motion for an infinite set of uncoupled Brownian harmonic oscillators, each with a force constant <math>k_{p}</math> and friction constant <math>\zeta_{p}</math> of its own. We have gone from one partial differential equation (which we don't know how to solve directly) for <math>\vec{R}(n,t)</math> to an infinite set of uncoupled ordinary differential equations (from a type we are already familiar with) for the normal coordinates <math>\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math>.
=====Great, we can now do some analysis! =====
======What can we say about the motion of the center of mass? ======
Using the results of section 3 we will now calculate two time correlation function that will help us in the near future. We first note that since <math>k_{0}=0</math>, <math>\vec{X}_{0}</math> is actually preforming free diffusion and hence:{\tiny <center><math> <(X_{0}(t)-X_{0}(0))_{\alpha}(X_{0}(t)-X_{0}(0))_{\beta}>=<(X_{0}(t)-<X_{0}(t)>)_{\alpha}(X_{0}(t)-<X_{0}(t)>)_{\beta}>=\delta_{\alpha\beta}\frac{2k_{B}T}{N\zeta}t</math></center> }On the other hand, the time correlation function for <math>\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math> ($p>0)$ is the one for a Brownian harmonic oscillator and hence:<center><math> <X_{p\alpha}(t)X_{p'\beta}(0)>=\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta_{pp'}\frac{k_{B}T}{k_{p}}e^{-t/\tau_{p}}</math></center> where the relaxation time $\tau_{p}$ is given by:<center><math> \tau_{p}=\frac{\zeta_{p}}{k_{p}}=\frac{N^{2}\zeta}{p^{2}\pi^{2}k}=\frac{\tau_{1}}{p^{2}}</math></center> A conclusion from the previous result is that: <center><math> <\left(X_{p\alpha}(t)-X_{p'\beta}(0)\right)^{2}>=\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta_{pp'}\frac{2k_{B}T}{k_{p}}\left[1-e^{-t/\tau_{p}}\right]</math></center>
We are now ready to calculate some real features of the Brownian motion of a polymer. We start with the motion of the center of mass, the position of the center of mass: <center><math> \vec{R}_{cm}(t)=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\vec{R}(n,t)dn\equiv\vec{X}_{0}(t)</math></center> is the same as the normal coordinate <math>\vec{X}_{0}(t)</math>. The mean square displacement of the center of mass is hence given by:<center><math> <(\vec{R}_{cm}(t)-\vec{R}_{cm}(0))^{2}>=3<(X_{0}(t)-X_{0}(0))_{\alpha}^{2}>=\frac{6k_{B}T}{N\zeta}t\equiv6D_{G}t</math></center> where the diffusion constant $D_{G}$ is given by:<center><math> D_{G}=\frac{k_{B}T}{N\zeta}</math></center> and we note that it is inversely proportional to the number of monomers. ====What can we say about rotational motion?==== To characterize rotational motion of the polymer molecule as a whole, let us consider the time correlation function <math><\vec{P}(t)\cdot\vec{P}(0)></math> of the end to end vector <math>\vec{P}</math>. Using normal coordinates, <math>\vec{P}(t)</math> can be written as: <center><math> \vec{P}(t)\equiv\vec{R}(N,t)-\vec{R}(0,t)=2\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=1}{\sum}}\left[cos\left(p\pi\right)-1\right]\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math></center> which results in:<center><math> \vec{P}(t)\equiv-4\overset{}{\underset{p:odd\,\, integers}{\sum}}\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math></center> We therefore conclude that:<center><math> <\vec{P}(t)\cdot\vec{P}(0)>=16\overset{}{\underset{p:odd\,\, integers}{\sum}}<\vec{X}_{p}(t)\cdot\vec{X}_{p}(0)>=16\overset{}{\underset{p:odd\,\, integers}{\sum}}\frac{3k_{B}T}{k_{p}}e^{-t/\tau_{p}}</math></center> This time correlation function is a summation over many terms with different relaxation times. We will now see that for large enough times this infinite sum is well approximated by the first term. We rewrite the correlation function as: <center><math> <\vec{P}(t)\cdot\vec{P}(0)>=\frac{24Nk_{B}T}{\pi^{2}k}e^{-t/\tau_{1}}\left[1+\overset{}{\underset{p:odd\,\, integers>1}{\sum}}\frac{1}{p^{2}}e^{-t\left[\frac{1}{\tau_{p}}-\frac{1}{\tau_{1}}\right]}\right]</math></center> but since: <center><math> \left[\frac{1}{\tau_{p}}-\frac{1}{\tau_{1}}\right]\geq\left[\frac{1}{\tau_{3}}-\frac{1}{\tau_{1}}\right]>0</math></center> we have:<center><math> e^{-t\left[\frac{1}{\tau_{p}}-\frac{1}{\tau_{1}}\right]}\leq e^{-t\left[\frac{1}{\tau_{3}}-\frac{1}{\tau_{1}}\right]}</math></center> We also know that: <center><math> \overset{}{\underset{p:odd\,\, integers>1}{\sum}}\frac{1}{p^{2}}=\frac{\pi^{2}}{8}-1</math></center> and hence the second term in the parentheses is bounded by an exponentially decaying function and moreover it is never larger than $1/4$: <center><math> \overset{}{\underset{p:odd\,\, integers>1}{\sum}}\frac{1}{p^{2}}e^{-t\left[\frac{1}{\tau_{p}}-\frac{1}{\tau_{1}}\right]}\leq\left[\frac{\pi^{2}}{8}-1\right]e^{-t\left[\frac{1}{\tau_{3}}-\frac{1}{\tau_{1}}\right]}<\frac{1}{4}</math></center> We conclude that the second term may be neglected for large times and the correlation function is approximated to be: <center><math> <\vec{P}(t)\cdot\vec{P}(0)>\cong\frac{24Nk_{B}T}{\pi^{2}k}e^{-t/\tau_{1}}</math></center> which decays exponentially with a single relaxation time <math>\tau_{1}</math>. The relaxation time <math>\tau_{1}</math> is called the rotational relaxation time, it is also denoted $\tau_{r}$ and is given by:<center><math> \tau_{r}=\frac{N^{2}\zeta}{\pi^{2}k}</math></center> ====What can we say about the motion of one specific bead?==== We now turn to study the internal motion of a polymer chain focusing on the mean square displacement of the $n-th$ monomer: <center><math> \phi(n,t)\equiv<\left[\vec{R}(n,t)-\vec{R}(n,0)\right]^{2}></math></center> Direct substitution for <math>\vec{R}(n,t)</math> and <math>\vec{R}(n,0)</math> gives: <center><math> \phi(n,t)=<\left[\vec{X}_{0}(t)-\vec{X}_{0}(0)+2\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=1}{\sum}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\left(\vec{X}_{p}(t)-\vec{X}_{p}(0)\right)\right]^{2}></math></center> utilizing the correlation functions we have obtained above all the cross terms vanish and we are left with: <center><math> \phi(n,t)=6D_{G}t\,+\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=1}{\sum}}\frac{24k_{B}T}{k_{p}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)^{2}\left[1-e^{-tp^{2}/\tau_{r}}\right]</math></center> Let us examine this expression in two limits, for <math>t\gg\tau_{r}</math>: <center><math> \phi(n,t)\simeq6D_{G}t\,+\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=1}{\sum}}\frac{12k_{B}T}{p^{2}\pi^{2}k}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)^{2}</math></center> The second term is a constant that doesn't depend on time (it is easily seen that the infinite sum converges) and hence <math>\phi(n,t)</math> is linear in <math>t</math> in this limit. For large enough times the displacement of the <math>n-th</math> monomer is determined by the diffusion constant of the center of mass as the monomer drifts away with the polymer as a whole. On the other hand, for <math>t\ll\tau_{r}</math>, the motion of the segments reflects the internal motion due to the many modes of vibration. In this limit we may approximate by replacing summation with integration and <math>cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)^{2}</math> by its average value <math>1/2</math>: <center><math> \phi(n,t)=\frac{6k_{B}T}{N\zeta}t\,+\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=0}{\int}}\frac{6Nk_{B}T}{p^{2}\pi^{2}k}\left[1-e^{-tp^{2}/\tau_{r}}\right]dp=\frac{6k_{B}T}{N\zeta}t+I</math></center> Doing the integral by parts we get: {\tiny <center><math> I=\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=0}{\int}}\frac{6Nk_{B}T}{\pi^{2}k}\left[e^{-tp^{2}/\tau_{r}}-1\right]d\frac{1}{p}=\frac{6Nk_{B}T}{p\pi^{2}k}\left[e^{-tp^{2}/\tau_{r}}-1\right]|_{0}^{\infty}+\overset{\infty}{\underset{p=0}{\int}}\frac{12tNk_{B}T}{\tau_{r}\pi^{2}k}e^{-tp^{2}/\tau_{r}}dp</math></center> }The first term vanishes (basic calculus) and the second term is transformed into a Gaussian integral which gives:<center><math> I=\frac{6tNk_{B}T}{\tau_{r}\pi^{2}k}\sqrt{\frac{\pi\tau_{r}}{t}}=\frac{6Nk_{B}T}{\sqrt{\tau_{r}}\pi^{3/2}k}\sqrt{t}</math></center> We can now write the $\phi(n,t)$ as: <center><math> \phi(n,t)=\frac{6Nk_{B}T}{\pi^{2}k}\left[\frac{t}{\tau_{r}}+\sqrt{\frac{\pi t}{\tau_{r}}}\right]\underset{t\ll\tau_{r}}{\simeq}\frac{6Nk_{B}T}{\pi^{3/2}k}\sqrt{\frac{t}{\tau_{r}}}</math></center> and observe that in this limit the mean square displacement of the <math>n-th</math> monomer increases like <math>\sqrt{t}</math>, i.e in a sub-diffusive manner. =====How does the Rouse model stand in comparison to experimental results? ===== Unfortunately not as good as one might have hoped. The Rouse model may seem to be a very natural way to describe the Brownian motion of a polymer chain, but unfortunately the conclusions drawn from it do not agree with the experimental results. As we saw above, for the Rouse model: <center><math> \begin{cases} \tau_{r}=\frac{N^{2}\zeta}{p^{2}\pi^{2}k}\propto N^{2}\propto M^{2}
D_{G}=\frac{6kT}{N\zeta}\propto\frac{1}{N}\propto\frac{1}{M}\end{cases}</math></center> where <math>M</math> is the molecular weight of the polymer. Experimentally however, the following dependencies were measured: <center><math> \begin{cases} \tau_{r}\propto M^{3\nu}
D_{G}\propto M^{-\nu}\end{cases}</math></center> Here, the exponent <math>\nu</math> is that which is used to express the dependence of the radius of gyration <math>R_{G}</math> on molecular weight (): <center><math> R_{G}\propto M^{\nu}</math></center> The value of <math>\nu</math> is determined by the nature of the interaction between the solvent and the polymer, in a good solvent <math>\nu\simeq\frac{3}{5}</math> and in the <math>\Theta</math> state <math>\nu=\frac{1}{2}</math> ().
The reason for the discrepancy between experiments and the Rouse model is that in the latter we have assumed the average velocity of a particular bead is determined only by the external force acting on it, and is independent of the motion of the other beads. However, in reality the motion of one bead is influenced by the motion of the surrounding beads through the medium of the solvent. For example, if one bead moves the solvent surrounding it will also move, and as a result other beads will be dragged along. This type of interaction transmitted by the motion of the solvent is called hydrodynamic interaction. We will discuss a model taking this interaction into account in the next section. \begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.5]{\string"29-07-2009 14-52-26\string".eps} \par\end{centering} \caption{The hydrodynamic interaction. If bead <math>n</math> moves under the action of the force <math>\vec{F}_{n}</math>, a flow is created in the surrounding fluid, which causes the other beads to move.} \end{figure} \newpage{} ====The Zimm Model for Polymer Dynamics==== \subsection{So we need a model that will take into account hydrodynamics interactions, but how do we do that?} In the Rouse model we have assumed the average velocity of a particular bead is determined only by the external force acting on it, and is independent of the motion of the other beads. This assumption led to the following Langevin equation:<center><math> \vec{v}_{n}(t)=\frac{d\vec{R}_{n}(t)}{dt}=-\frac{1}{\zeta_{n}}\frac{\partial U}{\partial\vec{R}_{n}}+\vec{g}_{n}(t)=\frac{\vec{F}_{n}}{\zeta_{n}}+\vec{g}_{n}(t)</math></center> In order to take into account hydrodynamic interaction we can generalize this assumption. Denoting the forces acting on the beads by <math>\vec{F}_{n}(n=1,2,..)</math> , we assume that there is a linear relationship between these forces and the average velocity <math><\vec{v}_{n}(t)></math> and so the following holds: <center><math> <\vec{v}_{n}(t)>=\overset{}{\underset{m}{\sum}}H_{nm}\cdot\vec{F}_{m}</math></center> Here <math>H_{nm}</math> is a <math>3\times3</math> matrix, the <math>nm</math> component of <math>H</math>. It is now our task to calculate <math>H_{nm}</math> and write the appropriate Langevin equation. This can be done using hydrodynamics and some approximations (), the result of the calculation gives: <center><math> H_{nm}=\begin{cases} I/\zeta & \,\,\, n=m
\frac{[\hat{r}_{nm}\hat{r}_{nm}+I]}{8\pi\eta\left\Vert \vec{r}_{nm}\right\Vert } & \,\,\, n\neq m\end{cases}</math></center> where <math>\eta</math> is the viscosity of the liquid, <math>I</math> is the <math>3\times3</math> identity matrix, <math>\vec{r}_{nm}\equiv\vec{R}_{n}-\vec{R}_{m}</math> and <math>\hat{r}_{nm}</math> is a unit vector in the direction of <math>\vec{r}_{nm}</math>. The appropriate Langevin equation is given by (taking the same potential $U$ as in the Rouse model): <center><math> \frac{d\vec{R}_{n}(t)}{dt}=k\overset{}{\underset{m}{\sum}}H_{nm}\cdot(\vec{R}_{m+1}(t)+\vec{R}_{m-1}(t)-2\vec{R}_{m}(t))+\vec{g}_{n}(t)</math></center> and the random force <math>\vec{g}_{n}(t)</math> is Gaussian with the following characteristics: <center><math> \begin{cases} <g_{\alpha n}(t)>=0 & \forall n,\forall\alpha=x,y,z
<g_{\alpha n}(t)g_{\beta m}(t')>=2k_{B}T\left(H_{nm}\right)_{\alpha\beta}\delta(t-t') & \forall n,m\,,\forall\alpha,\beta=x,y,z\end{cases}</math></center> \subsubsection{The Langevin equation we got seems complicated, it is not even linear in <math>\vec{R}_{n}(t)</math>! I guess there is an approximation coming my way, am I right? }
Since <math>H_{nm}</math> depends on <math>\vec{R}_{n}(t)</math> the Langevin equation we got is not linear in <math>\vec{R}_{n}(t)</math> and hence tremendously hard to solve. Zimm's idea was to replace <math>H_{nm}</math> (the factor that is causing the non-linearity) by its equilibrium average value <math><H_{nm}>_{eq}</math>, this is called the preaveraging approximation. In general the equilibrium value of <math>H_{nm}</math> depends on the interactions between the solvent and the polymer and hence will have a different value in a good/medium/bad solvents. Here we will concentrate on a special state of a polymer in solution, this state was also mentioned earlier and is called the <math>\Theta</math> state (). For a polymer in <math>\Theta</math> conditions, the vector <math>\vec{r}_{nm}</math> is characterized by a Gaussian distribution with zero mean and a variance of <math>|n-m|b^{2}</math>. Here <math>b</math> is the distance between two adjacent monomers and it follows that the probability density function for $\vec{r}_{nm}$ is: <center><math> P(\vec{r}_{nm})=\left(\frac{3}{2\pi|n-m|b^{2}}\right)^{3/2}exp\left(-\frac{3\left\Vert \vec{r}_{nm}\right\Vert ^{2}}{2|n-m|b^{2}}\right)</math></center> Since <math>H_{nm}</math> is a function only of <math>\vec{r}_{nm}</math> we can calculate $<H_{nm}>_{eq}$ (for $n\neq m$) as follows:{\scriptsize <center><math> <H_{nm}>_{eq}=\int d^{3}\vec{r}P(\vec{r})H_{nm}=\int d\vec{r}\left(\frac{3}{2\pi|n-m|b^{2}}\right)^{3/2}exp\left(-\frac{3r^{2}}{2|n-m|b^{2}}\right)\frac{[\hat{r}\hat{r}+I]}{8\pi\eta r}</math></center> }Noting that in spherical coordinates: <center><math> \hat{r}\hat{r}=\left[\begin{matrix}{ccc} sin^{2}\theta cos^{2}\phi & sin^{2}\theta cos\phi sin\phi & cos\theta sin\theta cos\phi
sin^{2}\theta cos\phi sin\phi & sin^{2}\theta sin^{2}\phi & cos\theta sin\theta sin\phi
cos\theta sin\theta cos\phi & cos\theta sin\theta sin\phi & cos^{2}\theta\end{array}\right]</math></center> We have:<center><math> \overset{\pi}{\underset{0}{\int}}sin\theta d\theta\overset{2\pi}{\underset{0}{\int}}d\phi\hat{r}\hat{r}=\left[\begin{matrix}{ccc} \frac{4\pi}{3} & 0 & 0
0 & \frac{4\pi}{3} & 0
0 & 0 & \frac{4\pi}{3}\end{array}\right]=\frac{4\pi}{3}I</math></center> and hence:{\scriptsize <center><math> <H_{nm}>_{eq}=\int d^{3}\vec{r}P(\vec{r})H_{nm}=\overset{\infty}{\underset{0}{\int}}4\pi r^{2}dr\left(\frac{3}{2\pi|n-m|b^{2}}\right)^{3/2}exp\left(-\frac{3r^{2}}{2|n-m|b^{2}}\right)\frac{\frac{4}{3}I}{8\pi\eta r}</math></center> }The integral is calculated in a straight forward way, defining <math>t=r^{2}</math> we have:{\scriptsize <center><math> \overset{\infty}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{I}{3\eta}\left(\frac{3}{2\pi|n-m|b^{2}}\right)^{3/2}exp\left(-\frac{3t}{2|n-m|b^{2}}\right)dt=\frac{I}{3\eta}\left(\frac{3}{2\pi|n-m|b^{2}}\right)^{3/2}\frac{2|n-m|b^{2}}{3}</math></center> }and hence: <center><math> <H_{nm}>_{eq}=h(n-m)I</math></center> where we have defined: <center><math> h(n-m)\equiv\frac{1}{\eta b}\left(\frac{1}{6\pi^{3}|n-m|}\right)^{1/2}</math></center> Substituting this result into our Langevin equation and re-writing it in the continuum limit we get:<center><math> \frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial t}=k\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}dmh(n-m)\frac{\partial^{2}\vec{R}(m,t)}{\partial^{2}m}+\vec{g}(n,t)</math></center> where the random force <math>\vec{g}(n,t)</math> is Gaussian with the following characteristics:{\small <center><math> \begin{cases} <g_{\alpha}(n,t)>=0 & \forall n,\forall\alpha=x,y,z
<g_{\alpha}(n,t)g_{\beta}(m,t')>=2k_{B}Th(n-m)\delta(t-t') & \forall n,m\,,\forall\alpha,\beta=x,y,z\end{cases}</math></center> }Note that <math>h(n-m)</math> depend only on <math>|n-m|</math> and we have indeed linearized our equation as promised. ======Seems familiar, shall we try normal coordinates again?====== Yes, we will one again use the normal coordinates defined for the Rouse model. We start by applying <math>\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)dn</math> to both side of the Langevin equation for $\vec{R}(n,t)$:{\tiny <center><math> \frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial t}dn=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\left[k\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}dmh(n-m)\frac{\partial^{2}\vec{R}(m,t)}{\partial^{2}m}\right]dn+\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{g}(n,t)dn</math></center> }The left hand side term is identified as: <center><math> \frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{\partial\vec{R}(n,t)}{\partial t}dn=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left[\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{R}(n,t)dn\right]=\frac{d\vec{X}_{p}(t)}{dt}</math></center> The first term on the right hand side gives: <center><math> \frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\left[k\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}dmh(n-m)\frac{\partial^{2}\left[\vec{X}_{0}(t)+2\overset{\infty}{\underset{q=1}{\sum}}cos\left(\frac{q\pi m}{N}\right)\vec{X}_{q}(t)\right]}{\partial^{2}m}\right]dn</math></center> which yields: <center><math> \frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\left[-2k\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}dmh(n-m)\overset{\infty}{\underset{q=1}{\sum}}\left(\frac{q\pi}{N}\right)^{^{2}}cos\left(\frac{q\pi m}{N}\right)\vec{X}_{q}(t)\right]dn</math></center> and with some additional algebra we get: <center><math> -\overset{\infty}{\underset{q=1}{\sum}}\frac{2kq^{2}\pi^{2}}{N}\vec{X}_{q}(t)\left[\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{q\pi m}{N}\right)h(n-m)dmdn\right]</math></center> Defining: <center><math> \begin{cases} k_{q}=\frac{2q^{2}\pi^{2}k}{N} & \,\,\, q=0,1,2,3...
h_{pq}=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{q\pi m}{N}\right)h(n-m)dmdn & \,\,\, p,q=0,1,2,3...\end{cases}</math></center> this term can be written as: <center><math> -\overset{\infty}{\underset{q=1}{\sum}}h_{pq}k_{q}\vec{X}_{q}(t)</math></center>
======But this doesn't decouple the equations! another approximation?======
Indeed, we will approximate by neglecting all the off diagonal terms. The reasoning goes as follows, we first note that setting <math>m-n=l</math> and noting that $h(n-m)=h(m-n)$ we can write $h_{pq}$ as: <center><math> h_{pq}=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}dn\overset{N-n}{\underset{-n}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{q\pi(n+l)}{N}\right)h(l)dl</math></center> we now use a trigonometric identity:<center><math> cos(A+B)=cos(A)cos(B)-sin(A)sin(B)</math></center> to get:{\tiny <center><math> h_{pq}=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}dn\left[cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{q\pi n}{N}\right)\overset{N-n}{\underset{-n}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{q\pi l}{N}\right)h(l)dl\,-cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)sin\left(\frac{q\pi n}{N}\right)\overset{N-n}{\underset{-n}{\int}}sin\left(\frac{q\pi l}{N}\right)h(l)dl\right]</math></center> }For large <math>q</math>, the two inner integrals rapidly approach the following integrals:<center><math> \begin{cases} \overset{\infty}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{q\pi l}{N}\right)h(l)dl=\frac{\sqrt{N}}{\sqrt{3\pi^{3}q}\eta b}
\overset{\infty}{\underset{-\infty}{\int}}sin\left(\frac{q\pi l}{N}\right)h(l)dl=0\end{cases}</math></center> With this substitution $h_{pq}$ becomes:\underbar{ }<center><math> h_{pq}=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{q\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{\sqrt{N}}{\sqrt{3\pi^{3}q}\eta b}dn</math></center> and after using the trigonometric identity: <center><math> cos(A)cos(B)=\frac{1}{2}\left[cos(A-B)+cos(A+B)\right]</math></center> {\small <center><math> \begin{cases} h_{pq}=\frac{1}{2N^{3/2}\sqrt{3\pi^{3}q}\eta b}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{\pi n(p-q)}{N}\right)+cos\left(\frac{\pi n(p+q)}{N}\right)dn=\frac{\delta_{pq}}{\sqrt{12N\pi^{3}p}\eta b} & p>0\end{cases}</math></center> }If <math>q</math> is small our approximation is still fair but for the case <math>q=0</math> it is invalid and this case deserves special attention. The careful reader may have noticed that the sum:<center><math> -\overset{\infty}{\underset{q=1}{\sum}}h_{pq}k_{q}\vec{X}_{q}(t)</math></center> starts from <math>q=1</math> and it may seem that a discussion regarding <math>q=0</math> is pointless. We will nevertheless require this case (<math>q=0</math>) later on and so we calculate directly{\small : }<center><math> h_{p0}=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)dn\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{1}{\eta b}\left(\frac{1}{6\pi^{3}|n-m|}\right)^{1/2}dm</math></center> The inner integral gives:<center><math> \overset{n}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{1}{\eta b}\left(\frac{1}{6\pi^{3}(n-m)}\right)^{1/2}dm+\overset{N}{\underset{n}{\int}}\frac{1}{\eta b}\left(\frac{1}{6\pi^{3}(m-n)}\right)^{1/2}dm</math></center> which results in:<center><math> \frac{-2}{\eta b}\left(\frac{n-m}{6\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}|_{0}^{n}+\frac{2}{\eta b}\left(\frac{m-n}{6\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}|_{n}^{N}=\frac{2}{\eta b}\left(\frac{n}{6\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}+\frac{2}{\eta b}\left(\frac{N-n}{6\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}</math></center> Substituting this into the expression for $h_{p0}$ gives:<center><math> h_{p0}=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\frac{2}{\eta b}\left(\frac{n}{6\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}dn+\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(p\pi-\frac{p\pi t}{N}\right)\frac{2}{\eta b}\left(\frac{t}{6\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}dt</math></center> where we have changed variables to <math>t=N-n</math>. It is now easy to see that for odd $p$: $h_{p0}=0$, while for even $p$ we get: <center><math> h_{p0}=\frac{4}{\eta bN^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{6\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\sqrt{n}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)dn\,\,\,\, for\,\, even\,\, p</math></center> For $p=0$ this gives:<center><math> h_{00}=\frac{8}{3\eta b}\left(\frac{1}{6N\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2}</math></center> while for even <math>p>0</math>, the integral may be re-expressed in terms of the Fresnel integral <math>S(x)=\overset{x}{\underset{0}{\int}}sin^{2}(t)dt</math> to give: <center><math> \overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\sqrt{n}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)=\frac{-\sqrt{2}N^{3/2}}{2\pi p^{3/2}}S(\sqrt{2p})</math></center> and we see that:<center><math> \left|\frac{-\sqrt{2}N^{3/2}}{2\pi p^{3/2}}S(\sqrt{2p})\right|\leq\frac{N^{3/2}}{\pi p}</math></center> concluding that for $p>0$:<center><math> \begin{cases} \left|h_{p0}\right|\leq\frac{4}{\eta b\pi p}\left(\frac{1}{6N\pi^{3}}\right)^{1/2} & even\,\, p>0
h_{p0}=0 & odd\,\, p>0\end{cases}</math></center> We see that for large <math>N</math>, <math>h_{p0}</math> is small and also decays with <math>p</math>. We will hence neglect <math>h_{p0}</math> for <math>p>0</math> and keep only the diagonal term <math>h_{00}</math>.
======O.K, what about the random forces?======
We are left with the second term on the right hand side of the original equation which we deal with by defining the random forces:<center><math> \begin{cases} \vec{g}_{p}(t)=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)\vec{g}(n,t)dn & \,\,\, p=0,1,2,3...\end{cases}</math></center> Which are characterized by zero mean:<center><math> \begin{cases} <g_{\alpha p}(t)>=\frac{1}{N}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)<g_{\alpha}(n,t)>dn=0 & \forall p\,,\forall\alpha=x,y,z\end{cases}</math></center> And by: <center><math> \begin{cases} <g_{\alpha p}(t)g_{\beta p'}(t')>=2k_{B}T\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta(t-t')h_{pp'} & \forall p,p'\,,\forall\alpha,\beta=x,y,z\end{cases}</math></center> since: {\footnotesize <center><math> <g_{\alpha p}(t)g_{\beta p'}(t')>=\frac{1}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{p'\pi n'}{N}\right)<g_{\alpha}(n,t)g_{\beta}(n',t')>dndn'</math></center> }gives: {\footnotesize <center><math> <g_{\alpha p}(t)g_{\beta p'}(t')>=\frac{2k_{B}T\delta_{\alpha\beta}\delta(t-t')}{N^{2}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}\overset{N}{\underset{0}{\int}}cos\left(\frac{p\pi n}{N}\right)cos\left(\frac{p'\pi n'}{N}\right)h(n-n')dndn'</math></center> }which yields the result by definition of <math>h_{pp'}</math>. This means that the random forces with different values of <math>p</math> (remember <math>h_{pp'}\propto\delta_{pp'}</math>) and/or acting in perpendicular directions and/or acting in different times are independent.
======That was a bit long, could you please sum up the main result?======
The main result is that we have found the equations of motion for the normal coordinates <math>\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math> and that they are given by: <center><math> \frac{d\vec{X}_{p}(t)}{dt}=-\frac{k_{p}}{\zeta_{p}}\vec{X}_{p}(t)+\vec{g}_{p}(t)</math></center> with <center><math> \begin{cases} k_{p}=\frac{2p^{2}\pi^{2}k}{N} & \,\,\, p=0,1,2,3...
\zeta_{0}=1/h_{00}=\frac{3\eta b}{8}\left(6N\pi^{3}\right)^{1/2} & \,\,\, p=0
\zeta_{p}=1/h_{pp}=\sqrt{12N\pi^{3}p}\eta b & \,\,\, p=1,2,3...\end{cases}</math></center> and since the random forces are independent of each other, the motions of the <math>\vec{X}_{p}</math>'s are also independent of each other. These are the equations of motion for an infinite set of uncoupled Brownian harmonic oscillators, each with a force constant <math>k_{p}</math> and friction coefficient <math>\zeta_{p}</math> of its own. We have once again gone from one partial differential equation (which we don't know how to solve directly) for <math>\vec{R}(n,t)</math> to an infinite set of uncoupled ordinary differential equations (from a type we are already familiar with) for the normal coordinates <math>\vec{X}_{p}(t)</math>.
\subsubsection{Great! This is very similar to what we got for the Rouse model, are we going to repeat the same type of analysis? }
Since the equation for the normal modes is the same as that for the Rouse model, we can immediately write the expressions for the diffusion constant of the center of mass and the rotational relaxation time using the results of the previous section:<center><math> \begin{cases} D_{G}=\frac{k_{B}T}{\zeta_{0}}=\frac{8k_{B}T}{3\eta b\left(6N\pi^{3}\right)^{1/2}}
\tau_{r}=\frac{\zeta_{1}}{k_{1}}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{\pi}}\frac{\eta b}{k}N^{3/2}\end{cases}</math></center>
=====How does the Zimm model stand in comparison to experimental results? =====
As can been seen <math>D_{G}</math> and <math>\tau_{r}</math> depend on the molecular weight $M$ as follows (recall that $M\propto N$): <center><math> \begin{cases} D_{G}\propto\frac{1}{\sqrt{M}}
\tau_{r}\propto M^{3/2}\end{cases}</math></center> The dependence of these quantities on the molecular weight agrees with experiments performed on solutions in the <math>\Theta</math> state. Furthermore, the relaxation times of the normal modes are: <center><math> \tau_{p}=\frac{\zeta_{p}}{k_{p}}=\frac{\tau_{r}}{p^{3/2}}</math></center> and hence for short times (<math>t\ll\tau_{r}</math>) the average mean square displacement of the $n-th$ monomer is given by: <center><math> \phi(n,t)\approx\frac{2Nb^{2}}{\pi^{2}}\overset{\infty}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{1-exp(-tp^{3/2}/\tau_{r})}{p^{2}}dp</math></center> integration by parts gives:<center><math> \phi(n,t)\approx\frac{2Nb^{2}}{\pi^{2}}\left[\frac{-1+exp(-tp^{3/2}/\tau_{r})}{p}\right]|_{0}^{\infty}+\frac{3Ntb^{2}}{\tau_{r}\pi^{2}}\overset{\infty}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{exp(-tp^{3/2}/\tau_{r})}{\sqrt{p}}dp</math></center> The first term drops (elementary calculus), the second term is treated by a change of variable $x=tp^{3/2}/\tau_{r}$ :<center><math> \phi(n,t)\approx\frac{3Ntb^{2}}{\tau_{r}\pi^{2}}\overset{\infty}{\underset{0}{\int}}\frac{2\tau_{r}exp(-x)}{3t\left[\frac{\tau_{r}x}{t}\right]^{2/3}}dx=\frac{2Nb^{2}\Gamma(1/3)}{\pi^{2}}\left[\frac{t}{\tau_{r}}\right]^{2/3}</math></center> where we have identified the gamma function <math>\Gamma(x)=\overset{\infty}{\underset{0}{\int}}t^{x-1}e^{-t}dt</math>. The relation <math>\phi(n,t)\propto t^{2/3}</math> has been confirmed by analysis of the Brownian motion of DNA molecules. \begin{figure}[H] \begin{centering} \includegraphics[scale=0.5]{\string"31-07-2009 01-21-59\string".eps} \par\end{centering} \caption{The average mean square displacement of the terminal segment of a DNA molecule (solid line), observed by fluorescence microscopy. The dashed line is calculated from the theory of Zimm. The graph is plotted on a log-log scale, on this type of plot the slope of the lines corresponds to the exponent <math>\alpha</math> in the relation <math>\phi(n,t)\propto t^{\alpha}</math>. The fact the the lines are parallel, supports the prediction <math>\alpha=\frac{2}{3}</math>. Taken from: J. Polym. Sci., 30, 779, Fig. 5. } \end{figure} \newpage{} ====I Have More Questions, Where can I get Answers? ==== \begin{thebibliography}{3} \bibitem{key-4}Introduction to Polymer Physics, Chapters 4\&5, M. Doi Translated by H. See, Clarendon Press, 30 November 1995. \bibitem{key-5}The Theory of Polymer Dynamics, Chapters 3-5, M. Doi and S. F. Edwards, Clarendon Press, 3 November 1988. \bibitem{key-6}Polymer Physics, Chapter 8, Michael Rubinstein and Ralph H. Colby Oxford University Press, 26 June 2003. \end{thebibliography}
