page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/Aug05 667

revision.text:
== Problem 4a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" | Given a smooth function <math>f(x) \!\,</math>, state the secant method for the approximate solution of nonlinear equation in <math> \mathbb{R}\!\,</math>
:::::::<math>f(x) = 0 \!\,</math> |}
==Solution 4a== <math>x_{k+1} = x_k - \frac{x_k - x_{k-1}}{f(x_k) - f(x_{k-1})}f(x_k) \!\,</math>
==Problem 4b== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" | State the order of convergence for this method, and explain how to derive it. |}
==Solution 4b== If <math>f''(x) \!\,</math> is bounded and <math> x_0 \!\,</math> is close to <math> x_* \!\,</math>, then the secant method has convergence order <math>\phi = \frac{1+ \sqrt{5}}{2} \approx 1.6180339887 \!\,</math> (the Golden ratio).
A partial proof of this can be found [http://www.mathcs.emory.edu/ccs/ccs315/ccs315/node19.html here]
==Problem 4c== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" | Are there situations in which the order of convergence is higher? Explain your answers. |}
==Solution 4c==
== Problem 5 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the initial value problem
<math>y'=f(t,y), \quad y(0)=y_0 \!\,</math>
|}
== Problem 5a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the ODE in integral form and explain how to use the trapezoidal quadrature rule to derive the trapezoidal method with uniform time step <math>h=\frac{T}{N} \!\,</math>:
<math>y_{n+1}=y_n+\frac{h}{2}(f(t_{n+1},y_{n+1})+f(t_n,y_n)) \!\,</math>
|}
== Solution 5a ==
<math>y(t_{n+1})-y(t_n) = \int_{t_n}^{t_{n+1}}y' = \int_{t_n}^{t_{n+1}} f(t,y) \approx \frac{h}{2}( f(t_{n+1},y_{n+1})+ f(t_n,y_n) ) \!\,</math>
== Problem 5b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Define the concept of absolute stability. That is, consider applying the method to the case <math>f(t,y)=\lambda y \!\,</math> with real <math>\lambda \!\,</math>. Show that the region of absolute stability contains the entire negative real axis of the complex <math>h \lambda \!\,</math> plane.
|}
== Solution 5b ==
Letting <math>f(t,y) = \lambda y \!\,</math>, we have
<math>y_{n+1}=y_n+\frac{h}{2}\lambda y_{n+1}+\frac{h}{2} \lambda y_n \!\,</math>
If we let <math>h \lambda =z \!\,</math>, and rearrange the equation we have
<math>y_{n+1}= \underbrace{\left( \frac{1+\frac{z}{2}}{1-\frac{z}{2}}\right)}_M y_n \!\,</math>
We require <math>M <1 \!\,</math>. This is true if <math>\lambda \!\,</math> is a negative real number.
== Problem 5c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Suppose that <math>f(t,y)=Ay\!\,</math> where <math>A \in R^{n\times n} \!\,</math> is a symmetric matrix and <math>y \in R^n \!\,</math>. Examine the properties of <math> A\!\,</math> which guarantee that the method is absolutely stable (Hint: study the eigenvalues of <math>A \!\,</math>).
|}
==Solution 5==
We now want instead
<math>\left\| \frac{1+\frac{h}{2}A}{1-\frac{h}{2}A} \right\| <1 \!\,</math>
i.e.
<math> \|1+ \frac{h}{2}A \| < \| 1- \frac{h}{2} A \| \!\,</math>
or (since <math>A\!\,</math> is symmetric)
<math>\rho(I+\frac{h}{2}Q \Lambda Q^T) < \rho(I-\frac{h}{2} Q \Lambda Q^T) \!\,</math>
or (since multiplying by orthogonal matrices does not affect the norm)
<math>\rho(I+\frac{h}{2}\Lambda ) < \rho(I-\frac{h}{2} \Lambda) \!\,</math>
or (by definition)
<math>\max_i \{ 1+\frac{h}{2}\lambda_i\} < \max_i \{ 1 - \frac{h}{2}\lambda_i \} \!\,</math>
If <math>A \!\,</math> is negative definite (all its eigenvalues are negative), the above inequality holds.
== Problem 6 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the following two-point boundary value problem in <math>(0,1): \!\,</math>
<math>(1) \qquad -u_{xx}+u = 1, \quad u'(0)=u'(1)=0 \!\,</math> |}
== Problem 6a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Give a variation formulation of (1), i.e, express it it as
<math>(2) \qquad u \in H: a(u,v)=F(v), \mbox{ for all } v \in H \!\,</math>
Define the function space <math>H \!\,</math>, the bilinear form <math>a \!\,</math>, and the linear functional <math>F\!\,</math> and state the relation between <math> (1)\!\,</math> and <math>(2) \!\,</math>. Show that the solution <math>u \!\,</math> is unique.
|}
== Solution 6a ==
===Variational Form === Derive the variational form by multiplying by test function <math>v \in H \!\,</math> and integrating from 0 to 1. Use integration by parts and substitute initial conditions to then have:
Find <math>u \in H = \{ v \in H^1(0,1) \} \!\,</math> such that for all <math> v \in H\!\,</math>
<math>\underbrace{\int_0^1 u'v' + \int_0^1 uv}_{a(u,v)} = \underbrace{\int_0^1 v}_{F(v)} \!\,</math>
===Relationship between (1) and (2) ===
(2) is an equivalent formulation of (1) but it does not involve second derivatives.
===Existence of Unique Solution ===
By the Lax-Milgram theorem, we have the existence of a unique solution.
* bilinear form continuous/bounded: <math> a(u,v) \leq C \|u\|_1 \|v\|_1 \!\,</math>
* bilinear form coercive: <math> a(u,u) \geq 1 \cdot \|u\|_1^2 \!\,</math>
* functional bounded: <math> F(v) \leq \|v\|_1 \!\,</math>
<math> \begin{align} \int v &= \int 1 \cdot v \\ &\leq \|1\| \|v\|_0 \\ &\leq \|v\|_1 \end{align} \!\,</math>
== Problem 6b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the finite element method with piecewise linear elements over a uniform partition <math>P=\{ x_i=(i-1)h\}_{i=1}^N \!\,</math> with meshsize <math>h=\frac{1}{N-1} \!\,</math>. If <math>U=(u_i)_{i=1}^N \!\,</math> is the vector of nodal values of the finite element solution, find the stiffness matrix <math>A \!\,</math> and right hand side <math>F \!\,</math> such that <math>AU=F \!\,</math>. Show that <math>A \!\,</math> is symmetric and positive definite. Show that solution <math>U \!\,</math> is unique
|}
==Solution 6b==
Define hat functions <math>\{ \phi_i \}_{i=1}^N \!\,</math> as basis of the discrete space. Note that <math>\phi_0 \!\,</math> and <math>\phi_n \!\,</math> have only half the support as the other basis functions. Using this basis we have
<math> \underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} \frac{h}{3}+\frac{1}{h} & \frac{h}{6}-\frac{1}{h} & & & & & \\ \frac{h}{6}-\frac{1}{h} & \frac{2}{3}h + \frac{2}{h} &\frac{h}{6}-\frac{1}{h}& & & & \\ & \ddots & \ddots &\ddots &&& \\ & & & &&\frac{h}{6}-\frac{1}{h}&\frac{h}{3}+\frac{1}{h} \end{bmatrix} }_A \underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \\ \vdots \\ u_n \end{bmatrix} }_U = \underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} \frac{h}{2} \\ h \\ \vdots \\ \frac{h}{2} \end{bmatrix} }_F \!\,</math>
Observe that <math>A \!\,</math> is symmetric. It is positive definite by Gergoshin's theorem. The solution <math>U \!\,</math> is unique since <math>A \!\,</math> is diagonally dominant.
== Problem 6c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider two partitions <math>P_1 \!\,</math> and <math>P_2 \!\,</math> of <math> [0,1]\!\,</math>, with <math>P_2 \!\,</math> a refinement of <math>P_1 \!\,</math>. Let <math>V_1 \!\,</math> and <math>V_2 \!\,</math> be the corresponding piecewise linear finite element spaces. Show that <math>V_1 \!\,</math> is a subspace of <math> V_2\!\,</math>
|}
== Solution 6c ==
If <math>v \in V_1 \!\,</math> then it is also in <math>V_2 \!\,</math> since <math> P_2 \!\,</math> is a refinement of <math>P_1 \!\,</math>. In other words, since <math> V_1\!\,</math> is piecewise linear over each intervals, it is also piecewise linear over a refinement of its interval.
== Problem 6d == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>u_1 \in V_1 \!\,</math> and <math>u_2 \in V_2 \!\,</math> be the finite element solutions. Show the orthogonality equality.
<math>\|u-u_1\|_{H^1}^2= \|u-u_2\|_{H^1}^2 + \|u_1 - u_2 \|_{H^1}^2 \!\,</math>
|}
==Solution 6==
From orthogonality of error, we have
<math>a(u-u_h, v_h)=0 \!\,</math> for all <math>v \in V_h \!\,</math>
Specifically,
<math>a(u-u_2, u_1-u_2)=0 \!\,</math>
Then
<math>\underbrace{a(u-u_1,u-u_1)}_{\|u-u_1\|_{H^1}^2}+2\underbrace{a(u-u_2,u_1-u_2)}_0=\underbrace{a(u-u_2,u-u_2)}_{\|u-u_2\|_{H^1}^2}+\underbrace{a(u_1-u_2,u_1-u_2)}_{\|u_1-u_2\|_{H^1}^2} \!\,</math>
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/Jan05 667

revision.text:
==Problem 4== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Let <math>f: R^n \rightarrow R \!\,</math> be a nonlinear smooth function. To determine a (local) minimum of <math>f \!\,</math> one can use a descent method of the form
:<math>x_{k+1}=x_k+\alpha_k d_k \quad (k \geq 0)\quad \quad (1) \!\,</math>
where <math>0 \leq \alpha_k \leq 1 \!\,</math> is a suitable parameter obtained by backtracking and <math> d_k </math> is a descent direction i.e. it satisfies
:<math>f(x_{k+1}) < f(x_k) \quad \quad (2) \!\,</math> |}
==Problem 4a== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the steepest descent method (or gradient) method and show that there exist <math> 0 < \alpha_k \leq 1\!\,</math> such that the resulting method satisfies (2)
|}
==Solution 4a==
===Steepest Descent Method===
<math>x_{k+1}=x_k-\alpha_k \nabla f(x_k) \!\,</math>
Choose <math>\alpha_k \in (0,1] \!\,</math> such that <math> \alpha_k \!\,</math> minimizes <math>f(x_k-\alpha_k \nabla f(x_k)) \!\,</math> i.e.
<math>\alpha_k : \min_{0 < \alpha_k \leq 1} f(x_k - \alpha_k \nabla f(x_k)) \!\,</math>
===Directional Derivative Negative===
To satisfy (2), the directional derivative should be negative i.e.
<math>\nabla_{d_k} f(x_k) = \lim_{\alpha_k \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x_k+\alpha_k d_k)-f(x_k)}{\alpha_k} <0 \!\,</math>
which implies
<math>\underbrace{f(x_k+\alpha_kd_k)}_{f(x_{k+1})} < f(x_k)\!\,</math>
since <math>\alpha_k \in (0,1]\!\,</math>
==Problem 4b== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the Newton method and examine whether or not there exist <math>\alpha_k \!\,</math> which yield (2). Establish conditions on the Hessian <math>H(f(x)) \!\,</math> of <math> f(x)\!\,</math> which guarantee the existence of <math>\alpha_k \!\,</math>.
|}
==Solution 4b== ===Newton's Method=== <math>x_{k+1}=x_k-H^{-1}(f(x_k))\nabla f(x_k) \!\,</math>
===Directional Derivative Negative=== To have descent, we want the directional derivative to be negative i.e.
<math> \nabla_{\alpha_k d_k} f(x_k) = \nabla f(x_k) \cdot \alpha_k d_k= - \nabla f(x_k) \cdot H^{-1}(f(x_k)) \nabla f(x_k) < 0 \!\,</math>
which implies
<math>\nabla f(x_k)^T H^{-1}(f(x_k)) \nabla f(x_k) > 0 \!\,</math>
Therefore <math>H^{-1}(f(x_k)) \!\,</math> is positive definite and therefore <math>H(f(x_k)) \!\,</math> is positive definite.
==Problem 4c== {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
If we replace the Hessian by the matrix <math>H(f(x))+ \gamma_k I \!\,</math>, where <math>\gamma_k \geq 0 \!\,</math> and <math>I </math> is the identity matrix, we obtain a quasi-Newton method. Find a condition on <math>\gamma_k \!\,</math> which leads to (2). |}
==Solution 4c==
We now want <math>\tilde{H}(f(x_k))=H(f(x_k))+\gamma_kI \!\,</math> to be positive definite.
Let <math>\lambda_i \!\,</math>, <math>i=1,2,\ldots,n \!\,</math> be the eigenvalues of <math>H(f(x_k)) \!\,</math>.
Then <math> \lambda_i + \gamma_k \cdot 1\!\,</math>, <math> i=1,2,\ldots,n\!\,</math> are eigenvalues of <math>\tilde{H}(f(x_k)) \!\,</math>.
Since we want <math>\tilde{H}(f(x_k)) \!\,</math> to be positive definite, we equivalently have for <math>i=1,2,\ldots,n \!\,</math>
<math>\lambda_i + \gamma_k > 0 \!\,</math>
i.e.
<math>\gamma_k > -\lambda_i \quad i=1,2,\ldots,n \!\,</math>
== Problem 5 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the following nonlinear autonomous initial value problem in <math>R </math> with <math>f \in C^2 </math>.
:<math>y'=f(y) \quad \quad y(0)=y_0 </math>
|}
== Problem 5a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the ODE in integral form and use the mid-point quadrature rule to derive the mid-point method with uniform time-step <math>h=\frac{T}{N} </math>:
:<math>y_{n+1}=y_n+hf(\frac{y_{n+1}+y_n}{2}) </math>
|}
==Solution 5a==
For <math>x \in [x_n, x_{n+1}] \!\,</math>,
<math>y(x_{n+1})-y(x_n)=\int_{x_n}^{x_{n+1}} f(y(x))dx \approx h \cdot f\left(\frac{y_{n+1}+y_n}{2}\right) \!\,</math>
== Problem 5b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Define truncation error <math>T_n \!\,</math>. Assuming that <math>T_n=O(h^3) \!\,</math>, show an estimate for the error <math>|y(t_N)-y_N| \!\,</math>. What is the order of the method? (Hint: use that <math>f \!\,</math> is Lipschitz continuous.
|}
== Solution 5b == <math> \begin{align} |e_{n+1}| &= |y(t_{n+1}) - y_{n+1}| \\ &\leq |y(t_n) - y_n| + h \underbrace{\left| f \left( \frac{ y(t_{n+1}) - y(t_{n}) }{2} \right) - f \left( \frac{ y_{n+1} - y_{n} }{2}\right) \right| }_{\leq \frac{\gamma}{2}|y(t_{n+1}) - y(t_{n}) - y_{n+1} + y_{n}|} + \mathcal{O}(h^3) \\ &\leq |e_n| + \frac{h\gamma}{2} \left( |e_{n+1}| + |e_{n}| \right) + \mathcal{O}(h^3) \end{align} </math>
where <math>\gamma \!\,</math> is the Lipschitz constant of <math>f \!\,</math>. Rearranging terms we get
<math>|e_{n+1}| \leq \underbrace{\frac{1+\frac{h\gamma}{2}}{1-\frac{h\gamma}{2}}}_{C}|e_n| + \mathcal{O}(h^3) \!\,</math>
In particular, <math>|e_1| \leq C \underbrace{|e_0|}_{0} +\mathcal{O}(h^3) \!\,</math>
Then <math>e_{N} \!\,</math> is given by
<math> \begin{align} e_{N} &= \left( C^{N-1} + C^{N-2} + \cdots + C + 1 \right) \mathcal{O}(h^3) \\ &= \frac{C^N-1}{C-1} \mathcal{O}(h^3) \\ &\leq K \mathcal{O}(h^2)
\end{align} \!\,</math>
== Problem 5c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Prove that <math>T_n=O(h^3) \!\,</math> for this method. (Hint: expand first <math>y(t_{n+1}) \!\,</math> and <math>y(t_n) \!\,</math> around <math>\tau_n = t_n+ \frac{h}{2} \!\,</math> and next expand <math>f(\frac12(y(t_{n+1})+y(t_n))). \!\,</math> Also expand <math>y'(t) \!\,</math> around <math>\tau_n \!\,</math>.) |}
== Solution 5c == The midpoint method may be rewritten as follows:
<math>y(t_{n+1})=y(t_n)+\frac{h}{2}y'(t_{n+1})+\frac{h}{2}y'(t_n) + T_n \!\,</math>
which implies
<math>y(t_{n+1})-y(t_n)-\frac{h}{2}y'(t_{n+1})-\frac{h}{2}y'(t_n) = T_n \!\,</math>
Expanding each term around <math>\tau_n=t_n+\frac{h}{2} \!\,</math> yields <math> T_n\!\,</math>.
<math> \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \mbox{Order } h & y(t_{n+1}) & -y(t_n) & -\frac{h}{2}y'(t_{n+1}) & -\frac{h}{2} y'(t_n) & \Sigma \\ \hline &&&&&\\ 0& y(t_n+\frac{h}{2}) & -y(t_n+\frac{h}{2}) & --- & --- & 0 \\ &&&&&\\ 1& y'(t_n+\frac{h}{2})\frac{h}{2} & -y'(t_n+\frac{h}{2})(-\frac{h}{2}) & -\frac{h}{2}y'(t_n+\frac{h}{2}) & -\frac{h}{2}y'(t_n+\frac{h}{2}) & 0 \\ &&&&&\\ 2&\frac{y''(t_n+\frac{h}{2})}{2} \frac{h^2}{4}&-\frac{y''(t_n+\frac{h}{2}}{2}\frac{h^2}{4}&-\frac{h}{2}y''(t_n+\frac{h}{2})\frac{h}{2}& -\frac{h}{2}y''(t_n+\frac{h}{2})(-\frac{h}{2})&0\\ &&&&&\\ 3&O(h^3)&O(h^3)&O(h^3)&O(h^3)&O(h^3)\\ \hline \end{array} </math>
== Problem 6 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the following boundary two-point boundary value problem in <math>(0,1) \!\,</math> with <math>\epsilon << 1 \leq b:\!\,</math>
:<math>-\epsilon u_{xx}+bu_x = 1, \quad u(0)=u(1)=0 \!\,</math>
|}
== Problem 6a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the finite element method with piecewise linear elements over a uniform partition of <math>(0,1) \!\,</math> with meshsize <math>h \!\,</math>. If <math>U={U_i}_{i=0}^{I+1} \!\,</math> is the vector of nodal values of the finite element solution, find the (stiffness) matrix <math>A \!\,</math> and right-hand side <math> F\!\,</math> such that <math>AU=F \!\,</math>. Is <math>A \!\,</math> symmetric? Is <math>A \!\,</math> positive definite?
|}
== Solution 6a ==
===Weak Variational Formulation===
Multiplying the given equation by a test function <math>v \in H_0^1 [0,1] \!\,</math> and integrating from 0 to 1 gives the equivalent weak variational formulation:
Find <math>u \in H_0^1 [0,1] \!\,</math> such that for all <math>v \in H_0^1 [0,1] \!\,</math> the following holds
:<math>\underbrace{\epsilon \int_0^1 u' v' dx + b \int_0^1 u' v dx}_{a(u,v)} = \underbrace{\int_0^1 v dx}_{f(v)} \!\,</math>
===Discrete Variational Formulation===
Let <math>V_h = \{ v \in H_0^1 [0,1] : \left. v_h \right|_{[x_{i-1},x_i]}\mbox{ linear } \!\,</math> for <math>i=1,2,\ldots,n \} \!\,</math>
Then we have the discrete variational formulation which is an approximation to the weak variational formulation.
Find <math>u_h \in V_h \!\,</math> such that for all <math>v_h \in V_h \!\,</math>
:<math>a(u_h,v_h)=f(v_h) \!\,</math> ===Define basis for V_h===
Let <math>\{ \phi_i \}_{i=1}^n \!\,</math> be the linear "hat" functions which defines a basis for <math>V_h \!\,</math>.
<math> \phi_i(x)= \begin{cases} \frac{x-x_{i-1}}{h} & \mbox{ if } x\in[x_{i-1},x_i] \\ \frac{x_{i+1}-x}{h} & \mbox{ if } x\in[x_i,x_{i+1}] \\ 0 & \mbox{ otherwise } \end{cases} \!\,</math>
Then calculation yields the following: (draw pictures)
<math>\int_0^1 \phi_i(x) dx = h \!\,</math>
<math> \phi_i'(x)= \begin{cases} \frac{1}{h} & \mbox{ if } x\in[x_{i-1},x_i] \\ -\frac{1}{h} & \mbox{ if } x\in[x_i,x_{i+1}] \\ 0 & \mbox{ otherwise } \end{cases} \!\,</math>
<math> \int_0^1 \phi_i'(x)\phi_j'(x) dx= \begin{cases} \frac{2}{h} & \mbox{ if } i=j \\ -\frac{1}{h} & \mbox{ if } |i-j|=1 \\ 0 & \mbox{ otherwise } \end{cases} \!\,</math>
<math> \int_0^1 \phi_i(x)\phi_j'(x)dx= \begin{cases} 0 & \mbox{ if } i=j \\ \frac12 & \mbox{ if } i-j=1 \\ -\frac12 & \mbox{ if } i-j=-1 \\ 0 & \mbox{ otherwise } \end{cases} \!\,</math>
===Discrete Variational Formulation in Matrix Form=== Since <math>\{ \phi_i \}_{i=1}^n \!\,</math> is a basis for <math>V_h \!\,</math>,
:<math>u_h=\sum_{i=1}^n u_{hi}\phi_i \!\,</math>
Also, the discrete variational formulation may be expressed as
:<math>\epsilon \sum_{i=1}^n u_{hi} \int_0^1 \phi_i'(x)\phi_j'(x)dx+ b \sum_{i=1}^n u_{hi} \int_0^1 \phi_i'(x) \phi_j(x)dx = \int_0^1 \phi_j(x) dx \mbox{ for }j=1,2,\ldots,n\!\,</math>
which in matrix form is
<math>\underbrace{ \begin{bmatrix} 2\frac{\epsilon}{h} & -\frac{\epsilon}{h}+\frac{b}{2} & 0 & \cdots &\cdots & 0 \\ -\frac{\epsilon}{h}-\frac{b}{2} & 2\frac{\epsilon}{h} & -\frac{\epsilon}{h}+\frac{b}{2} & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & \ddots &\ddots & \ddots & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & \cdots &\cdots & 0 & -\frac{\epsilon}{h}-\frac{b}{2} & 2\frac{\epsilon}{h} \end{bmatrix}}_A \begin{bmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \\ \vdots \\ u_n \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} h\\ h\\ \vdots\\ h \end{bmatrix} \!\,</math>
<math>A \!\,</math> is not symmetric. <math>A \!\,</math> is positive definite if
:<math>\frac{\epsilon}{h}> \frac{b}{2} \!\,</math>
== Problem 6b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Find a relation between the three parameters <math>h, \epsilon, b \!\,</math> for <math> A\!\,</math> to be an <math>M-\!\,</math>matrix, i.e. to have <math>a_{ii} >0, a_{ij} \leq 0 \!\,</math> if <math>i \neq j \!\,</math> and <math>a_{ii} \geq -\sum_{i \neq j} a_{ij} \!\,</math>
|}
== Solution 6b == The first,second, and last rows all yield the same inequality for <math>A \!\,</math> to be an <math>M \!\,</math>-matrix:
:<math>\frac{\epsilon}{h} > \frac{b}{2} \!\,</math>
== Problem 6c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the upwind modification of the ODE
:<math>-(\epsilon+\frac{b}{2}h)u_{xx}+bu_x=1 \!\,</math>
Show that the resulting matrix <math>A \!\,</math> is an M-matrix without restrictions on <math>h, \epsilon \!\,</math> and <math>b \!\,</math>. |}
== Solution 6c ==
Substituting <math>\epsilon+\frac{b}{2}h \!\,</math> for <math>\epsilon \!\,</math> yields the following matrix <math>A \!\,</math>:
<math> \begin{bmatrix} 2\frac{\epsilon}{h} +b & -\frac{\epsilon}{h} & 0 & \cdots &\cdots & 0 \\ -\frac{\epsilon}{h}-b & 2\frac{\epsilon}{h}+b & -\frac{\epsilon}{h} & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & \ddots &\ddots & \ddots & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & \cdots &\cdots & 0 & -\frac{\epsilon}{h}-b & 2\frac{\epsilon}{h}+b \end{bmatrix} \!\,</math>
All off diagonal entries are <math>\leq 0 \!\,</math>. Diagonal entries are <math> >0\!\,</math>
The first row meets the last condition since
:<math> 2\frac{\epsilon}{h} +b \geq \frac{\epsilon}{h}\!\,</math>
The second row through (n-1) rows meets the last condition since
:<math> 2\frac{\epsilon}{h} +b \geq \frac{\epsilon}{h}+b + \frac{\epsilon}{b}\!\,</math>
The last row meets the last condition since
:<math> 2\frac{\epsilon}{h} +b \geq \frac{\epsilon}{h}+b\!\,</math>
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/Aug04 667

revision.text:
== Problem 5a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
State Newton's method for the approximate solution of
:<math>f(x)=0 \!\,</math>
where <math>f(x) \!\,</math> is a real-valued function of the real variable <math> x\!\,</math>
|}
==Solution 5a==
<math>x_{k+1}=x_k - \frac{f(x_k)}{f'(x_k)} \!\,</math>
== Problem 5b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
State and prove a convergence result for the method.
|}
== Solution 5b ==
<math> \begin{align} x_{k+1} &= x_k - f'(x_k)^{-1}f(x_k) \\ \underbrace{x_{k+1}-x_*}_{e_{k+1}} &= \underbrace{x_k - x_*}_{e_k} - f'(x_k)^{-1}f(x_k) \\ &=f'(x_k)^{-1}[f'(x_k)e_k - ( f(x_k) - \underbrace{f(x_*)}_0 ) ) \\ &=f'(x_k)^{-1}\left[f'(x_k)e_k - e_k\int_0^1 f'(sx_k+(1-s)x_*)ds \right] \\ &=f'(x_k)^{-1}\left[f'(x_k)e_k - f'(x_*)e_k - e_k \int_0^1 ( f'(sx_k+(1-s)x_*)-f'(x_*)) ds \right ] \\ \|e_{k+1}\| &\leq \|f'(x_k)^{-1}\| \left[ L \|e_k\|^2+\frac{L}{2}\|e_k\|^2 \right] \mbox{ where L is Lipschitz constant of } f' \\ &=\|f'(x_k)^{-1}\| \frac32 L \|e_k\|^2
\end{align} \!\,</math>
== Problem 5c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
What is the typical order of convergence? Are there situations in which the order of convergence is higher? Explain your answers to these questions.
|}
==Solution 5c==
The typical order of local convergence is quadratic.
Consider the Newton's method as a fixed point iteration i.e.:
<math>x_{k+1}=\underbrace{x_k-\frac{f(x_k)}{f'(x_k)}}_{g(x_k)} \!\,</math>
Then
<math>g'(x_k)=1-\frac{f'(x_k)^2-f'(x_k)f(x_k)}{f'(x_k)^2} \!\,</math>
<math>g'(x_*)=0 \!\,</math>
Expanding <math>g(x_k) \!\,</math> around <math>x_* \!\,</math> gives an expression for the error
<math>\underbrace{g(x_k)}_{x_{k+1}}=\underbrace{g(x_*)}_{x_*}+\underbrace{g'(x_*)}_0 e_k +\frac{g''(x_*)}{2}e_k^2 + \frac{g'''(\xi)}{6}e_k^3 \!\,</math>
Note that if <math>g''(x_*) =0 \!\,</math>, then we have better than quadratic convergence.
== Problem 6 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the boundary value problem
:<math> \begin{cases} -u''(x)+u(x)=f(x), 0 \leq x \leq 1 \\ u'(0)=2, u(1)=0 \end{cases} \qquad(1) \!\,</math>
|}
== Problem 6a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Derive a variational formulation for (1).
|}
==Solution 6a==
Find <math> u \in H \!\,</math> such that for all <math>v \in H = \{ v \in H^1[0,1]: v(1)=0 \} \!\,</math>
<math>\underbrace{\int_0^1 u'v' dx + \int_0^1 uv}_{a(u,v)} = \underbrace{\int_0^1 f v - 2 v(0)}_{f(v)} \!\,</math>
== Problem 6b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
What do we mean by Finite Element Approximation <math>u_h \!\,</math> to <math> u \!\,</math> |}
==Solution 6b==
Let <math> P=\{x_i\}_{i=0}^{N} \!\,</math> be a partition of <math>[0,1] \!\,</math>. Choose a an appropriate discrete subspace <math>V_h \!\,</math> and basis functions <math> \{\phi_i\}_{i=0}^N\!\,</math>. Then
<math>u_h = \sum_{i=0}^N u_{hi} \phi_i \!\,</math>
The coefficients <math>u_{hi} \!\,</math> can be found by solving the following system of equations:
For <math>j=0,1,\ldots,N \!\,</math>
<math>\sum_{i=0}^N u_{hi} \int_0^1 \phi_i' \phi_j' dx + \sum_{i=0}^N u_{hi} \int_0^1 \phi_i \phi_j dx = \int_0^1 f \phi_j - 2 \phi_j(0) \!\,</math>
== Problem 6c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
State and prove an estimate for
<math>\|u-u_h\|_1 \equiv \left( \int_0^1 |u(x)-u_h(x)|^2 dx + \int_0^1 |u'(x)-u_h'(x)|^2 dx \right)^{\frac12} \!\,</math>
|}
==Solution 6c ==
Cea's Lemma:
<math>\|u-u_h\|_1 \leq \inf_{v \in V_h} C \|u - v\|_1 \!\,</math>
In particular choose <math>v_I \!\,</math> to be the linear interpolant of <math> u\!\,</math>.
Then,
<math>\|u-u_h\| \leq C \|u''\|_\infty h \!\,</math>
==Alternative Solution 6c==
Let <math> \{x_k\}_0^n </math> be a discrete mesh of <math> [0,1] </math> with step size <math> h </math>. Consider the the following integral
<math> \int_{x_k}^{x_{k+1}} |u(x)-u_h(x)|^2 dx </math>.
For some <math>\xi_k\in [x_k, x_{k+1}]</math>, <math> u(x)-u_h(x)=u'(\xi_k)*h </math> as <math> u_h </math> is just a linear interpolation on this interval. Hence
<math> \int_{x_k}^{x_{k+1}} |u(x)-u_h(x)|^2 dx=\int_{x_k}^{x_{k+1}} h^2 u'(\xi_k)^2 dx=h^3 u'(\xi_k)^2\leq h^3 ||u'||_\infty </math>.
Similarly, we can bound the <math> L_2(x_k, x_k+h) </math> norm of the error in the derivatives with <math> h^3 ||u''||_\infty </math>. With <math> n=1/h </math> such intervals we have
<math>\ ||u-u_h\||^2 \leq 2nh^3 \max(||u'||^2_\infty, ||u''||^2_\infty)=2h^2 \max(||u'||^2_\infty, ||u''||^2_\infty) .</math>
== Problem 6d == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Prove the formula
<math>\|u-u_h\|_1^2=\|u\|_1^2-\|u_h\|_1^2 \!\,</math>
|}
== Solution 6d==
<math> \begin{align} \underbrace{a(u-u_h,u-u_h)}_{\|u-u_h\|_1^2}+ 2 \underbrace{a(u-u_h,u_h)}_0 &= a(u,u)-2a(u,u_h)+a(u_h,u_h)+2a(u,u_h)-2a(u_h,u_h) \\ &=a(u,u)-a(u_h,u_h) \\ &=\|u\|_1^2 - \|u_h\|_1^2 \end{align} \!\,</math>
== Problem 7 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the initial value problem
:<math>y'=f(t,y), \quad y(t_0)=y_0 \!\,</math>
where <math>f \!\,</math> satisfies the Lipschitz condition
:<math> | f(t,y)-f(t,z)| \leq L|y-z| \!\,</math>
for all <math>t,y,z \!\,</math>. A numerical method called the midpoint rule for solving this problem is defined by
:<math>y_{n+1}=y_{n-1}+2hf(t_n,y_n) \!\,</math>
where <math>h \!\,</math> is a time step and <math>y_n \approx y(t_n) \!\,</math> for <math>t_n=t_0+nh \!\,</math>. Here <math>y_0 \!\,</math> is given and <math>y_1 \!\,</math> is presumed to be computed by some other method. |}
== Problem 7a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Suppose the problem is posed on a finite interval <math>t_0 \leq t \leq b \!\,</math> where <math>h=\frac{(b-t_0)}{M} \!\,</math>. Show directly,i.e., without citing any major results, that the midpoint rule is stable. That is show that if <math>\hat{y_0} \!\,</math> and <math>\hat{y_1} \!\,</math> satisfy
:<math>|y_0-\hat{y_0}| \leq \epsilon, \quad |y_1-\hat{y_1}| \leq \epsilon \!\,</math>
then there exists a constant <math>C\!\,</math> independent of <math>h \!\,</math> such that
:<math>|y_n -\hat{y_n}| \leq C \epsilon \!\,</math>
for <math>0 \leq n \leq M \!\,</math> |}
==Solution 7a ==
<math> \begin{align} y_{n+1} &= y_{n-1} + 2h f(t_n,y_n) \\ \hat{y}_{n+1} &= \hat{y}_{n-1} + 2h f(t_n, \hat{y}_n) \end{align} </math>
Subtracting both equations, letting <math>e_n \equiv y_n -\hat{y}_n \!\,</math>, and applying the Lipschitz property yields,
<math> \begin{align} e_{n+1} &\leq e_{n-1} + 2hL e_n \\ &\leq (1+2hL) \max \{ e_n, e_{n-1} \} \end{align} \!\,</math>
Therefore,
<math> \begin{align} e_n &\leq (1+2hL)^{n-1} \epsilon \\ &\leq (1+2hL)^n \epsilon \\ &\leq e^{2Lhn} \epsilon \\ &\leq e^{2L(t_n-t_0)} \epsilon \end{align} \!\,</math>
== Problem 7b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Suppose instead we are interested in the long term behavior of the midpoint rule applied to a particular example <math>f(t,y)=\lambda y \!\,</math>. That is, let <math> h \!\,</math> be fixed and let <math>n \rightarrow \infty \!\,</math> so that the rule is applied over a long time interval. Show that in this case the midpoint rule does not produce an accurate approximation to the solution to the initial value problem.
|}
== Solution 7b ==
Substituting into the midpoint rule we have,
<math>y_{n+1}=y_{n-1}+2h \lambda y_n \!\,</math>
or
<math>y_{n+1}-2h\lambda y_n - y_{n-1}=0 \!\,</math>
The solution of this equation is given by
<math>y_n = C_1 z_1^n + C_2 z_2^n \!\,</math>
where <math>z_1, z_2 \!\,</math> or the roots of the quadratic
<math>z^2-2h\lambda z - 1 \!\,</math>
The quadratic formula yields
<math>z= h\lambda \left(1 \pm \sqrt{1+\frac{4}{4h^2 \lambda^2}} \right) \!\,</math>
If <math>\lambda \!\,</math> is a small negative number, than one of the roots will be greater than 1. Hence, <math>y_{n} \rightarrow \infty \!\,</math> as <math> n \rightarrow \infty\!\,</math> instead of converging to zero since <math>y(t)=e^{\lambda t} \!\,</math>.
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

page.title: Numerical Methods Qualification Exam Problems and Solutions (University of Maryland)/Jan04 667

revision.text:
== Problem 4a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the boundary value problem
:<math> \begin{cases} -u''(x)+b(x)u(x)=f(x), 0\leq x \leq 1 \\ u(0)=u_l, u(1)= u_r \end{cases} \qquad (1) \!\,</math>
where <math>b(x), f(x) \in C[0,1] \!\,</math>, and <math>b(x) \geq 0 \!\,</math>. Formulate a difference method for the approximate solution of <math>(1) \!\,</math> on a uniform mesh of size <math>h \!\,</math>. Explain how <math>u''(x) \!\,</math> is approximated by a difference quotient |}
== Solution 4a==
From Taylor expansion of <math>u(x+h) \!\,</math> and <math>u(x-h) \!\,</math> around <math>x \!\,</math>, we have
<math> u''(x) = \frac{u(x+h)-2u(x)+u(x-h)}{h^2} + \frac{u''''(\xi)}{12}h^2 \!\,</math>
Let <math>P=\{x_i\}_{i=0}^{N+1} \!\,</math> be a uniform partition of <math>[0,1] \!\,</math> with step size <math> h\!\,</math>
Then for <math>i=2,\ldots, N-1 \!\,</math> we have
<math> \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{1}{h^2} &&& \frac{2}{h^2} + b(x_i) &&& -\frac{1}{h^2} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_{i-1} \\ u_i \\ u_{i+1} \end{bmatrix} = f(x_i) \!\,</math>
For <math>i=1: \!\,</math>
<math> \begin{bmatrix} \frac{2}{h^2}+b(x_1) &&& -\frac{1}{h^2} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \end{bmatrix} =f(x_1) + \frac{u_l}{h^2} \!\,</math>
For <math>i=N: \!\,</math>
<math> \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{1}{h^2} &&& \frac{2}{h^2}+b(x_N) \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_{N-1} \\ u_N \end{bmatrix} =f(x_N)+ \frac{u_r}{h^2} \!\,</math>
== Problem 4b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Suppose <math>b(x)=0 \!\,</math> and <math>u_l=u_r=0 \!\,</math> in <math>(1) \!\,</math>. Formulate a finite element method for the approximate solution of <math> (1)\!\,</math> in this special case, again on a uniform mesh. Using the standard "hat functions" basis for the finite element space, write out the finite element equations explicitly. Show that if an appropriate quadrature formula is used on the right-hand side of the finiite element equations, they (the finite element equations) are the same as the finite difference equations. |}
== Solution 4b ==
<math> \begin{bmatrix} \frac{2}{h} & -\frac{1}{h} & & & \\ -\frac{1}{h} & \frac{2}{h} &-\frac{1}{h} & & \\ & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \\ & & & -\frac{1}{h}& \frac{2}{h} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_1 \\ \vdots\\ \vdots\\ u_N \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \int_0^1 f \phi_i \\ \vdots \\ \\ \int_0^1 f \phi_N \end{bmatrix} \!\,</math>
Since we are integrating hat functions on the right hand side, an appropriate quadrature formula would be to take half of the midpoint rule. The regular midpoint rule would give double the actual integral value of a hat function.
Therefore <math>\int_0^1 f(x) \phi_i(x) \approx h f(x_i) \!\,</math>
Then the finite difference method and the finite element method yield the same matrix.
== Problem 4c == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Show that the matrix in <math>(b) \!\,</math> is non singluar.
|}
==Solution 4c==
Since the matrix is diagonally dominant, it is non-singular.
To show that the matrix has a non-zero determinant, 2n elementary row operation can be used to show that
<math>
\begin{bmatrix} \frac{2}{h} & -\frac{1}{h} & & \\ -\frac{1}{h} & \frac{2}{h} &-\frac{1}{h} & \\ & \ddots & \ddots & \\ & & -\frac{1}{h}& \frac{2}{h} \end{bmatrix} </math>
has the same determinant as
<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-\frac{1}{h} & \frac{2}{h} &-\frac{1}{h} & \\ & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \\ & & -\frac{1}{h}& \frac{2}{h}\\ & & & \frac{n+1}{h} \\ \end{bmatrix}
</math>
which is <math>\frac{n+1}{h^n}\neq 0</math>.
== Problem 5 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Consider the following dissipative initial value problem,
<math> \begin{cases} y'+f(y)=0, 0 \leq x \leq 1 \\ y(0)=y_0 \end{cases} \qquad (2) \!\,</math>
where <math>f: R \rightarrow R \!\,</math> is smooth and satisfies <math>0 \leq f'(y) \!\,</math>
|}
== Problem 5a == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Write the Backward Euler Method for (2). This gives rise to an algebraic equation. Explain how you would solve this equation.
|}
== Solution 5a ==
Using Taylor Expansion we have
<math> \begin{align} y(x-h) &= y(x)-y'(x)h +\frac{y''(\xi)}{2} h^2 \\ y(x) &= y(x-h)+y'(x)h - \frac{y''(\xi)}{2}h^2 \\ y(x_n) &= y(x_{n-1})+\underbrace{y'(x_n)}_{-f(y(x_n))}h - \underbrace{\frac{y''(\xi)}{2}h^2}_{O(h^2)} \qquad (*) \\ \end{align} </math>
Thus we have Backwards Euler Method:
<math> y_n = y_{n-1} - h f(y_n)\qquad (**)\!\,</math>
Let <math>e_n \equiv y(x_{n-1})-y_n \!\,</math>
== Problem 5b == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
Derive an error estimate of the form
:<math> |y(x_n)-y_n | \leq \frac{M}{2}h, n=1,2,\ldots \!\,</math>
where <math>M=\max_{0 \leq x \leq 1} |y''(x)| \!\,</math>. Do this directly, not as an application of a standard theorem. (Note that there is no exponential on the right hand side. |}
==Solution 5b==
Subtracting <math>(*) \!\,</math> and <math>(**) \!\,</math>, we have
<math> \begin{align} e_n &= e_{n-1}-h [ f(y(x_n))-f(y_n)] - \frac{y''(\xi)}{2}h^2 \\ &= e_{n-1}-h f'(y(\alpha)) e_n - \frac{y''(\xi)}{2} h^2 \quad \mbox{ (by MVT) } \\ e_n^2 &= e_{n-1}e_n - h \underbrace{f'(y \alpha)}_{< 0} e_n^2 - \frac{y''(\xi)}{2} h^2 e_n \\ &\leq e_{n-1}e_n - \frac{y''(\xi)}{2}h^2 e_n \\ e_n &\leq e_{n-1} - \frac{y''(\xi)}{2}h^2 \\ \| e_n \| &\leq \|e_{n-1}\|+ \frac{\|y''\|_\infty}{2}h^2 \\ \| e_n \| &\leq n \frac{\|y''\|_\infty}{2}h^2 \\ &\leq \frac{M}{2} h \end{align} \!\,</math>
== Problem 6 == {| WIDTH="80%" |- | style="background-color: #FFFFEE; border: solid 1px #FFC92E; padding: 1em;" valign="top" |
|}
==Solution 6==
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

revision.text:
The mesh topology diagram contradicts the text. The text says that each node connects with at least two other nodes, but there are nodes on the diagram that do not! [[User:Epachamo|Epachamo]] ([[User talk:Epachamo|talk]]) 13:08, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
: Thanks for pointing this out. This page's content was first based on a previous editor's text in an edition of the book that was geared toward an older version of the exam. I've made an attempt to correct this discrepancy. Eventually things will be filled in and polished throughout the book with the help of individuals like yourself. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 14:12, 27 May 2009 (UTC)

== Join Us! ==
{{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"| "User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks!
You should consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or logging in]]. It's free and requires no personal information. Here are some advantages:
* A username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, as your IP address will be hidden from most users. * Your own personal user page and talk page. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will directly attributed to you. * The use of your own [[Help:Watching pages|watchlist]] to monitor pages that you are interested in. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community.
We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]]. Be sure to sign your talk page comments with four tildes (<nowiki>~~~~</nowiki>).
| {{#if: | |<!-- this is so if anyone tries to use it where it doesn't go they will know. --> {{mbox|type=warning|This template must only be used on '''User [[Help:Talk page|discussion]]''' pages.}} }} }}--[[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 14:02, 27 May 2009 (UTC)

Hi Maria, I enjoyed reading about your personal background and educational philosophy. I am also going for my Interdisciplinary Studies Pk-6 degree. And like you, I was first thinking about going into the nursing/pediatric field, but decided teaching was my dream. El Savador sounds like a wonderful place I would absolutely love to visit one day. I really admire your parents for giving you and your sister a bilingual experience. I am interested in your thoughts on bilingual education. Do you think learning a second language beginning in the elementary years would be beneficial to students? I greatly agree with your educational philosophy. Teachers should strive to learn and understand the needs of their students. You spoke of children with special needs. I think labeling these students in Kindergarten with the special needs they have will give the students the best placement and opportunities for their unique learning styles. [[User:Afett001|Afett001]] ([[User talk:Afett001|talk]]) 14:04, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
Hi Maria, I like the way you worded your Philosophy. It was short and to the point, and I think that is great. Although it could have been a little more detailed. I also figured out that i wanted to work in a field that involved children at a young age. I think the majority of the students in this class would agree with you when it comes to finding a job shortly after graduation. Addressing whether or not a student has a learning disability at a young is very important. [[User:Rcoll029|Rcoll029]] ([[User talk:Rcoll029|talk]]) 1:27, 28 May 2009 (UTC)
Maria, I like your "About the Author" Page since I can identify with it as well. I am also of hispanic decent and the bilingual experience has been unforgettable for me, therefore I will teach it in the future as a foreign language education teacher. Your philosophy is very true. Catering to each child's need is the primordial part of teaching and Im glad you see it as well. Every child has a different learning method and as teachers we should all see that we may have to vary our curriculums.[[User:Ehern004|Ehern004]] ([[User talk:Ehern004|talk]]) 15:30, 30 May 2009 (UTC)

you shall *NOT* add specialization of swap in std, you shall provide overload in the type's namespace [27 May 2009] : True, although it's not illegal provided it's a specialization (as opposed to an overload), and even Sutter and Alexandrescu in their Coding Standards book (item 66) imply that this is a commonly adopted, acceptable solution if your compiler(s) don't support Koenig lookup. At least, that's my reading. [[Special:Contributions/221.47.185.5|221.47.185.5]] ([[User talk:221.47.185.5|talk]]) 03:27, 19 July 2009 (UTC)
This page is very wrong. Defining swap in both std and class namespace? Calling it a "common practice"? A link to comp.lang.c++.moderated discussion at the end of the page provides the correct solution, but it's completely ignored here. As it was already mentioned, you should provide an overload in the namespace of the class. When using swap, however, you shouldn't qualify it. You should do an unqualified call: 'using std::swap; swap(...);'. All compilers support ADL nowadays. It's not 1990ies any more.
I should add that for class templates it's not even possible to provide a swap specialization in the std namespace (no partial specializations for functions allowed). But if someone wants to do it as this page suggests, he'll end up with an overload. This overload will be illegal according to the Standard and it will interfere with swap specializations. '''Specializations do not overload''' - this language rule will put the ill-conceived swap overload ahead of properly written specializations in the overload resolution order. And it will likely result in some very strange compile-time error messages or runtime bugs.

revision.comment: moved [[Merge and acquisition]] to [[Management Strategy]] over redirect: Subpages use this root.
revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Management Strategy]]

Hi Angelia, nice to meet you in Wiki-world. That was some planning on the birth of your children. I have a son and a neice that was born on the same day (15 hours apart). I have worked with fifth and sixth graders going on nine years now, and have thought about working with the primary school students. I think I would like the change. What are the ages in your daycare? I like your educational philosophy, especially about how the classroom should bright and fun. I like doing the bullentin boards and seeing if the students notice the change. I like the idea about group assignments because it would give the students a chance to get to know each other and bounce ideas off each other and it helps them become critical thinkers. Parents should not only be involved in their child's classroom but also involved in the school (PTA). Good luck to you and all your endeavors.[[User:Msmhobbs04|Msmhobbs04]] ([[User talk:Msmhobbs04|talk]]) 23:52, 30 May 2009 (UTC)
Hi Angelia!
I think you have a great educational philosophy. I too firmly believe that parental involvement in your child’s education is so vitally important. My two youngest attend a small Catholic school in which I would describe the involvement of the parents as “nurturing”. Unfortunately, from my friends who teach in public schools at all grade levels, parental involvement seems to be more an exception than the rule. You sound like you have a great plan for your future classroom and I’m sure you’ll be a great teacher who really connects with your students. It is clear you really care about them. [[User:Sciaston|Sciaston]] ([[User talk:Sciaston|talk]]) 16:00, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
[[User:Jnewh001|Jnewh001]] ([[User talk:Jnewh001|talk]]) 13:08, 30 May 2009 (UTC) Hi Angelia,
I also agree with Sandra, you have great philosophy. I have always believed that children can tell the difference between a teacher who is there because they love it and the teacher that is there for the paycheck. I have had the experience with my daughters that I could see that they were not important to their teachers. That was frustrating for me and also for them because there was no motivation to please their teacher. One of my daughter had a teacher that left in the middle of the year to finish up her masters in library science and told the kids over and over that she was leaving teaching to go into library science because it was quieter. I was so upset, my daughter hated to go to school that year because she did not want to have to be in a class where a teacher did not want to be there. It has been my experience that as a supervisor of our aquatics instructional program that the teachers who engage their children, continue to make them feel special and important, and also who are present; have the most success with their children. That is what I hope to be able to do and in reading your philosophy, I am sure that you also concur. Parents are the bridges between students and teachers, that is one philosophy that we share! Good luck, Jill

Hey Rachel,
I just wanted to let you know that I loved the acronym you found from WVA! It should be posted in in every teachers classroom! Great job! [[User:Jkauf007|Jkauf007]] ([[User talk:Jkauf007|talk]]) 17:57, 10 June 2009 (UTC)
Hi Rachel!
Reading about your educational philosophy was so interesting! For a long time I did not know much about home schooling; however, I have 5 little cousins who are now home schooled (and have been for about 5 years or so) Learning about their educational experience is fascinating to me! They live in PA and have a huge home schooling community up there. So they do a lot of things at home where they are taught by their mom, but also get to do many activities and things with other home schooled children. Did you have any of that here in VA? I totally agree with the concept of finding teaching methods to benefit each child. Kids are SO different and all have unique needs. I think with your experience as a child combined with your chance to nanny will give you such a great foundation for teaching. I hope this semester goes well for you! See you in class! [[User:Khedl002|Khedl002]] ([[User talk:Khedl002|talk]]) 16:20, 29 May 2009 (UTC)khedl002
Hi Rachel-
Wow, you were blessed to have such a wonderful mother! My youngest nephew was diagnosed with ADD and with a little medication and a lot of nurturing from his Mom and Dad; he too has had great success in school. I feel so badly for all those kids out there that don’t get the support they need from their home and family like you had. Great teachers, like you said, are so often few and far between. I think about how differently their lives might be if they have someone who takes them by the hand and helps them understand how they need to learn and gives them the support and foundation they need to build upon for success when they move on to the next classroom. You have a unique experience, empathy and knowledge to take into your classroom to help all your students attain their goals. [[User:Sciaston|Sciaston]] ([[User talk:Sciaston|talk]]) 16:26, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
Hi Rachel
I would also like to commend your mom! Homeschooling can be difficult at times...especially with several children who have different learning styles. I agree with you that it is imperative to teach the classroom as a whole, but at the same time, understanding and accomodating the variances in learning styles. I think you will be able to use your homeschooling experiences to go above and beyond the traditional classroom setting in regards to curriculum, ie. a more hands-on approach. Enjoyed getting to know you...great outlook![[User:Scarlett1|Scarlett1]] ([[User talk:Scarlett1|talk]]) 06:31, 28 May 2009 (UTC)
Hello Rachel!
I believe your experiences in life will really help you in the classroom. Seeing teachers that come to the classroom after having "real world" experiences are a treat. Those teachers are able to relate to the kids and put education in real and interactive terms. While I understand the need for teachers to come straight out of school and into the classroom, it would be very beneficial for teachers to have some life experiences to draw on before teaching. For example in the business world, most MBA programs want their potential students to have real world experience to draw on before coming into their program. For them it helps bring the program alive. I believe the same is true for teachers who come into the classroom after spending time "living" before teaching. I look forward to working with you during this class! [[User:Jtmitchem|Jtmitchem]] ([[User talk:Jtmitchem|talk]]) 21:25, 28 May 2009 (UTC)
Rachel,
While I can see that a lot of people have already commented on your page, I also wanted to after reading your philosophy of education. First of all, I wanted to tell you that you should be very proud of what you have accomplished despite the severe ADD you faced. Your mother must have been a wonderful teacher to be able to guide you and prepare you so well to succeed even in a regular high school environment. I also agree that teachers need to assess the strengths and weaknesses of individual students in their classrooms so that inclusive classrooms can be successful. Interactive teaching strategies help to include all students and give everyone a chance to participate and learn something in the process. When a child stuggles in school, they may get discouraged. But if teachers can include them in various learning activities as you state in your philosophy, then they will not get so overwhelmed and feel better about learning. Thanks for such an interesting page! Have a great semester! [[User:Alucy001|Alucy001]] ([[User talk:Alucy001|talk]]) 20:19, 31 May 2009 (UTC)

I dig the chapter intro for School Organization. As soon as I started reading, I suspected you were the author. Kudos. [[User:Jenniferjkidd|Jenniferjkidd]] ([[User talk:Jenniferjkidd|talk]]) 03:21, 22 July 2009 (UTC)
Hey cutie. I would love to eat you like a donut. I tried to look for something wrong in your writing, but I had difficulty because it was so damn funny. [[User:Rebecca.hechler|Rebecca.hechler]] ([[User talk:Rebecca.hechler|talk]]) 23:04, 1 June 2009 (UTC)
Confession: Teaching is my back-up too. I want, more than anything, to be an opera singer. You want your life to be more like an elaborate fantasy novel, and I want my life to be more like an elaborate musical; specifically an opera. Try not to be so bitter :)[[User:Sbutl016|Sbutl016]] ([[User talk:Sbutl016|talk]]) 17:01, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
I really enjoyed reading your User page because not only did it make me laugh, it also made me believe in your philosophy of education. I think your future students will be lucky to have you as their professor because you are not afraid to take a risk with regards to teaching methods. I especially enjoyed reading how you propose to help your students become passionate about literature and learning in general...don't change a thing. Making learning correlate with students lives is novel approach...Kudos![[User:Scarlett1|Scarlett1]] ([[User talk:Scarlett1|talk]]) 06:16, 28 May 2009 (UTC)
Even though we've never met, and I certainly did not take that picture or buy that donut that you were consuming, I must congratulate you on your unorthodox approach. I too have plans to raise an army. May chance have it that we construct some massive chess board for scrimmage purposes and entice them to commence the battle of academic reckoning. It will be overwritten versus sloppily written– superheroes versus indieheroes– flip versus brit. There will be no parley... only the sweet sound of thundering war drums, the ripping of pages and the splatter of the darkest ancestral ink. In the end, we shall forge a new era. I dream of a day where I walk in a classroom as a teacher, make a Lovecraft or a Gaiman reference and hear a thunderous cacophony of voices asking for a high-five. [[User:Hsmit022|Hsmit022]] ([[User talk:Hsmit022|talk]]) 19:54, 28 May 2009 (UTC)
Hello BitterAsianMan, How intriguing it is to come across such an honest individual, their aren't many of you out there. I think your future classes will appreciate and remember you for it. I was off my chair at your wit and general approach to life. It's sad, because I remember reading Beowolf in high school, but nothing about the experience was memorable or offered a connection. It's nice to finally see someone in opposition to the norm, your passion will transfer to the students and ultimately resonate with them. Good luck, I look forward to reading about you someday! [[User:Rpaige|Rpaige]] ([[User talk:Rpaige|talk]]) 16:48, 30 May 2009 (UTC)

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/78.147.132.101|78.147.132.101]] ([[User talk:78.147.132.101|talk]]) to last version by Avicennasis
revision.text:
== Graphs == For C1 it is important to be able to draw graphs and labelling points of intersection between graphs, as well as axes intersection points i.e., where the graph crosses the x-axis and the y-axis. You must be familiar with the equation y = mx + c which is the equation for any straight line graph. For drawing a line graph, you must be able to put any linear equation into the above form and work out the gradient (m) and the y-intercept (+c) For example, the line y + x = 7, we must put it into the y = mx + c form, so we get y = -x + 7. From here we can see that the gradient is -1 and the line crosses the y axis at 7. We can substitute in anotehr x value, say 1, to get another y value (-1 + 7 = 6) so we have a gradient, -1, a y-intercept = 7, and a co-ordinate (-1,6) so now we can draw the line. To draw a quadratic graph, we must be familiar with factorizing (see relevant page) and from here we get the roots of the graph. The general shape for a quadratic is the parabola which is a U shape for a positive quadratic, and an upside-down U shape for a negative one. We can substitiue x = 0 into the equation of the quadratic to get the y-interecept.
== Transformations == There are 4 basic types of transformations y = f(x)+a - movement up by a units y = f(x-a) - movement along by a units (for f(x+a) it would be a movement along by -a units) y = af(x) - a vertical stretch of sf a y = f(ax) - a horizontal stretch of sf 1/a
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

==Tuple pronunciation==
It seems like the consensus on the pronunciation of the word Tuple prefers "TOO-pull" rather than "TUH-pull":
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/691437/how-do-you-pronounce-the-word-tuple
[[Special:Contributions/65.114.26.98|65.114.26.98]] ([[User talk:65.114.26.98|talk]]) 18:27, 27 May 2009 (UTC)

Hey Susan,
You article is starting to look great! As beneficial as it is to have links to other articles within yours, more information should be included within your answers. If you have any questions, please let me know. Have a great day! [[User:Jkauf007|Jkauf007]] ([[User talk:Jkauf007|talk]]) 18:10, 10 June 2009 (UTC)
Hi Susan!
When I read your "About the Author" page I couldn't believe how many things we have in common. The most obvious is that we are "teacher kids." I can still remember being in elementary school and being put in the other teacher's room so that I wouldn't have my mom in 5th grade. That same year a kid tried to pay me a quarter to get the answers for her on a math test. Don't worry, I didn't take the bait.
Do your fuzzy children have long lost siblings somewhere in Southside Virginia? I think I may have two of their long lost relatives living at my house. My Gertrude and Morticia look suspiciously like your two kitties. Hmmmmmm....
I, too, enjoy reading in what little spare time I have. Usually my nose is stuck in a textbook. When I get the opportunity to read "just for fun" I enjoy southern literature, especially Mary Kay Andrews and Ann B. Ross. I can't stand trashy romance novels! Give me a book with a juicy plot that makes you think anyday.
I agree with your philosophy of utiliziing a variety of instructional strategies in the classroom. It is important for all students to have the opportunity to learn regardless of their learning abilities. I love using technology in the classroom because it provides hands-on and visual learners an easier way to understand new concepts while reinforcing previously taught material.
It's great to see someone else interested in special education, too! Good luck this semester.
[[User:Acrow005|Acrow005]] ([[User talk:Acrow005|talk]]) 19:06, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
Hi Susan, I was looking through some of the pages and your cats caught my eye. I too grew up with a cat. I got her when I was nine and she just went to kitty heaven almost two years ago. I am also a dog lover. I have a airedale/blacklab mix named Lola who runs my life. I have had her since she was seven weeks and she is still as hyper as the day I got her. She definately keeps me on my toes.
I also in my very little spare time enjoy a good book. I got sucked into the Twilight series and it was actually really good. I am also reading a world geogrphy textbook right now, but it is not as good. haha.
I was a special education assistant all throughout high school. I started in eighth grade and loved the students so much I followed them to high school, well the ones that went on to my high school. I currently am observing in a kindergarten class and they are always using a large variety of educational tools. I agree with you it really does make a difference introducing students to a variety of tools. The teacher even has computers she sends the kids to use. I am very excited to be the teacher one day soon!
Good Luck with everything!! [[User:Lwill031|Lwill031]] ([[User talk:Lwill031|talk]]) 19:35, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
Hi Susan, Thanks for reading my page! Thank you for the compliments about my puppy! He is a Malti-poo. [[User:Regs1687|Regs1687]] ([[User talk:Regs1687|talk]]) 13:36, 2 June 2009 (UTC)
== Images ==
I appreciate the efforts to document the images, but information has not been provided on the options others have to reuse the above images. One of the licenses at [[WB:FILES#Licensing_Information]] would need to be placed on the image pages so that the terms of reuse are known. If the images cannot be reused, then Wikibooks cannot host the images. Thanks. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 19:30, 9 July 2009 (UTC)
Hello...Could you check and make sure things are correct with my pictures. I would not want anything deleted.
Thank you
:Thanks for updating the images. [[:File:Kiwi sitting on a chair.JPG]] and [[:File:Belleoncouch.JPG]] now have the information needed. The other images listed above still do not have information on them. However, they are not used by any pages, so maybe they were mistakenly uploaded and will not be used. The ones that you are using on your user page are good to go and will not be deleted. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 20:24, 10 July 2009 (UTC)
::Please provide information as you did for the two images above for [[:File:Beachtime.JPG]] as well. Thanks. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 00:59, 11 July 2009 (UTC)
I have tried to delete these pictures that are not in use on my pages but I am not able to figure out how to do that. Any help would be much appreaciated. Thank you
:They've now been deleted. Only certain people (administrators) can delete pages, images, etc. If you would like anything deleted in the future, you can add {{tlx|delete|Reasoning}} to the page and someone will see it shortly to take care of it. Thanks for your attention on this matter. Everything should now be taken care of. -- [[User:Adrignola|Adrignola]] <sup>[[User talk:Adrignola|talk]] [[Special:Contributions/Adrignola|contribs]]</sup> 19:52, 11 July 2009 (UTC)

revision.comment: Created page with 'Hi Mary! When I was reading your "About the Author" page, Blackstone caught my eye. I have a relative that is a police officer in Blackstone and another that works for VDOT. A…'
revision.text:
Hi Mary!
When I was reading your "About the Author" page, Blackstone caught my eye. I have a relative that is a police officer in Blackstone and another that works for VDOT. Also, I adopted my two cats from Donna at Critter Care. Small world, huh?
I think that it is wonderful that you have chosen to work towards your teaching license. Your work as an intructional assistant has and will continue to provide you with much needed experience. I have been a substitute and taught for one full year before making the decision to move forward with my education. Like you, I know the experience I gained in the classroom will serve me well in the future.
I, too, also prefer working with upper elementary students, specifically special education. I love to use tecnology in the classroom and love using the SMART board. It is great for showing multimedia clips, Powerpoint presentations, and allowing the students to participate in interactive lessons. What student likes to hear the teacher go on and on about a topic? Technology keeps students interested in the lesson being presented.
Good luck this semester and keep up the hard work!
[[User:Acrow005|Acrow005]] ([[User talk:Acrow005|talk]]) 19:29, 27 May 2009 (UTC)

Hi Heather,
Unlike you I am awful at biology, but high five to you for enjoying science. I also am not married yet, just waiting on that ring! :) I am currently working on my teaching licensure at ODU and have a bachelor's degree in psychology. I also very clearly remember some of the teacher's who changed my life. My high school psychology teacher is the reason I majored in psychology. I also remember my third grade teacher, only because she was very scary.
When reading your philosophy on teaching I felt many of our point were similar. I am a neat freak so I definately would like a well organized classroom. Although I do not know how long it will last teaching kindergarteners. I also enjoy group work. I always enjoyed group work in school therefore I believe I will utilize it in my classroom. I also believe visual learning is key. I overall would like my students to feel comfortable in the classroom and enjoy being there. I think how you set up a classroom is very important. I hope that both of our future students will enjoy our tidy classrooms.[[User:Lwill031|Lwill031]] ([[User talk:Lwill031|talk]]) 19:50, 27 May 2009 (UTC)

Hi, does anyone else have any interest in pursuing Medical Physiology? I have a lot of material that I can put up, and am in the process of loading this. However to get this book into some sort of usable form is going to take the joints efforts of a number of people. Frank Boumphrey 2009-06-03 - I hope to be finished the section on GI by the end of this week, then I will tackle the remainder of Biochemistry and the cell. Can we have some discussion on layout? F.B.--[[User:Boumphreyfr|Boumphreyfr]] ([[User talk:Boumphreyfr|talk]]) 00:34, 4 June 2009 (UTC)

Hello Lwill031,
I was skimming through these friendly about me profiles and came across your page. It seems as though we have lots in common, so I figured this would be an easy response. I also love the beach and have two mouthy hound dogs that keep me on my toes. They love a good, quiet beach and constantly require something to burn off all that extra energy. My dachshund is hilarious however, while his tiny legs just sink in the sand. They love their long walks though. (I think I love them too.) :D
Let’s see...I am originally from Western MD and then the Shenandoah Valley. However, once I came to the ocean, I figured there was no turning back. I also have a huge passion for cooking and a wonderful boyfriend who appreciates that. I have worked in restaurants for a long time, and although a not so fabulous career, I have learned many valuable "tricks of the trade". Nonetheless, I am always up for a new recipe. I graduated from ODU in 2004 with the same Psychology/Human Services degree. It seems as though you have put it to better use than I have. I really wanted to work with at risk teenagers, but found it difficult to obtain an okay paying job with my bachelors. So...here I am, happily pursuing my prek-6 licensure and then hopefully my masters in school counseling. Let's see...you had me until the kindergarten grade. I can really appreciate the impact kindergarten teachers have on emotional development, but am more of a 3rd grade teacher myself. I love the little ones and am hoping to soon teach the kindergarten class at my church. However, at the end of the day, I think I have a niche with third graders who still love their teachers, but are also ready to explore the world on their own. Lastly, I could not agree with you more about the ways in which you will structure your classroom. I feel children, especially at that age, need all forms of activities to engage their senses. Colors, music, dancing...fun and happiness. I also believe however, that amidst all the happiness, we must also send our students home with better emotion regulation skills, coping strategies, and preparation for everything the world has to offer.
Take care, have a wonderful summer, and a successful semester. Autumn [[User:Abitt002|Abitt002]] ([[User talk:Abitt002|talk]]) 22:17, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
Hello,Lyndsey
I loved reading your philosophy on education. It was great hearing from someone who has been in the classroom already and has seen first hand what it is like. I too love working with kids. I have ran a daycare out of my home for the past four years. I am pursuing the PreK-6 liscensure. It sounds like you will be a wonderful teacher and love every minute of it. [[User:Aferg006|Aferg006]] ([[User talk:Aferg006|talk]]) 04:08, 30 May 2009 (UTC)

Hi Afett001, Ahh...a fellow Winchester individual. I actually spent ten years of my life in the Shenandoah Valley. All of my high school years and then community college at Lord Fairfax. I came to Virginia Beach to attend ODU. It wasn't too far away from my family, but just far enough. Oh...and who could forget the beach? That was definitely a plus. I hope you are enjoying the beautiful mountains though. I always enjoyed being able to get lost on any of the side roads down route 50, 522, or even route 7. You don't realize how important wide-open spaces are until you don't have them anymore. There are not too many places to get lost in VA Beach. Maybe pungo...? I'm sure that area has grown a lot though. In the now eight years I have been away, I hear it has changed tremendously. I hope not too much. I don't get to visit that area too often anymore, as my parents have moved to Richmond and the rest of my family is in Western, MD. However, I will be driving through there over the weekend to visit my grandfather. I'll tell you, every October I miss those mountains. I miss skyline drive and even tacky apple blossom festival. I certainly miss the Long Branch hot air balloon and wine festival. If you haven't done that...I highly recommend it. I miss Sweet Caroline's, Brewbakers, and even Coalie Harry's for after work drinks with friends. I miss that old town feel that has live bands on weekends. I'm assuming none of this has changed, but perhaps it has. Nonetheless, I also love the beach. Wouldn't trade it either. I think it's funny that we never truly appreciate where we live until we are gone. Anywho...enough of the nostalgia...
I too ended up in a career that wasn't my passion. I am now happily pursuing my prek-6 licensure and would love to eventually finish my masters in school counseling. I think that teachers today face one of the most challenging, yet rewarding careers. We have opportunities to provide equality in our classrooms. We have opportunities to appreciate and respect the diversity of all our students. I'm with you...I believe that all elementary grades would be fine to teach, but I really love third grade. Fourth grade and fifth grade would be more preferable than the earlier years. I want to work with children who still love their teachers, but are secure enough and curious enough to explore their own curiosities. Well...take care, good luck, and have a wonderful summer. Autumn [[User:Abitt002|Abitt002]] ([[User talk:Abitt002|talk]]) 22:16, 27 May 2009 (UTC)
Hello. My name is Heather. I couldn't help but respond to your page because we share the same views. I am amazed that some people don't encourage group work. I am like you...it enables students to feed off of each other and see things in different perspectives. I couldn't agree with you more about patience. As an educator you must possess patience; if not, lord help ya!! Not all students are sweet and behave well. Believe me I know all about those don't listen, talk out of turn, yell at ya type of students. They can be very hard to deal with sometimes. However if we have patience it makes it easier, but then their are some that just can't be tamed and for those we have alternative school.:) Good luck with class and I hope you enjoy your career as an educator. [[User:Hcomb003|Hcomb003]] ([[User talk:Hcomb003|talk]]) 15:21, 30 May 2009 (UTC)
Hola Anakristen, beautiful name by the way. My name is Bianca. I could not help not to write on your page. As I read the information you wrote about yourself, I was intrigued on how much you have done in such a short life. You seem like a very hard working and nice loving person as well, I can imagine the chaos in the house with so many people and pets. As you, I love being around children. They always seem to light up the room but as I read your educational philosophy I had to strongly disagree with a specific point. Yes, teachers are great role models for students. They teach them to be not only good learners but they also instill basic positive personal experiences in their younger years. We are all entitled to our own opinion with that said I cannot help to understand why you believe that English is the only language that should be taught in school. Teachers not only should be able to handle diversity but they should also be diverse as well. I am not saying that all teachers should know more than one language but they should promote to students learning another language because of the benefits. This world has become so small, mixed and competitive especially in the job market. Having more than one language regardless of which one, it is such a privilege a benefit to students in their future. I love how you said that lecture lessons that are enforced by group activities reinforce a subject matter. I think this is true in every way and that some teachers don’t do it enough. Students benefit so much from other students when they are engaged in group projects. Different skills and ideas can be learned from others, this helps them not only learn how to work with other people but to develop a larger range of problem solving since they learn more and more with each project they are assigned.[[User:Bpenn005|Bpenn005]] ([[User talk:Bpenn005|talk]]) 17:18, 30 May 2009 (UTC)
Hello Anakristen! I have lived in Virginia for several years, but I have never been to northern Virginia. Although I do not have six cats, I do have a German Shepherd, so my own house does not have too many dull moments either. My degree is also for PreK-6, and I would prefer to teach fourth or fifth grade. I would not have a problem teaching 6th grade, however that is my limit, because I could never see myself teaching middle school or high school. Good instructional strategies are also essential in a classroom; even though student will constantly need your guidance as a teacher, it is good to teach them methods where they can solve problems on their own. This is especially true for special needs students, who need as much confidence and independence as they can receive. [[User:Adart001|Adart001]] ([[User talk:Adart001|talk]]) 20:25, 31 May 2009 (UTC)
Hello Anakristen, I had the privelege of reading your author page. I see that you have had a remarkable background in just the few years you've been out of high school. I can appreciate how you started a career as a banker. This gave you experience in a particular field, but now after some other experiences, you feel that teaching is right for you. I would like to congratulate you on finding a career path that you feel fits your interests and personal mission. I wish you all the best as you contine to pursue this track of work....I have zero dogs and cats, and so if and when I decided to get one or more such pets, I will contact you for some input. Thanks. Michael [[User:Mbrowder|Mbrowder]] ([[User talk:Mbrowder|talk]]) 01:42, 14 June 2009 (UTC)

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Political History of New Zealand/The First Political Parties]]

:::::::::'''Semester Two Review'''
A major theme we focused on this semester was the American Dream. The American Dream will be examined by looking back on some of the novels read this year. Some of these novels are: ''The Great Gatsby'' by F. Scott Fitsgerald, ''Of Mice and Men'' by John Steinbeck, and ''A Raisin in the Sun'' by Lorraine Hansberry. I only intend to show the theme as it is demonstrated in the literature.
The American Dream changes throughout ''The Great Gatsby''. At first, the American Dream seems like something that only the greatly wealthy possess. Yet, the American Dream seems to fade with exceeding wealth. So it can be noted that it's not as exciting to be rich and famous as it seems to be.
The American Dream is illustrated at different viewpoints in ''Of Mice and Men''. One biew is the pursuit of happiness, but with obstructions in the way. On the other hand, are the elderly really helpful to society? So it may be noted that there are different values for the American Dream.
The American Dream is displayed as a set of values in ''A Raisin in the Sun''. It appears as a person's dreams at first. Then it becomes a sense of one's goals, and the personal bond of a family. Thus, giving an even closer understanding of the American Dream.
All in all, it can be summarized that the American Dream is a subject that is often reviewed. In fact, many American novels touch the subject of the American Dream. Thus, the American Dream is recognized as a common subject in literature. Lastly, the imaginary in the novels mentioned above, help to describe the American Dream.

==2000 Election==
[[Image:George-W-Bush.jpeg|200px|right|thumb|George W. Bush]][[Image:Al Gore, Vice President of the United States, official portrait 1994.jpg|100px|left|thumb|Al Gore]] As Clinton's presidency came to a close, Democrats nominated Al Gore, Clinton's vice president, as their nominee, and the Republicans chose George W. Bush, the governor of Texas and son of former President George H.W. Bush.
Florida had traditionally been a Democratic-leaning state, but explosive population growth in the late nineties had brought many social and economic conservative Cubans to southern Florida. The growth had left Florida very evenly split among the parties.
On election night, the news media outlets first predicted Florida to go to Gore, then to Bush, and then decided that the race was too close to call. Florida law provided for an automatic recount when votes differ by such a small margin, and when Florida decided that Bush had won, Gore sued Bush to force further recounts in several Florida counties. Bush counter-sued, and the case went to the Supreme Court of the United States. In a 5-4 decision, the Court decided that the state of Florida must recount all the ballots in all the Florida counties and not just those for which Gore had sued, in accordance with the Equal Protection Clause of the U.S. Constitution. As Florida was required by the Florida Constitution to certify its election within days of the Court's decision<ref>[http://a257.g.akamaitech.net/7/257/2422/14mar20010800/frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/supremecourt/00-949_dec12.fdf Supreme Court decision]</ref>, there was not enough time to recount the entire state. Thus, the final state count stood, with Bush winning Florida by 537 votes, (and as a result receiving 271 electoral votes to Gore's 267, and therefore gaining the presidency), although he lost the popular vote. [[Image:US presidential election 2000 map.svg|thumb|250px|The 2000 Presidential Election.]]
== Early Bush Administration Policy ==
=== Domestic Affairs ===
=== Foreign Affairs ===
During the 2000 campaign, some had criticized George W. Bush on his qualifications in the realm of foreign relations as a state governor. One such incident which supposedly epitomized this lack of experience was when Bush was interviewed by a local television reporter and asked if he knew who the leader of Chechnya was and the name of the general who had recently taken over the government of Pakistan, to which Bush could not answer either. The perception early on in the Bush presidency was that his administration was relatively disinterested in foreign policy.
During the first eight months of his administration, one of the major issues concerned how to deal with North Korea, an issue which had also plagued his predecessor. On February 9, 2001, a U.S. Navy submarine, the USS ''Greeneville,'' collided with a Japanese fishing vessel, killing all nine aboard. President Bush promptly apologized for the incident.
The administration's first major foreign policy crisis came, however, on April 1, 2001, in the form of the '''Hainan Island incident,''' during which a U.S. Navy EP-3E ARIES II surveillance aircraft was forced to land at a Chinese military airport after colliding with a Chinese aircraft. One Chinese pilot was killed and the 24 member crew of the U.S. aircraft were detained by the Chinese government. The flight had occurred over a portion of the South China Sea over which the U.S. and China disagreed on the issue of U.S. naval overflights. The administration issued an apology for the death of the Chinese pilot as well as the entering of China's airspace to land, which the U.S. Ambassador Joseph Prueher said "did not have verbal clearance."
However, the early happenings of the Bush administration would be largely forgotten after the tragedy that struck one Tuesday morning.
==The Closing Decade== As the decade closes, it is hard to say what people will say of it. There has not yet been a name picked for this new decade.
{{reflist}} {{chapnav|New Ruler|Hope}}
